lQauI62r.title: Optimization of operating parameters for supercritical carbon dioxide extraction of lycopene by response surface methodology
lQauI62r.abstract: An experimental design was developed to investigate the effect of operating temperature, operating pressure and extraction time on lycopene yield and extract antioxidant activity (IC 50 ) during supercritical carbon dioxide extraction from tomato pomace. The statistical analysis of the experiment indicated that individual factors such as pressure and temperature, and interactive factors such as pressure with temperature and time had significant effects on lycopene yield. The central composite design showed that the polynomial regression models developed were in good agreement with the experimental results, with R 2 of 0.97 and 0.94 for lycopene yield and extract antioxidant activity, respectively. The optimal condition for lycopene extraction within the experimental range of the variables studied was at 57 °C, 40 MPa, and 1.8 h. At this condition, the predicted amount of lycopene extracted was 28.64 mg in 100 g dried tomato pomace (corresponding to 93% lycopene recovery). In order to investigate the effect of experimental extraction condition on the antioxidant activity of the extract, IC 50 was used as an index, which is the concentration that gives 50% reduction in the absorbance of the hydroxyl free radical. The analysis of the results relating to extract antioxidant activity showed that the individual effects of pressure and time, as well as their interactive effects, were significant. The statistical model gave the optimal point for antioxidant activity at 57 °C, 53 MPa, and 1.8 h of extraction, at which the value of 1/IC 50 was 12.31 ml/mg (i.e. IC 50 = 0.081 mg/ml). Keywords Lycopene Supercritical CO 2 extraction Antioxidant activity Response surface methodology 1 Introduction Lycopene is the main among several carotenoids in tomato. Lycopene molecule corresponds to isoprenoid polyenes (C 40 H 56 ), which contain eight C5-isoprene units, and has a central skeleton constituted of 22 carbon atoms, and two ends with an additional 9 carbon atoms each. It exhibits strong free-radical scavenging activity ( Jamal and Chieri, 2006 ) superior to vitamin C and protects against lipid peroxidation and oxidative damage of LDL-cholesterol, cells, tissues, and cell membranes. In general, lycopene is highly sensitive to light, oxygen and heat, and can be degraded easily during the conventional extraction using organic solvents due to extended exposure to oxidative stresses ( Macias-Sanchez et al., 2005 ). Hence, there is considerable industrial interest in isolating lycopene from biological substrates for use in nutraceuticals and related applications. Supercritical fluid extraction has established itself as an alternative to traditional, low-selectivity, and questionable isolation processes using organic solvents, because of the relatively low critical temperature ( T c = 304.1 K), inertness, and non-toxicity of carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) ( Felix-Valenzyela et al., 2001; Wang et al., 2001 ), the most commonly used supercritical solvent. Supercritical CO 2 extraction processes are typically carried out at near-environmental temperatures and in the absence of air, which reduces heat requirements, and avoids thermal and oxidative damage of labile compounds ( Mendes et al., 2003; Tonthubthimthong et al., 2001 ). There are several reports in literature on the supercritical CO 2 extraction of lycopene from tomato products ( Rozzi et al., 2002; Careri et al., 2001 ). Although supercritical carbon dioxide is nowadays considered a new alternative for benign extraction of natural compounds, the selection of the operating conditions for specific applications is still an area of active research. In the case of lycopene production from tomato, many recent studies have investigated the effects of operating conditions in order to find the optimal extraction conditions for the process ( Lamin et al., 2007; Topal et al., 2006; Ollanketo et al., 2001; Baysal et al., 2000 ). These previous investigations have reported that the total amount of lycopene extracted and its concentration in the extract are influenced by the extraction pressure and temperature. In most of the previous studies, the process conditions have been optimized merely by changing one variable-at-a-time. Such experiments do not consider interactions between process variables, which causes the results to be biased and the recommended operating conditions to be suboptimal. Although some of these researches have successfully extracted lycopene from tomato pomace by supercritical carbon dioxide extraction, the evaluation of the extract bioactivity, which is very important for industrial application of production from agricultural byproducts as functional additives, is scarcely considered in the extraction processes. Many researches have proven that the addition of an organic modifier such as ethanol can enhance the extraction efficiency of bioactive compounds by raising the solubility or extractive selectivity of CO 2 ( Lamin et al., 2007; Hasbay-Adil et al., 2007; Armando et al., 2006; Ruckenstein and Shulgin, 2002 ). In the case of processes influenced by multiple variables, statistical experimental design has been shown to be a powerful tool for determining the effects of operational factors and their interactions; this allows process optimization to be conducted effectively ( Wen et al., 2008a,b; Ozkal et al., 2005; Vasapollo et al., 2004 ). This technique has been used widely in the chemical industry and has been successfully applied to investigate the effects of extraction parameters on supercritical fluid extraction of lycopene and carotenoids ( Lamin et al., 2007; Careri et al., 2001 ). In this work, the experimental design and response surface methodology were applied to investigate the individual and interactive effects of operating pressure, temperature and extraction time on the amount of lycopene obtained from tomato pomace as well as the resultant antioxidant activity of the resulting extract by using ethanol-modified supercritical CO 2 as the extraction medium. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Tomato pomace was kindly provided by Xinjiang Tunhuaxin Tomato Product Co., Ltd. (Kuitun, Xinjing, China). Lycopene (purity > 98%, w/w, Sigma) was purchased from Shanghai Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All other chemicals and reagents were of the highest grade commercially available and purchased from Guoyao Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Chengdu, China). 2.2 Extraction of lycopene by soxhlet extraction To determine the total amount of lycopene in the extract, extraction was carried out in a soxhlet apparatus, in which 2 g of dried tomato pomace was extracted with 250 ml chloroform for 7 h until the color of the condensed solvent at the top of the apparatus was clear. 2.3 Pretreatment of sample The dried tomato pomace was saponified in 0.5 M aqueous NaOH at 40 °C for 45 min ensuring that the mixture was protected from light. The saponified tomato pomace was then neutralized to pH 7 using 1 M H 2 SO 4 , followed by centrifugation at 3000 r/min or 1730 g (F2402 H Allegra™ X-22R Cenrifuge, USA) for 15 min. The supernatant was removed and residue containing saponified tomato pomace was dehydrolyzed using absolute ethanol ( Inakuma, 1998 ) for supercritical extraction. 2.4 Supercritical fluid extractions A batch of 100 g of saponified tomato pomace powder was taken in a 1 l stainless steel tubular extractor. Ethanol (16%) was continuously added into an on-line cartridge and it was carried into the extractor by the SC-CO 2 . The procedure used was as follows. Liquid CO 2 from a siphon tube type cylinder was passed through a cooling bath and then compressed to the desired working pressure by a syringe pump, and subsequently heated up to the supercritical condition by a coil type heat exchanger. The supercritical CO 2 with ethanol flowed into the extractor, and contacted with the saponified powder to extract lycopene into the CO 2 phase. The extract laden CO 2 gas was led into the first separator accompanied by a pressure decreases to 7 MPa and 50 °C. Then, the extract was further depressurised in a second separator to 6 MPa and 30 °C. Finally, the expanded low-pressure CO 2 gas was released into ambient conditions. The extract collected in the second separator was ready for HPLC analysis of lycopene. 2.5 Lycopene determination Lycopene was analyzed in the reverse phase using HPLC (HP1100, fitted with a diode array detector detecting at 472 nm, Model G1306 A, Agilent Technologies, USA). Firstly, 20 μl sample was filtered (0.2 μm), and injected into a SUPELCOSIL LC-18 reverse phase column (15 cm × 4.6 mm, 5 μm). The mobile phase composition optimized for best composition was found to be acetonitrile: methanol (85:15, v/v). The flow rate was set to 1.0 ml/min. Lycopene was quantified using a calibration curve. 2.6 Analysis of antioxidant activity Scavenging hydroxyl radical was employed as index to estimate antioxidant activity of extract. In aqueous media OH is generated through the Fenton reaction. The reaction mixture included 20 μl FeCl 2 (1 × 10 −3 M), 30 μl, 1,10-phenanthroline (1 × 10 −3 M), 800 μl balanced salt solution (BSS) consisting of 3.1 mM KCl, 134 mM NaCl, 1.2 mM CaCl 2 , 1.2 mM MgSO 4 , 0.25 mM KH 2 PO 4 and 15.7 mM NaHCO 3 (pH 7.38), and 50 μl H 2 O 2 (0.6%). Absorbance was measured at a wavelength of 510 nm using distilled water as a reference ( Xiaoyan et al., 2006 ). For comparing the antioxidant activity in various extracts, the concentration of extract producing 50% reduction in the radical absorbance (IC 50 ) was used as an index. The value of IC 50 was determined from the plot of percent inhibition versus the corresponding concentration of lycopene, in which the values of percent inhibition were calculated using the following equation: Percent inhibition ( % ) = ( 1 - A 1 / A 0 ) × 100 where A 1 and A 0 are absorbance of test sample and the reference, respectively. The data are presented as mean of triplicates, as the concentration of extract required for a 50% reduction (IC 50 ) of radical absorbance. 2.7 Experimental design For supercritical liquid extraction, the parameters influencing the amount of lycopene extracted are temperature, pressure, co-solvent additional ratio, flow rate and extraction time. However, in the present work, the co-solvent ratio was kept constant at 16% and the flow rate of carbon dioxide was kept constant at 0.7 l/min, which were shown to be most suitable in preliminary experiments. Therefore, this experiment involved 3 factors, extraction pressure, temperature and time. In the research, a 2 3 full factorial central composite design was employed to fit a second order polynomial model which indicated a requirement of 17 experiments for analysis ( Kui, 2005 ). The general equation of the second degree polynomial is stated as follows: (1) y = β 0 + ∑ i = 1 3 β i x i + ∑ i = 1 3 ∑ j ⩾ i 3 β ij x i x j + ε where y is the predicted response; x i , x j are input variables which influence the response variable y ; β 0 is a constant; β i is the i th linear coefficient; β ii is the quadratic coefficient and β ij ( i ≠ j ) is the linear-by-linear interaction between x i and x j . The test variables were transformed to range between −1 and 1 for the appraisals of factors. The variables were coded according to the following equation: (2) x i ′ = x i - x cp Δ x i , i = 1 , 2 , 3 where x i ′ is the coded value of the independent variable; x i is its real value; x cp is the its real value at the centre point; and Δ x i is the step change in the variable ‘ i ’. The actual and coded levels of the independent variables used in the experimental design are shown in Table 1 . ‘STATISTICA’ software (version 8.0, StatSoft Inc., Tulsa, USA) was used for response surface regression of the data obtained. The statistical analysis of the model was performed in the form of analysis of variance (ANOVA).This analysis includes the Fisher’s test (over-all model significance), its associated probability P ( F ), correlation coefficient R , and determination coefficient R 2 which measures the goodness of fit of regression model. It also includes the t -value for the estimated coefficients and associated probabilities. 3 Results and discussion As mentioned earlier, a 2 3 full factorial central composite design was used to evaluate, both, the main and the interaction effects of the operating parameters. All experimental data obtained are shown in Table 2 . The effects of the experimental parameters were evaluated by statistical analysis of the experimental data shown in Table 2 . The enter method was used to calculate the estimated coefficients of the polynomial functions of response surfaces for both lycopene yield and extract antioxidant activity. The analysis of variance (ANOVA) is presented in Table 3 for lycopene yield and the extract antioxidant activity in term of 1/IC 50 . The analysis showed that both models were statistically significant at 95% confidence. For supercritical fluid extraction, the solubility of organic compounds depends largely on the balance between fluid density and solute vapor pressure, which are both controlled by fluid temperature and pressure. When the pressure increases, the fluid density increases, thus the solubility increases. On the other hand, when the temperature increases, the fluid density decreases, however the solute vapor pressure increases. In other words, the solubility may increase, remain constant, or decrease with increase in the temperature at constant pressure, depending on whether the solute vapor pressure or the solvent density is the predominant factor. Fluid pressure in Tables 4 and 5 was found to play an important role in both lycopene yield and the extract antioxidant activity (IC 50 ). The results showed that the individual effects of pressure and temperature, and the interactive effects of pressure with temperature and time were significant in the case of lycopene yield. As a result, the extraction yields increased when the operating pressure increased. In the case of extract antioxidant activity, the individual effects of pressure and time, and the interactive effect between pressure and time were significant. Fig. 1 shows three-dimensional plot of the response surface for lycopene yield for which the polynomial function is (3) Lycopene yield ( mg ) = 24.05 - 1.50 [ P ] - 1.33 [ P ] 2 - 2.64 [ T ] 2 + 2.67 [ t ] - 2.46 [ P ] [ T ] + 1.62 [ T ] [ t ] Fig. 2 shows that the polynomial regression model was in good agreement with the experimental results, with R 2 of 0.97. From the model, the optimum condition for lycopene yield was at 57 °C, 40 MPa, and 1.8 h, and the lycopene yield was 28.64 mg in 100 g dried tomato pomace, approximately 93.81% of the total amount of lycopene determined from the soxhlet extraction, which was 30.53 mg. In case of lycopene from tomato pomace by supercritical CO 2 without any modifiers reported by Topal et al., the results showed that with optimized operating conditions, the maximum yield of lycopene (1.18 mg of lycopene/g of sample) was obtained at 100 °C and 40 MPa. However, the higher yield of lycopene from tomato wastes at higher temperatures without considering the bioactivity of extract has limited industrial application, because the bioactivity could well be compromised ( Ollanketo et al., 2001 ). It has been proved that organic solvents are used to improve the solubility of the bioactive components and ethanol seems to be favored because of its non-toxic effect, which is ideal for food products ( Lamin et al., 2007 ). Fig. 3 shows three-dimensional plot of the response surface for the extract antioxidant activity (1/IC 50 ), for which the polynomial function is (4) 1 / IC 50 ( ml/mg) = 11.26 + 0.72 [ P ] - 0.33 [ P ] 2 + 0.98 [ t ] - 0.26 [ t ] 2 - 0.34 [ P ] [ t ] As shown in Fig. 4 the coefficient of determination for this model regression indicated reasonable agreement between model and experimental results. The experimental results obtained from the approximate model suggest that the optimal conditions under which the highest antioxidant activity was achieved are: 57 °C, 53 MPa, and 1.8 h extraction time, which results in an IC 50 value of 0.081 mg/ml. The result suggests that the methodology used in this research is able to identify operating conditions which selectively extract lycopene compounds with higher bioactivity. 4 Conclusions The experimental design and approach enabled to establish the polynomial functions that describe the effects of operating temperature, operating pressure and extraction time on the lycopene yield from tomato pomace using ethanol-modified supercritical CO 2 as the extraction medium. In this study, the significant variables influencing lycopene yields were pressure and temperature, and the interaction between pressure, temperature and extraction time. A polynomial regression model was proposed which described the experimental results satisfactorily; and based on the proposed model, the optimum conditions for lycopene yield were found to be at 57 °C, 40 MPa, and 1.8 h. Under these conditions, the estimated lycopene yield was 28.64 mg from 100 g dried tomato pomace (giving a recovery of 93%). For the extract antioxidant activity, the analysis showed that the individual effects of pressure and extraction time, and the interaction between pressure and time were significant. The optimum conditions for antioxidant activity were found to be: 57 °C, 53 MPa, and 1.8 h. Under these conditions, the IC 50 value was 0.081 mg/ml. The research demonstrates that ethanol-modified supercritical CO 2 extraction results in high yields of lycopene with a high level of bioactivity, and it is a promising alternative to the use of traditional organic solvent extraction. i3vmnfaD.title: THE STUDY OF IPv6 ROUTE SPOOFING BASED ON ICMPv6
i3vmnfaD.abstract: The theory of network protocol spoofing in IPv6 is introduced,and the ICMPv6 protocol and its leak are analyzed in details.The elements and methods of route spoofing based on ICMPv6 protocol are discussed.The implementation methods of ICMPv6 redirect error spoofing and ICMPv6 route message spoofing are presented.
keywords: Protocol spoofing Route spoofing IPv6 ICMPv6 Libpcap Libnet

DlL7AneL.title: Antimicrobial activities of new food preservative celllibiosyl methyl fumarate
DlL7AneL.abstract: A new type of preservatives which contain α,β-unsaturated carbonyl group,the cellibiosyl methyl fumarate(CMF) was synthesized and its antimicrobial activity was studied.The results showed that CMF could inhibit bacteria and yeast.It could effectively inhibit bacteria of Escherichia coli,Bacillus subtilis,Staph-ylococcus aureus,Paecilomyces variotii,Saccharomyces cerevlsiae and mixing microbic bacterias.The minimum inhibition concentration(MIC) of this inhibitor on several bacterials and yeasts was 0.05%,0.05%,0.04%,0.05%,0.04% and 0.06%,respectively.The antimicrobial rate on Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus was exceed 80% of blank after 70 h when 0.04% CMF was added.The antimicrobial rate on Saccharomyces cerevlsiae was 90%.

p7ml45eZ.title: Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification(LAMP) for Detection of Human Astrovirus and Its Application in Reclaimed Water
p7ml45eZ.abstract: A loop-mediated isothermal amplification(LAMP) technology was developed for rapidly detecting human astrovirus.The data showed that the optimal amplification condition was at 65℃ for 90 min with 4 mmol·L-1 magnesium ions and 1 mol·L-1 betaine.The specificity of RT-LAMP assay was further validated by restriction analgsis of the amplified products and we got two bands(84bp and 135bp) as expected.There is also no cross-reaction with different virus(human rotavirus and norovirus) and restriction analysis of the amplified products.The sensitivity of the LAMP and PCR were 5.04 copies·μL-1 and 5.04×10 copies·μL-1,respectively.Improved RT-LAMP and RT-PCR were both used for detection of human astrovirus in 12 reclaimed water samples.The detection rates of human astrovirus were 41.7%(5/12) and 33.3%(4/12),respectively.All these results suggested that LAMP was a simple,high sensitivity and specificity method which was potential for rapid detection of human astrovirus.

j1Ng7Zrl.title: Metabolic kinetics of tert-butylhydroquinone and its metabolites in rat serum after oral administration by LC/ITMS.
j1Ng7Zrl.abstract: Liquid chromatography-ion trap mass spectrometry (LC/ITMS) was employed for a metabolic kinetics study of tert-butylhydroquinone (TBHQ) and its metabolites in rat serum after oral administration. The mean serum concentration-time data of TBHQ and its four metabolites (M1-M4) in both male and female rats after oral administration of TBHQ at dosages of 7, 350 and 700 mg/kg were all best-fitted by a two-compartment model with first-order absorption. TBHQ was rapidly absorbed, distributed and metabolized. The metabolites were also distributed rapidly except M2, but eliminated more slowly than TBHQ. At the doses of 350 and 700 mg/kg, the total concentrations of TBHQ and its metabolites in serum were much higher for male than female rats during the metabolic process (P < 0.01). In addition, the serum concentrations of M1, M3 and M4 were all much higher for males than for females (P < 0.01) during the metabolic process, while no significant differences between male and female rats were found (P > 0.05) for TBHQ and M2, at the doses of 350 and 700 mg/kg. The exploratory assessment of dose proportionality for TBHQ and its metabolites by the power model indicated that the TBHQ exposure increased in a more-than-dose-proportional manner, but the exposures of the metabolites M1-M4 increased in a less-than-dose-proportional manner, across the dose of 7-700 mg/kg.

MkWGvVCl.title: Optimization on Cellulase and Ultrasonic Wave Assisted Extraction  Technology of Momordica charantia Polysaccharides
MkWGvVCl.abstract: To establish the extraction technology of cellulase assisted by ultrasonic wave of Momordica charantia polysaccharides(MCP),the optimization was applied to discuss some factors including ultrasound power,enzyme amount,the ratio of solid to liquid,extracting time,pH value,temperature with Box-Behnken center-united design and the method of response surface analysis(RSM).Through establishing the second regression model,the optimal parameters were conformed as follows: ultrasound power 390 W,cellulase amount 3 500 U/g(enzyme activity was more than 200 U/mg),ratio of solid to liquid 1∶38,extracting time 40 min,pH value 5,temperature 56℃.Then the yield of crude Momordica charantia polysaccharides is 21.1%,higher 7.8%,13.5% and 7.7%,respectively,comparing with the specific heat of flooding,ultrasonic wave and cellulase.These results suggested that cellulase assisted by ultrasonic wave extraction technology was one of the effective ways to improve the yield of Momordica charantia polysaccharides.

Rl3PUnTi.title: One-step synthesis of substituted dihydro- and tetrahydroisoquinolines by FeCl3.6H2O catalyzed intramolecular Friedel-Crafts reaction of benzylamino-substituted propargylic alcohols.
Rl3PUnTi.abstract: A mild, versatile, and efficient method for the one-step synthesis of substituted dihydro- and tetrahydroisoquinolines has been developed by the FeCl3.6H2O catalyzed intramolecular allenylation/cyclization reaction of benzylamino-substituted propargylic alcohols, representing the first example of the intramolecular Friedel-Crafts reaction of propargylic alcohols.

5eDpPWoJ.title: Effects of the Musca domestica L.larvae extract on scavenging oxygen free radicals.
5eDpPWoJ.abstract: Effects of the housefly(Musca domestica L.) larvae extract(HLE) on oxygen free radical scavenging were studied.The deoxyribose iron system and pyrogallol autoxidation system were used to determine the scavenging effects of HLE at different concentrations on ·OH and O~--2.The antioxidant value(AOV) of HLE was determined by H-2O-2 oxidiative system.The results showed that the IC-(50) of·OH and O~--2.of HLE was 1.93 mg/mL and 3.26 mg/mL respectively;the AOV of 0.5% HLE was 9.01 mg/g,which was 1.29 times as high as that of the same concentration of vitamin C.

4oUxqP4W.title: The expression of endogenous H_2S in the kidney of diabetic nephropathic rats
4oUxqP4W.abstract: Objective The aim of the study was to explore the role and expression of H_2S in the kidney of diabetic nephropathic rats.Methods Glomerular pathology,H_2S generating enzyme activity in kidney,and relative amount of cystathionine -γ-lyase(CSE) mRNA and cystathionine-β-svnthase(CBS) mRNA,the mRNAs of the two endogenous H_2S synthesis enzymes,in kidney were compared among diabetic nephropathic group(DN group),DN+ NaHS group(H_2S group) and control group.Results H_2S generating enzyme activity and the relative amount of CSE mRNA were significantly decreased in kidney in DN group(P<0.01),but CBS mRNA was similar in the 3 groups(P>0.05).Glomerular pathology was less severe in H_2S group than in DN group.Conclusion The decrease of endogenous H_2S in DN group may result from the lower expression of CSE in the kidney.Exogenous H_2S treatment may delay the progression of diabetic nephropathy.

9v2FzT2d.title: Antioxidant Effect of Carboxymethyl-pachyman
9v2FzT2d.abstract: To investigate the antioxidant activity of carboxymethyl-pachyman in vitro and in vivo.The antioxidant activity of carboxymethyl-pachyman in vitro was evaluated by determining its reducing power and scavenging capacities against hydroxyl,superoxide anion and H2O2.The content of MDA and the activity of SOD in blood serum and liver of mouse were assayed to evaluate the antioxidant activity of carboxymethyl-pachyman in vivo.The carboxymethyl-pachyman could inhibit the production of MDA and increase the activity of SOD in blood serum and liver of mouse.The carboxymethyl-pachyman revealed reducing power,and effectively eliminated hydroxyl,superoxide anion and H2O2.The carboxymethyl-pachyman has obvious antioxidant effect.

fVEOnCzA.title: Optimization of Two-phase Solvent System Extraction Processing for Isoflavone from Flos puerariae by Response Surface Methodology
fVEOnCzA.abstract: Flos puerariae was used as raw material to extract isoflavone using n-buatnol/water two-phase system as solvents. Based on single factor experiments, the optimal extraction processing was explored by central design composite experiments combined with response surface methodology. Results showed that the optimal extraction processing parameters were extraction time of 1.3 h, extraction temperature of 70 ℃, n-buatnol-water ratio of 1:1 (V/V) and material-liquid ratio of 1:55 (g/mL). Under these optimal conditions, the extraction rate of isoflavone was 96.24%, which was very close to predicted value. Therefore, it is feasible to optimize the extraction processing of isoflavone from Flos puerariae by response surface methodology.

McRN8Nd2.title: Simvastatin protects against amyloid beta and HIV-1 Tat-induced promoter activities of inflammatory genes in brain endothelial cells.
McRN8Nd2.abstract: Increased deposition of amyloid beta (Abeta) is characteristic for normal aging and human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1)-associated alterations of the central nervous system. In addition, both Abeta and HIV-1 are known to induce cellular oxidative stress and disruption of the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Therefore, we hypothesize that Abeta and HIV-1 protein Tat can potentiate their proinflammatory effects at the brain endothelium level. To address this hypothesis, we studied promoter activity of three proinflammatory genes in an in vitro BBB model of human brain microvascular endothelial cells (HBMEC) cocultured with a human astrocyte cell line producing Tat (SVGA-Tat cells) and exposed to Abeta. Treatment of HBMEC with Abeta(1-40) in the presence of SVGA-Tat cells resulted in a significant up-regulation of E-selectin, CC chemokine ligand-2, and interleukin-6 promoter activities and protein levels compared with the individual effects of Abeta or Tat. In addition, Abeta markedly amplified E-selectin promoter activity in HBMEC cocultured with HIV-1-infected Jurkat T cells. Simvastatin, the 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl coenzyme A reductase inhibitor, effectively blocked proinflammatory reactions induced by Abeta in cocultures with SVGA-Tat cells or with HIV-1-infected Jurkat cells. The present study indicates that a combined exposure to Abeta and Tat or HIV-1 can synergistically potentiate the expression of inflammatory genes in brain endothelial cells. In addition, simvastatin may provide a beneficial influence by reducing these effects at the BBB level.

t9k2GkN6.title: Ln[N(SiMe3)2]3/RNH2 catalyzed monoaddition of terminal alkynes to nitriles: A novel and concise access to the synthesis of ynones
t9k2GkN6.abstract: A mild and highly selective Ln[N(SiMe3)2] 3/n-BuNH2 catalyzed addition of terminal alkynes to nitriles has been established, revealing a novel reactivity pattern of alkynes with nitriles and providing a new, economical, and mild method for the synthesis of conjugated ynones. © 2008 American Chemical Society.

8S8MFxXk.title: Prevention and rapid recovery of fatigue of officers and soldiers from plateau with amino acids and vitamins
8S8MFxXk.abstract: Objective The present paper is a report of investigation of prevention and rapid recovery of fatigue rate of officers and soldiers on a plateau caused by military operations with the aid of amino acids and vitamins.Methods The participants were 100 officers and soldiers,whose Modified Fatigue Rating Scale(MFIS) scores were >21 points.The participants were randomly divided into three groups: capsule,placebo,and granules.Amino acids capsule,placebo,or amino acid-fructose beverage was given to respective group for 14 days continuously.The scores of a 3000 m race of the officers and soldiers stationed on a plateau was measured on the first and 14th days.The maximal grip strength of the right hand,fist-making times per minute,and the height reaching by the hand after three steps for the same candidate were observed before and after fatigue loading(3000 m race).The blood levels of lactic acid and urea nitrogen of the candidates were measured after fatigue loading on the first and the 14th days.Results The 3000 m race results of officers and soldiers in the capsule and granules groups on the 14th day were better than that of the first day(P<0.05),whereas no significant difference was noted in the placebo group(P>0.05).The difference between the capsule and the granules groups in grip strength,fist-making times per minute,and hand reaching height on the 14th day were obviously lower than that on the first day(P<0.05),whereas no significant difference was observed in the placebo group(P>0.05).The blood levels of lactic acid and urea nitrogen in the capsule and granules groups on the 14th day were lower than that on the first day(P<0.05),while there was no significant difference in the placebo group(P>0.05).Conclusions Amino acids and vitamin preparations can obviously improve the military performance capacity of officers and soldiers stationed on the plateau.Similarly,they can effectively prevent the lowering of jumping ability and grip strength caused by military fatigue.Therefore,amino acids and vitamin preparations play an important role in the prevention and rapid recovery of fatigue in servicemen stationed on plateau.

za7h7BCz.title: Genome-Wide Association Study of Circadian Behavior in <Emphasis Type="Italic">Drosophila melanogaster</Emphasis>
za7h7BCz.abstract: Circadian rhythms influence physiological processes from sleep–wake cycles to body temperature and are controlled by highly conserved cycling molecules. Although the mechanistic basis of the circadian clock has been known for decades, the extent to which circadian rhythms vary in nature and the underlying genetic basis for that variation is not well understood. We measured circadian period (Ʈ) and rhythmicity index in the Drosophila Genetic Reference Panel (DGRP) and observed extensive genetic variation in both. Seven DGRP lines had sexually dimorphic arrhythmicity and one line had an exceptionally long Ʈ. Genome-wide analyses identified 584 polymorphisms in 268 genes. We observed differences among transcripts for nine genes predicted to interact among themselves and canonical clock genes in the long period line and a control. Mutations/RNAi knockdown targeting these genes also affected circadian behavior. Our observations reveal that complex genetic interactions influence high levels of variation in circadian phenotypes.

ndYkomv8.title: A new technique for testing dynamic tensile behavior of metals at elevated temperatures
ndYkomv8.abstract: A high-temperature tensile impact experimental technique, based on a rapid-contact heating method, is developed to test specimen at temperatures up to 1073K. High-strain-rate tensile responses of commercially pure titanium at elevated temperature are investigated. The testing results show that the yield stress and ultimate tensile stress all decrease with increasing temperature, while the fracture strain decreases with increasing temperature at the temperature range 25°C<t<350°C, and increases with increasing temperature t>350°C. Copyright © 2005 SAE International.

8efSZWLv.title: A novel empirical model for SiC MESFETs with self-heating effect
8efSZWLv.abstract: In this paper, a novel empirical model based on Angelov model for SiC MESFETs with self-heating effect is presented. Modifications of drain current and nonlinear capacitive model are proposed to adapt to the measured date without the thermal subcircuit. These new models could simplify the equivalent circuit topology and are easier to implement in CAD simulation tools. A good agreement has been obtained between simulated and measured results. © 2010 IEEE.

m7Rc1aGF.title: Impact of Different Dialysis Modalities on Nutrition Status of Maintenance Hemodilysis Patients
m7Rc1aGF.abstract: Objective To investigate the impact of different dialysis modalities on the nutrition status of maintenance hemodilysis patients.Methods Twenty-eight hemodilysis patients were randomly divided into three groups and received hemodialysis(the HD group,10 cases),hemodiafiltration and hemodialysis(the HD+HDF group,8 cases),and hemoperfusion and hemodialysis(the HD+HP group,10 cases) respectively for one year.Malnutrition inflammation score(MIS),albumin(ALB),total protein(TP),iron-binding capacity(IBC),serum creatinine(SCr),blood urea nitrogen(BUN),total cholesterol(TC),Hb,lymphocyte counts(LC),and Kt/V before and after treatment among the three groups were compared.Results MIS before treatment displayed no significant differences among the three groups(P=0.821);after one year of treatment,MIS of the HD+HDF group and the HD+HP group were remarkably lower than that of the HD group(P<0.01) while no significant difference was noted between the HD+HDF group and the HD+HP group(P>0.05).Before treatment,ALB,TP,Kt/V,LC,TC,Hb among the three groups were not significantly different(P>0.05);after one year of treatment,ALB,TP,Hb,LC notably increased in the HD+HDF group and the HD+HP group in comparison with the HD group(P<0.01),while differences in Kt/V and TC among the three groups were not statistically significant(P>0.05).Conclusion Hemodiafiltration or hemoperfusion associated with hemodilysis is considered as satisfiable method of choice for maintenance hemodilysis.

pufofET5.title: Changes of Plasma Soluble CD40L in Uremic Patients undergoing Maintenance Hemodialysis and Its Clinical Significance
pufofET5.abstract: Objective To investigate the changes of plasma soluble CD40ligand(sCD40L) and it′s relationship to vascular pseudo-von Willebrand factors(vWF) and tissue factors(TF),to probe further into the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis in uremic patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis(MHD).Methods Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay was used to measure the plasma sCD40L,vWF and TF in maintenance hemodialysis patients(MHD group,n=48) and healthy volunteers(control group,n=22).Results(1)The levels of sCD40L,vWF and TF were significantly higher in MHD group than those in control(P< 0.01).The levels of sCD40L,vWF and TF were significantly higher in MHD patients with coronary heart disease(CHD) than those without CHD(P< 0.05);(2) Linear correlation analysis showed that sCD40L level was positively related to vWF(P<0.01),and TF(P<0.01);(3) Logistic regression analysis showed that sCD40L,vWF and TF were related to the occurrence of CHD(P<0.05).Conclusion The elevated levels of sCD40L,vWF and TF in MHD patients,particularly in those with CHD,may partake in the formation of atherosclerosis,and the positive correlation of sCD40L with vWF and TF may indicate the possible mechanism in which sCD40L facilitates CHD occurrence by up-regulating vWF and TF expression.

zxPshkE9.title: Separation of hyaluronic acid from fermentation broth by tangential flow microfiltration and ultrafiltration
zxPshkE9.abstract: This work examined the use of a two-stage tangential flow filtration process for the separation of hyaluronic acid from fermentation broth. Microfiltration (MF) membranes (0.45, 0.20 μm in pore diameter) and ultrafiltration (UF) membranes (MWCO 300, 100 kDa), made from polyvinylidene fluoride, were used to achieve the separation in series. Operating conditions of each stage were firstly optimized to give the best separation. Then, the two-stage membrane process was undertaken with two separating schemes: the first using MF followed by UF with pure water as diafiltrate, the second similar to the first except permeate from previous UF stage as diafiltrate for MF stage. The optimal conditions were transmembrane pressure 0.1 MPa, crossflow velocity 1.25 m/s, solution pH 4.0 and enhanced ionic strength 0.25 mol/l NaCl for MF membranes, and 0.15 MPa, 1.25 m/s, pH 7.0 and 0.1–0.25 mol/l NaCl for UF membranes, respectively. The two schemes could effectively separate and purify HA with above 77% overall yield and about 1000 purification factor. The second scheme seemed to be more effective for its higher overall yield (89%) and saving water. Keywords Microfiltration Ultrafiltration Tangential flow filtration Hyaluronic acid Fermentation broth 1 Introduction The downstream processing of cell cultures and the separation of extracellular biometabolites produced represents one of the main tasks of bioengineering. Tangential flow or crossflow filtration technique (TFF) has been demonstrated its feasibility of separating or removing cell debris (e.g. fungi [1] , rod-shaped bacteria [2,3] ), and recovering biosynthetic substances (e.g. xanthan gum [4] , antibiotics [5–8] ) after bacterial fermentation. In TFF, the bulk flows tangentially across the membrane and perpendicularly to the permeation flux. Its filtrating performance depends on the properties of the membrane, product and the operational conditions (transmembrane pressure, crossflow velocity, solution chemistry, concentration factor, running time, etc.). Besides, TFF is usually considered to work effectively on the condition that the solutes differ by 10-fold in size. van Reis et al. [9] firstly created the conception high performance tangential flow filtration (HPTFF) to describe high resolution membrane processes which could achieve the separation of solutes that differ by less than 10-fold in size. Different strategies were taken by HPTFF, such as proper choice of pH and ionic strength (IS), use of electrically charged membranes and a diafiltration mode, operation in optimal hydrodynamic conditions to maximize the selectivity and control of membrane fouling [10] . van Reis et al. [9] used HPTFF to separate immunoglobulin G (IgG) from bovine serum albumin (BSA), obtaining 84% yield and 30-fold purification factor. Cheang and Zydney [10] described a two-stage ultrafiltration process for the purification of α-lactalbumin (α-LA) and β-lactoglobulin (β-LG) from whey protein isolate in two separating strategies, with more than 10-fold purification factor and above 85% yield of α-LA and more than four-fold purification factor and about 70% yield of β-LG. Therefore, HPTFF may improve the separation of solutes whether the differences of their molecular sizes are less than 10-fold or not. As one of natural polyelectrolytes, hyaluronic acid (HA) is a member of glycosaminoglycans and is constituted by alternating and repeating units of d -glucuronic acid and N -acetyl- d -glucosamine linked at 1, 3 and 1, 4 position to form a linear chain [11] . The distributions of the molecular size are of wide range (10 5 to 10 7 Da). HA is highly hydrophilic, and in aqueous solutions shows high viscoelastic behavior and water binding capacity due to the high molecular weight and the high number of charged groups. Physicochemical studies have demonstrated that HA molecules in solution, at a concentration as low as 1 g/l, form a three-dimensional network stabilized by interchain interactions [12] . The application of HA will be easily found in cosmetics such as skin creams, cleansers, and facial aesthetics [13] . Recent biomedical applications of HA include ophthalmic surgery, arthritis treatment, wound healing, embryonic development, tissue regeneration, tumorigenesis, etc. [11,14] . HA is usually prepared by fermentation with microorganisms belonging to Streptococcus zooepidemicus [15–18] . The separation and purification of HA involves the precipitation of HA from fermentation broth by repeatedly using large amounts of organic solvents such as ethanol, acetone, isopropanol, CPC, etc. [19,20] . However, the process is complicated and time-consuming, which leads to high cost. Moreover, the use of organic solvents or other added substances will potentially contaminate environment and do harm to the qualities of HA. Although membrane technology was used in some purifying processes [21,22] , it was just to concentrate HA solution or to remove small soluble molecules. Therefore, further processes were needed. So far, membrane processes as key technologies to separate and purify HA from fermentation broth has been rarely reported, especially the operating parameters of the processes. In the present study, the separation of HA from fermentation broth will be carried out by a two-stage tangential flow microfiltration (MF) and ultrafiltration (UF) process based on the conception of HPTFF. The process will also be evaluated according to the yield and purification factor of HA, process time and pure water diafiltrate needed. Operating conditions for each stage are firstly optimized to give the best separation in a total recirculation mode. Then, two separating schemes consisting of two diafiltration steps will be tested to separate HA from fermentation broth, and also compared and evaluated. 2 Theory Conventionally, the separation efficiency has been studied by calculating the ratio of permeation factors, which is termed as selectivity and is defined as (1) S i / j = P i P j (2) P = C p C R where S is the selectivity, P the permeation factor of solute i (or j ) in the feed (retentate), C R and C p are the concentration of solute in the feed and the permeate, respectively. Membrane system used in the experimental tests can be modeled as a CSTR [23] . In the continuous diafiltration, the mass balance for a solute in the feed gives the following equations. In the case of pure water as diafiltrate to hold the volume of feed unchangeable, the solute concentration in the feed: (3) C R = C 0 e − P V D and in the permeate: (4) C P = P C 0 e − P V D where C 0 is the initial solute concentration in the solution to be treated, V D is the number of diavolume. As far as washing with a solution containing the solute at concentration C add is concerned, the equations for C R and C p are given as follows [23] : (5) C R = 1 P [ C add − ( C add − C 0 P ) e − P V D ] (6) C P = C add − ( C add − C 0 P ) e − P V D The primary goals of multiple-solute separations are to achieve a desired yield of the solute as well as an acceptable level of purification from one or several impurities. The yield of desired solute is simply equal to the ratio of the mass of recovered solute to the initial mass in the solution to be treated. If the desired solute is in the permeate for MF stage (represented by subscript “1”), then the yield of the solute is defined as follows. In the case of washing with pure water, the yield [24] is (7) Y 1 = 1 − e ( − P 1 V D .1 ) As for washing with a solution containing the solute at concentration C add , the yield can be expressed, using Eq. (5) and the overall mass balance of the solute for the diafiltration process: (8) V 0.1 C 0.1 + V D .1 V 0.1 C add = V 0.1 C R .1 + V p .1 C ¯ p .1 where V 0 is the initial volume of the solution to be treated, V p the cumulative volume of the permeate at the end of diafiltration, and C ¯ p is the average concentration of the solute in the cumulative permeate at the end of diafiltration. The yield is: (9) Y 1 = 1 − e − P 1 V D .1 + C add C 0.1 V D .1 − 1 P 1 ( 1 − e − P 1 V D .1 ) In UF stage (represented by subscript “2”), the desired solute is in the feed, and only washing with pure water is taken into consideration. Therefore, the yield at the stage can be defined as [24] : (10) Y 2 = e ( − P 2 V D .2 ) The overall yield of the desired solute for the two-stage MF and UF membrane process in this work can be defined as (11) Y = Y 1 Y 2 Substituting Eq. (7) or Eq. (9) , and Eq. (10) in Eq. (11) gives: (12) Y = [ 1 − e ( − P 1 V D .1 ) ] e ( − P 2 V D .2 ) (13) Y = 1 − e − P 1 V D .1 + C add C 0.1 V D .1 − 1 P 1 ( 1 − e − P 1 V D .1 ) e ( − P 2 V D .2 ) One point to note is that a small loss of the solute in the pre-concentration (if needed) is not taken into account for the calculation of Y while the loss does exist in the process. The overall purification factor for the two-stage membrane processes is termed as the ratio of the mass of recovered solute in the final product solution to the initial mass in the solution to be treated divided by the sum of the same ratio of all impurities: (14) β i = V f C ¯ f . i V 0 C 0. i ∑ j ≠ i V f C ¯ f . j V 0 C 0. j = Y i ∑ j ≠ i Y j where β is the purification factor, V f the volume of the final product solution, and C ¯ f is the average concentration of the solute in the final product solution. Eq. (14) accounts for the presence of all the possible impurities in the final product solution. Thus, cell bodies and proteins are considered as impurities for the calculation of HA purification factor. In addition, Eq. (14) can be used to calculate the purification factor of the desired solute in every stage with the solute yield in the stage. 3 Materials and methods 3.1 Fermentation The microorganism used for the production of HA was a strain of S. zooepidemicus (supplied by China agricultural science research center) numbered 05-02-552 in our laboratory. Fermentation medium comprised (g/l deionized water unless otherwise stated): glucose 60.0, yeast extract 12.0, peptone 15.0, NaCl 2.0, MgSO 4 ·7H 2 O 1.0, K 2 HPO 4 1.5. All medium solutes were analytical grade and dissolved in deionized water. Glucose, yeast extract, peptone and salt solutions were autoclaved separately. The microorganisms were cultured for about 18 h in two 250-ml conical flasks (100 ml culture volume) to develop the inocula before fermentation. The makeup of the culture in the flasks was same to the fermentation medium expect that glucose was 2 g/l. Then, the inocula were added to the fermentation medium at 10% v/v. Fermented broths were produced in a 5-l BioTECH-5BG fermentor (Baoxin Biological Equipment Co. Ltd. Shanghai, China) using a working volume of 2 l. Fermentations were carried out for about 30 h and in the following conditions: pH 7.0–7.2, temperature 37 °C, air supply 2 l/min, agitation 200–300 r/min. All these conditions were under the automatic control. 3.2 Membrane filtration system A flat-plate membrane module with four channels was used in this study. Each channel was 13 cm, 0.8 cm and 2.5 mm of length, width and thickness respectively, 9.5 mm of inner hydraulic diameter and a filtering area of 10.4 cm 2 . Four types of Polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) MF and UF membranes available commercially were used: membranes with 0.45 and 0.20 μm in pore size(supplied by Beihua Liming Co. Ltd., China), and PVDF300 (MWCO 300 kDa) and PVDF100 (MWCO 100 kDa), supplied by Synder Filtration, USA. A new membrane was used to obtain reproducible result in each experiment. Fig. 1 shows the schematic diagram of the membrane filtration system. A magnetic gear pump (MG 213, Italy) was used to pump the broth from the 1.5-l feed tank to circulate (crossflow filtration) along the surface of the flat-plate membranes in the module. The applied pressure was controlled by ball valves 1, 3, and monitored with pressure gauges 4 and 5. Crossflow velocity was calculated from circulating retentate flow rate measurement with a rotor flowmeter 6. Pressures (inlet and outlet of membrane), retentate flow rate were monitored and adjusted to remain closer to the selected values whenever necessary. In the system, the permeate side of membrane was open to atmosphere, and thus the pressure of permeate side was equal to zero. Therefore, the transmembrane pressure (TMP) was defined as the average of pressures of inlet and outlet. In this study, the temperature was 25 ± 1 °C, and controlled by a heat exchanger 8. Permeate was collected for 30 s at different times and measured by a BS223S electronic balance (Sartorius, Germany; Accuracy 0.001 g) to calculate permeation flux. Samples were periodically taken for analysis. The system was cleaned by recirculating 0.1 mol/l NaOH solution for twice (each for 15 min) after each batch filtration. Then, the system was flushed by deionized water to ensure the system was restored its original performance. 3.3 Analytical methods Hyaluronic acid in the whole broth, the permeate and the feed was determined by the method of Bitter and Muir [25] , using glucuronolactone as a standard. Its contents in solution were calculated from the glucuronolactone value by multiplication by an experimental factor of 2.39 [26] . The sample was first centrifuged at 3000 r/min for 15 min to remove cell bodies (if needed). Two and a half fold volumes of absolute ethanol were added to 1 volume of the sample free of cell bodies and the solution was centrifuged at 3000 r/min for 15 min. The precipitate was recovered, redissolved in deionized water, and analyzed for the HA concentration. The weight-average molecular mass ( M w ) of HA was evaluated by intrinsic viscosity [27] . Mark–Houwink coefficients were k = 0.016 and a = 0.841 [28] . Sample was taken after 4 h recirculation of the broth with a constant crossflow velocity in the membrane filtration system. Absorbance measurement at 280 nm by SPECORD 200 (Analytik Jena AG, Germany) was used to detect protein content in samples. The sample was diluted in deionized water to an absorbance of less than 1 before measurement. The absorbance was then multiplied by the dilution factor. The bacterial concentration was obtained from dry cell weight, which was determined by centrifuging, washing the cells, centrifuging again and drying the cells at 105 °C to a constant weight. Shear stress and apparent viscosity were measured at shear rates 1–2000 s −1 by Rhesstress 300 (Thermo Haake, USA) to study the rheological characteristics of HA fermentation broth. The measurement was done at 25 °C. Although the broth contained other substances with small molecular size, some of them could totally pass through the membranes and the others had a similar permeation to that of proteins. Therefore, they were not taken into consideration in this study. 3.4 Experimental procedure In the first step, the membrane performances of filtrating HA fermentation broth were investigated to determine the optimal operating conditions for the good separation of HA, based on the conception of HPTFF. All the four types of membranes were used. The peristaltic pump 13 in the Fig. 1 was turned off, and the system ran in a total recirculation mode. Both the permeate and retentate were recycled back to the feed tank to maintain HA concentration constant. In the second step, a two-stage membrane process for separation of HA from fermentation broth was carried out with 0.45 μm and PVDF100 membranes in a continuous diafiltration mode, using the optimal conditions. The feed tank was supplied with the 300 ml broth. The system initially ran in a total recirculation mode for about 90 min to be stabilized. Then, the peristaltic pump 13 was turned on, and the diafiltrate was continuously added to the feed tank at a rate equal to the permeate flow rate to keep the solution volume constant. Two separating schemes were tested. The first scheme was MF followed by UF. Pure water was used as diafiltrate in the two stages. The total permeate collected from the MF stage was used as a feed of the second diafiltration after pre-concentration at a certain volume concentration ratio (VCR). The final HA product was recovered from the retentate of UF. The second scheme was similar to the first scheme expect that the collected permeate from previous UF stage was used as the diafiltrate for MF stage. 3.5 Calculation methods of experimental yield The yield of HA during the experiments was calculated using the following equations. In MF stage: (15) Y 1 = V p .1 C ¯ p .1 V 0.1 C 0.1 = V D .1 V 0.1 C ¯ p .1 V 0.1 C 0.1 in UF stage: (16) Y 2 = = V 0.2 C R .2 V 0.2 C 0.2 and for the overall yield of HA: (17) Y = V f C ¯ f V 0 C 0 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Membrane performances of filtrating HA fermentation broth Under certain operating conditions, permeation fluxes of all MF and UF membranes used declined rather quickly during the first minutes, and appeared to reach an apparent steady state after 90 min of operation. Fluxes were considered as stabilized after 120 min in the experiments realized. Thus, all the experimental data reported here were obtained after fluxes were stabilized. 4.1.1 Hydrodynamic conditions In this section, all MF and UF membranes were tested in similar solution chemistry, i.e. pH was equal to 7.0, and no additive was used to regulate IS of the broth. 4.1.1.1 Influences of transmembrane pressure (TMP) on selectivity TMPs adopted in the experiments were in the range of 0.05–0.2 MPa. Cell bodies could be completely retained by all the membranes used. HA permeation factor ( P HA ) for MF membranes was about 60% at TMP 0.05 MPa, and declined gradually with increasing TMP. At TMP 0.2 MPa, it was below 45%. P HA for UF membranes also went down from about 15% to 5% with increasing TMP from 0.05 to 0.15 MPa. But it would go up to about 10% at TMP 0.2 MPa. Proteins permeation factors ( P pro ) for MF and UF membranes were about 80% and 70% at TMP 0.05 MPa, respectively. They went down with increasing TMP. At TMP 0.2 MPa, they reached about 66% and 56%, respectively. The reduction of P HA for MF membranes with increase in TMP was due to the increase in initial permeation fluxes. The larger initial permeation fluxes of MF membranes were, the more molecules with less than the pore sizes (especially proteins) in the broth would get into the insides of MF membrane pores and plug them, which led to actual pore sizes diminished to a lower level. For UF membranes, cell bodies and HA molecules were prone to aggregate on their surfaces and form deposit layer thanks to relatively smaller pore sizes. With increasing TMP, the deposit was compressed so that the less HA molecules could pass through the membrane. On the other hand, HA is a linear chain-like polyelectrolyte stabilized by hydrogen bonds between the glycosidic linked monomers [29] . At TMP 0.2 MPa, the hydrogen bonds may be destroyed, and HA molecule could be shrunk to one with a smaller volume. The diminished volume of HA would explain the increase of P HA at this TMP. The decrease of P pro for all the membranes with increasing TMP might be attributed to the effects of initial permeation fluxes and concentration polarization, and the gathering of retained proteins at the upstream surface of membranes and inside membranes. Fig. 2 shows the variations of selectivities of proteins relative to HA ( S pro/HA ) for all the membranes used with TMP. The selectivity of HA relative to cell bodies ( S HA/cell ) was not depicted since the permeation factor of cell bodies ( P cell ) for all membranes was zero. S pro/HA for all MF membranes was similarly lower in the range of TMPs while S pro/HA for UF membranes was rather higher at TMP 0.15 MPa, manifesting they could give a good separation between HA and proteins in this case. The data of permeation fluxes also showed that permeation fluxes of MF membranes remained unchangeable when TMP was above 0.1 MPa and that the largest fluxes of UF membranes were achieved at TMP 0.15 MPa. Therefore, the optimal TMP for MF and UF membranes were determined to be 0.1 MPa and 0.15 MPa, respectively. 4.1.1.2 Influences of the crossflow velocity The experiments on the rheological properties of the broth showed that it possessed shear-thinning characteristics. Its apparent viscosity decreased with increasing shear rate from 1 to 2000 s −1 . Therefore, permeation fluxes would be raised with increasing shear rate or crossflow velocity [4] . However, HA molecules with linear chains and high molecular weight could be degraded easily under the action of mechanical stress, e.g. higher shear rate. Fig. 3 shows the effects of crossflow velocity ( v ) on the HA weight-average molecular mass ( M w ) which is an important indicator of HA qualities. It declined remarkably when v was above 1.25 m/s. Thus, the crossflow velocity of 1.25 m/s was considered as optimal for the experiments. In Table 1 are listed the data of membrane performances of filtrating HA fermentation broth in the optimal hydrodynamic conditions. MF membranes could give a complete separation between cell bodies and HA as the selectivities of HA relative to cell bodies ( S HA/cell ) were infinite, and UF membranes could provide a good separation between HA and proteins ( S pro/HA = 7.9 or more). Therefore, a two-stage membrane process could be used to separate HA from fermentation broth. Cell bodies could be removed from the broth by MF in the first stage. Then, solutes with small molecular size such as proteins would be got rid of by UF in the following stage. Nevertheless, P HA for MF membranes was only about 50%, and P pro for UF membranes was less than 60%. As a result, the operating time and cost of the process would increase [24] . Therefore, a further study on the influences of solution chemistry on the membrane performances should be carried out to improve the P HA for MF membranes and P pro for UF membranes, respectively. 4.1.2 Influences of solution chemistry The initial pH of the broth was 7.0–7.2, its electric conductivity corresponded to that of about 0.1–0.15 mol/l NaCl solution, and the initial HA concentration was generally 1000 mg/l or more. Thus, the broths containing about 1000 mg/l of HA were used in the following experiments. The pH of the broth was regulated by 6 mol/l HCl and NaOH, and enhanced ionic strength (EIS) by NaCl. Typical experimental data for filtration of the broth under the different conditions of solution chemistry are shown in Table 2 . P cell was not listed in the table and the following sections of this paper as it was zero for all MF and UF membranes. In addition, only the experimental data of 0.45 μm and PVDF100 membranes are given in the table as two MF membranes and two UF membranes exhibited similar separating performances, respectively. P HA increased remarkably to above 77% when solution pH was equal to 4.0 or less with the ionic strength of the broth unchanged. The change was due to the nature of HA molecule at different pH. The carboxyl groups of glucoronic acids in the repeating units of HA molecule would be dissociated in the aqueous solution, conferring a polyanionic character to the molecule. In other words, there was a strong negative charge for every disaccharide unit. The intramolecular and intermolecular electrostatic interactions contributed to the formation of a big molecular volume in the solution. However, the intrinsic viscosity and the molecular radius decreased reversible due to the protonation of glucoronic acid groups at pH less than 5.0 [30] , which might lead to the higher permeation factors. In addition, P pro increased a lot at pH 4.0–5.0 since the pH might be equal or close to the isoelectric points of proteins, and changed the interactions of proteins with membranes and other solutes. The permeation fluxes were lowest in this case, showing severe membrane fouling. Increasing EIS could result in the rises of the permeation fluxes as well as the permeation factors of HA and proteins when EIS was in the range of 0–0.2 mol/l and pH at 7.0. Notwithstanding, they hardly increased, even declined a little at EIS above 0.2 mol/l. EIS can play two major roles. One is to screen the electrostatic interactions, and the other is to diminish the viscosity of the broth, which has a great effect on permeation flux. Under the influence of EIS, the chains of HA molecule were “shrunk” from an expanded to a more compressed shape as a result of suppressing repulsions in the polyelectrolyte chains [31] . The electrostatic repulsions of HA molecules with membranes were also weakened. Therefore, P HA increased. Larger EIS might reverse the nature of charges of HA molecule and membranes, and consequently increased the electrostatic interactions. As a result, the permeation factors might even decrease slightly, instead of increasing. It was also the case with proteins in the broth. The lowest apparent viscosity of the broth was at EIS 0.20 mol/l, and did not decline at EIS 0.25 mol/l, based on the measurements of the viscosities in different EIS. That could be used to explain the increasing permeation fluxes with increasing EIS till to 0.20 mol/l. It is interesting to note that the permeation fluxes and the permeation factors of HA and proteins were greatly enhanced at pH 4.0 and EIS 0.25 mol/l, compared with those at pH 7.0 and EIS 0. The combination of pH and EIS had a great effect on membrane performances. The larger P HA would be preferable although S HA/cell for MF membrane was infinite as P cell was equal to zero. Thus, the solution chemistry at pH 4.0 and EIS 0.20–0.25 mol/l NaCl was chosen for microfiltration of HA fermentation broth to remove cell bodies and allow HA to pass through more easily. As for UF membrane, S pro/HA was affected positively by EIS and negatively by the reduction of solution pH. The membrane provided the highest S pro/HA (about 17.5) at pH 7.0 and EIS 0.25 mol/l, and good selectivity at pH 7.0 and EIS 0.1–0.2 mol/l. Therefore, the solution chemistry at pH 7.0 and EIS 0.10–0.25 mol/l NaCl was chosen for ultrafiltration of HA fermentation broth to let proteins pass through UF membrane quickly and achieve a good separation between proteins and HA. 4.2 Separating HA from fermentation broth with the combination of MF and UF membranes In order to realize high degrees of yield and purification during HA separation, the continuous diafiltration mode was adopted to effectively recover more HA in MF stage and wash out more permeatable proteins through UF membrane. The diafiltrations of HA fermentation broth were conducted on the optimal operating conditions achieved in the above experiments, i.e. TMP 0.1 MPa, v 1.25 m/s, solution pH 4.0 and EIS 0.25 mol/l NaCl for MF stage, and 0.15 MPa, 1.25 m/s, pH 7.0 and 0.20 mol/l NaCl for UF stage, respectively. In the case of pure water as diafiltrate, the buffer solution, prepared from 0.03 mol/l NaH 2 PO 4 and 0.03 mol/l Na 2 HPO 4 , was used. The IS of the solution was close to that of the broth. EIS was regulated to 0.25 mol/l NaCl, and pH to 4.0 and 7.0 for MF and UF stages, respectively. For the calculations using the equations in Section 2 , the following P HA and P pro were adopted according to Table 2 : P HA = 85.0%, P pro = 83% in MF stage, and P HA = 5.0%, P pro = 75.0% in UF stage. 4.2.1 Scheme 1: MF-UF (using pure water as diafiltrate) A series of experiments were firstly carried out to determine an optimal number of diavolume ( V D.1 ) in MF stage. It is shown in Fig. 4 that HA and proteins in the feed are continuously washed out with increasing V D.1 . The contents of HA and proteins declined quickly at the beginning of the diafiltration, to about 50% at V D.1 1.0, and then tended to reduce gradually. HA was recovered in the permeate solution, thus the yield of HA ( Y 1 ) started with zero and increased throughout the first diafiltration. P HA and P pro declined slightly in the course of the diafiltration. The averages of P HA and P pro were about 81% and 79%, respectively. That was caused by intensified membrane fouling due to a long-term diafiltration operation. Therefore, HA and proteins contents in the feed declined less than the values of prediction using Eq. (3) . Accordingly, HA yield in MF stage ( Y 1 ) was slightly lower than the calculating values using Eq. (7) . It reached more than 99% at V D.1 8. Its increment was barely perceptible when V D.1 was beyond 8. Thus, V D.1 equal to 8 was chosen in MF stage. The collected permeate obtained at the end of the first diafiltration ( V D.1 = 8) was used as the feed in the following UF stage. As HA concentration in the feed was lower (less than 150 mg/l), the feed was first pre-concentrated at a VCR by MWCO 60,000 membrane, according to the suggestions of Ng et al. [32] . Then, the second diafiltration began, and the permeate was discarded. Absorbance at 280 nm (Abs280) in the permeate was continuously monitored in the course of the diafiltration. When Abs280 in the permeate sample was less than 0.02 [33] , UF stage ended. Different VCRs adopted at pre-concentration would lead to different numbers of diavolume ( V D.2 ) at the end of this stage. For example, about 10-fold pure water was needed to wash out protein through UF membrane to satisfy the terminal condition when VCR reached 12. Some results of the stage (including pre-concentration) are listed in Table 3 . It can be seen that the total time, T 2 (sum of pre-concentration time, T c and diafiltration time, T d.2 ) needed in the stage was shortest at VCR 8. Although T c was shortest and the permeation flux in the second diafiltration was largest at VCR 4, they were outweighed by large volume of the diafiltration feed. Therefore, the total time was still highest. What is more, pure water needed as diafiltrate was most. One advantage at VCR 12 was that pure water needed as diafiltrate was least. However, T c was longest. In addition, the initial concentrations of HA and proteins in the second diafiltration were highest, which led to lowest permeation flux during diafiltration and biggest V D.2 at the end of the stage. Therefore, the time for diafiltration was still high, so was the total time. Another point should be noted that the yield of HA ( Y 2 ) declined with increasing VCR. The reason for it was that bigger VCR led to bigger V D.2 , which in turn led to more HA washed out with proteins in the diafiltration. That would cause the reduction in the yield since HA was recovered from the retentate in the second diafiltration. It seemed to more reasonable that the second diafiltration in UF stage began after pre-concentration at VCR 8 based on the results listed in Table 3 and analysis mentioned above. Y 2 was higher than the predictions using Eq. (10) for two reasons. One was that P HA declined gradually so that its average (about 3.5%) was below the level shown in Table 2 in the course of the second diafiltration due to long-term membrane fouling. The other was that HA with smaller molecular size was firstly washed out, and HA with larger molecular size left would reduce the permeation factor. The less P HA would result in less loss of HA in the retentate and consequently increased HA yield in the stage. The higher Y 2 crucially led to higher overall yield of HA ( Y ) as Y 1 was more than 99%. Thus, Y was also higher than the predictions using Eq. (12) . 4.2.2 Scheme 2: MF-UF (using permeate from UF as diafiltrate for MF) The second scheme was tested to improve the yield of HA and save pure water as diafiltrate in the above two-stage membrane process. The collected permeate solution from previous UF stage was used as the diafiltrate for MF stage of scheme 2. One volume of pure water was provided to further wash out HA from the retentate before the end of the first diafiltration. Then, began UF stage, including pre-concentration step and the second diafiltration, which was similar to that described in scheme 1. The permeate solution from previous UF stage contained 18.3 mg/l of HA and 1.356 of Abs280. Fig. 5 shows the variations of HA and proteins contents in the retentates and HA yield in the two stages with the numbers of diavolume. The contents of HA and Abs280 in the retentate went down rather quickly when the diafiltrate volume was less than six-fold initial volume of the feed in the first diafiltration ( Fig. 5 a). Then, they declined smoothly. At V D.1 9, the concentration of HA was about 20 mg/l. One volume of pure water was added at this time as it was impossible for HA concentration to be lowered to the concentration in the diafiltrate from previous UF stage. Then, it was lowered abruptly. It declined very slowly while the contents of proteins in the retentate went down rapidly in the latter period of the second diafiltration, indicating the increase in S pro/HA due to reduction of P HA for UF membrane ( Fig. 5 b). The yield of HA reached 117% at the end of MF stage thanks to recovery of HA from the permeate solution of previous UF stage. Thus, the overall yield in the process increased to 89%, compared with that in scheme 1. Besides, the process only needed 10.5-fold volumes of pure water as diafiltrate. 4.2.3 Comparisons of two schemes tested Main results of separating HA with the two schemes tested are listed in Table 4 . It should be noted that the total process time, T was the sum of the times needed in two stages, including the time needed for pre-concentration (VCR = 8). The purification factors of HA ( β ) were calculated using Eq. (14) , in terms of experimental measurements of solute contents in the initial feed and final product solution. In this work, only cell bodies and proteins were considered as impurities in HA solution. The two schemes could effectively separate HA from the fermentation broth, and the purification factors were about 1000, which showed the product had a high purity. Scheme 2 greatly improved the yield of HA (to 89%), and saved much pure water needed as diafiltrate ( V D = 10.5). One disadvantage was that it had the longer total process time. However, a much bigger membrane filtering area is usually used in the practical application of membrane process, which will shorten the process time to a large degree. Therefore, scheme 2 seemed to be more effective for the practical use. 5 Conclusions The combination of MF with UF membranes could effectively separate HA from fermentation broth on the given optimized operating conditions. MF membranes with pore size 0.2–0.45 μm could be used to remove cell bodies, and UF membranes with MWCO 100–300 kDa to retain HA but allow protein impurities to pass through. The optimal operating conditions in this work were TMP 0.1 MPa, v 1.25 m/s, solution pH 4.0 and EIS 0.25 mol/l NaCl for MF membranes, and 0.15 MPa, 1.25 m/s, pH 7.0 and 0.10–0.25 mol/l NaCl for UF membranes respectively. The process, with two different separating schemes, could achieve above 77% overall yield and about 1000 purification factor of HA. Using the permeate from the previous UF stage as diafiltrate for MF stage seemed to be more effective as could improve the overall yield of HA (to 89%) and save pure water. The tangential flow filtration system used in the experiments can be easily scaled, using properly designed membrane system [34] . Therefore, a similar level of separation of HA would be achieved at large scale. References [1] D.M. Krstić S.L. Markov M.N. XIzSoUdl.title: FeCl(3).6H(2)O catalyzed disproportionation of allylic alcohols and selective allylic reduction of allylic alcohols and their derivatives with benzyl alcohol.
XIzSoUdl.abstract: Iron chloride has been found to be an efficient catalyst for the disproportionation of allylic alcohols, which provides a convenient method for selective transformation of allylic alcohols to alkenes and alpha,beta-unsaturated ketones. Furthermore, this catalytic system is also effective for highly selective allylic reduction of allylic alcohols, allylic ethers, and allylic acetates with benzyl alcohol under neutral and convenient reaction conditions.

UL45ylEX.title: The influence of the large military exercise on the soldiers' some immune-endocrine function
UL45ylEX.abstract: Objective To investigate the influences of large-scale military exercise on immune and endocrine secretory function of soldiers.Methods The psychological stress self-evaluation test(PSET)was applied on 126 officers and soldiers before and after the military exercise.Radioimmunoassay(RIA)technique was employed to determine the contents of serum interlukine-2(IL-2),interlukine-6(IL-6),interlukine-8(IL-8),tumor necrosis factor(TNF),cortisol(Cor)and aldosterone(Ald)in 126 subjects.All data were processed by correlation analysis.Results Compared with that of before exercise,the contents of serum IL-2 declined significantly(P<0.05),while the serum IL-6,IL-8,TNF,cortisol and aldosterone increased significantly(P<0.05)after the military exercise in the 126 officers and soldiers after the military exercise.There was a positive correlation between the serum contents of the above agents and PSET.Conclusion As a strong psychosocial stress agent,military exercise may cause obvious physiological changes in participants.It is necessary to give suitable psychological and physiological intervention,in order to reduce the stress induced by military exercise.

CQBvjfYZ.title: Corilagin, a promising medicinal herbal agent
CQBvjfYZ.abstract: Abstract   Corilagin, a gallotannin, is one of the major active components of many ethnopharmacological plants. It was isolated from  Caesalpinia coriaria  (Jacq.) Willd. (dividivi) by Schmidt in 1951 for the first time. In the past few decades, corilagin was reported to exhibit anti-tumor, anti-inflammatory and hepatoprotective activities,  etc . However, little attention was paid to its pharmacological properties due to the complicated and inefficient extract method. In recent years, with the development of extraction technology corilagin was much easier to obtain than before. Thus, people return to pay attention to its anti-tumor, hepatoprotective, and anti-inflammatory activities, particularly as an anti-tumor agent candidate. Our research team had focused on the distribution, preparation and anti-tumor activity of corilagin since 2005. We found corilagin showed good anti-tumor activity on hepatocellular carcinoma and ovarian cancer. What’s more, corilagin showed a low level of toxicity toward normal cells and tissues. Due to the extensive attention that corilagin has received, we present a systematic review of the pharmacological effects of corilagin. In this review, we summarized all the pharmacological effects of corilagin with a focus on the molecular mechanism of anti-tumor activity and show you how corilagin affected the signaling pathways of tumor cells as well as its physicochemical properties, distribution and preparation methods.

2sLDnsnF.title: Supramolecular organogelators based on Janus type at nucleosides
2sLDnsnF.abstract: J-AT nucleoside-based organogelators 1a and 1b were designed and synthesized. They were endowed with unparalleled superiority to natural nucleobase analogues 2-6 to gelate aromatic solvents due to their excellent self-assembly properties. The J-AT nucleoside-based organogelators showed a specific self-complementary base pair recognition characteristic. The gel stabilities of 1a and 1b were drastically influenced by adenine analogue 2, hardly affected by thymine analogue 3, uracil analogue 4, cytosine analogue 5, and mildly interrupted by guanine analogue 6. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd. dJYiX2KL.title: Isolation and characterization of microcrystalline cellulose from pomelo peel.
dJYiX2KL.abstract: In this study, cellulose from pomelo peel (PP-C) was isolated using alkaline hydrogen peroxide liquor extraction, and PP-C was further hydrolyzed by hydrochloric acid to yield microcrystalline cellulose (PP-MCC). Several analytical methods were used to determine the structural characteristics, crystalline behavior, morphological properties, thermal properties, and water/oil binding capacity of PP-C and PP-MCC. Fourier-transform infrared spectra and morphological analysis showed that the alkaline hydrogen peroxide treatment and acid hydrolysis successfully removed hemicellulose and lignin from pomelo peel fibers. Both PP-C and PP-MCC had only a cellulose I polymorph structure, and the crystallinity index of PP-MCC increased compared with that of PP-C. The degradation temperatures of PP-C and PP-MCC were approximately 257 °C and 280 °C, respectively. The water/oil binding capacity of PP-MCC was significantly higher than that of the commercial MCC. Our results thus suggested that PP-MCC might be suitable for use as a food stabilizer and pharmaceutical additive.

I2ITEYqG.title: Up-to-Standard Rate of Hemoglobin Levels and the Impact of Age and Sex among New Hemodialysis Patients in Beijing in 2008
I2ITEYqG.abstract: Objective To analyze the up-to-standard rate of hemoglobin levels among new hemodialysis patients from Beijing Hemodialysis Qulity Control Improvement Center(BJHDQCIC)in 2008,and to investigate it′s relationship with the gender and age of the patients.Methods Up-to-standard rate of hemoglobin levels of prevalent and incident hemodialysis patients in Beijing were analysed.The relationship between hemoglobin levels with gender and age was further investigated.Results The overall up-to-standard rate of hamoglobin in Beijing in 2008 was 11.83%,38.91%,and 43.02% respectively for patients at the beginning of hemodialysis,after 3~6 months of hemodialysis,and after 6 months of hemodialysis.Sex was one of the factors that effected the up-to-standard rate of haematochrome at the beginning of the dialysis therapy(P=0.002),while no sex differences were noticed in patients after 3~6 months of hemodialysis(P>0.05).Again,no significant differences were noticed among different age groups both at the beginning and after 3~6 months of the dialysis therapy.The overall up-to-standard rate of hamoglobin in the group over 6 months of dialysis treatment is higher than in the other groups for patients over 60(P<0.01).Conclusion The overall up-to-standard rate of hemoglobin in Beijing hemodialysis patients is lower than in other countries because of the lack of treatment in the earlier stages.Gender and age are among the factors that affect the up-to-standard rate of hemoglobin.
