wm40fvXA.title: Experimental study on the dynamic tensile behavior of a poly-crystal pure titanium at elevated temperatures
wm40fvXA.abstract: A new technique for measuring dynamic tensile behavior of metallic materials at elevated temperatures was developed. This technique employs a rapid contact heating method to obtain a stable and nearly homogenous high temperature field in the testing gage of the specimen. As an application of this new technique, a commercially pure titanium (CP-Ti) was tested in the strain rate range of 300 s −1 –1400 s −1 and in a temperature range of 298 K–973 K. Quasi-static experiments (10 −3 s −1 , 10 −2 s −1 ) were also performed in the same temperature range for comparison. The testing results indicated that both temperature and strain rate have pronounced influence on the mechanical behavior of CP-Ti. Keywords High temperature Strain rate Dynamic behavior Titanium 1 Introduction Numerous engineering applications of structural metallic materials involve dynamic or impact types of loading. In order to make a full understanding on the deformation and fracture process of these structures, it is necessary to know the dynamic properties of the materials involved in these structural components. When the loading rate is high, the mechanical response of a material is generally different from what it is at a lower rate. This is commonly explained by the theory of “thermal activation” [1] , i.e. the dislocation movement, which is usually the determinant of plastic flow, is dominated by the applied stress and the thermal equilibrium fluctuation of the dislocation. One of the important results of this theory is that the effective stress required for the plastic flow is greatly dependent on the strain rate and temperature at which the deformation occurs. This mechanism is particularly important in the high-rate deformation process, since elevated temperature arises naturally in high-rate deformation through adiabatic heating. Therefore, understanding of the dynamic plastic response of metals at elevated temperatures is of fundamental importance for the understanding of the rate-controlling mechanisms of plastic flow as well as of technical importance for applications in which high temperatures involved. The first and the most important step of this research is to develop an effective high-rate high-temperature testing system. In this section, we will make a brief review on the development of such apparatus. Since the Split Hopkinson Pressure Bar (SHPB) [2] is the most common approach to the measurement of the dynamic response of materials, investigations on the temperature dependence of materials at high strain rates are mainly focused on their compression properties. In general, there are two categories of methods to realize such high-temperature experiment [3] . One approach is to heat the specimen while it is in contact with the input and output bars, allowing a high temperature rise to develop within the bars. This approach requires further adjustment in the temperature-dependent modulus, and thus the impedance and wave velocity, of the bar material [4–6] . Another method is to heat the specimen while minimize the temperature rise and the length of affected region of the bars. Based on this concept, Frantz et al. [7] developed a non-contact heating technique in the SHPB systems. A screw-driven bar mover system is used to move the bars into contact with the well heated specimen just a few milliseconds before testing. Since the contact time for the cold bars and the specimen is short, there is not enough time for the temperature of the specimen to drop and for the temperature in the bars to increase significantly. Similar ideas were also adopted by other researchers [8,9] . However, this technique is limited to compressive test in which the specimen is simply placed between the bars. In tensile tests, the specimen must be glued or mechanically connected to the bars, which is impossible to accomplish in a very short time. A different way to heat the specimen while keeping the bar in a relatively low temperature is to use a high intensity localized heating device, such approach was attempted by Rosenberg et al. [10] using induction heating for tests at temperatures up to 700 °C. It must be noted that, most of the high-rate high-temperature experimental researches have been focused on the compression tests. However, investigations have shown that the mechanical responses of many materials are quite different while subjected to different types of loading. For example, in many initially-textured poly-crystalline hexagonal metals (e.g. rolled plates or extruded rods), a compressive stress applied nearly parallel to the basal planes of the grains favors twinning, whereas a similarly-directed tensile stress can not induce such twins [11,12] . As a result, the stress–strain curves of these materials obtained in tension and compression are very different. Such tension/compression asymmetry makes high-rate high-temperature tensile test very essential for getting a full knowledge of the mechanical behaviors of metals. In the present research, a new experimental technique was developed for tensile impact testing at elevated temperature. This technique uses two preheated furnaces to rapidly heat the specimen to a desired temperature in a rather short period of time, thus avoids a significant temperature rise in input and output bars. As an application, the effects of temperature and strain rate on the mechanical behavior of a commercially pure titanium (CP-Ti) was studied. The new technique is described in the following section. 2 Experimental techniques 2.1 Tension technique Since Harding firstly developed tensile Hopkinson-bar technique in 1960 [13] , various modifications have been made to generate tensile loading pulse in Split Hopkinson Bar (SHB) system. Nicholas [14] place a shoulder between the two Hopkinson Pressure Bars, so the initial compression wave will bypass the specimen and then reflected in tension to load the specimen. Staab and Gilat [15] introduced a direct-tension Split Hopkinson-bar apparatus in which the specimen is loaded by a tensile wave that is generated by the release of a prestressed section of the incident bar. In recent decades, direct impact on an impact block connected to the input bar was employed to generate tension pulse [16,17] . A weighbar tube or a gas gun with strike tube was generally used for generating the load. Xia et al. [18] further developed an indirect method by placing a short metal bar between the impact block and the incident bar, as shown in Fig. 1 . Tensile wave will be created while the short metal bar is subjected to impact loading and deformed to fracture. The main superiority of this modification is that the amplitude and duration of the incident pulse could be easily shaped only by changing the diameter and length of the short metal bar. Moreover, attributed to its plastic flow, the prefixed short metal bar can filter the high-frequency oscillation introduced by the impact process to the loading pulse, thus a rather smooth incident wave is obtained and the pseudo constitutive response brought by the oscillation [19] can be eliminated. 2.2 The high temperature Split Hopkinson Tension Bar (SHTB) at USTC Based on the concept of rapid contact localized heating, two versions of heating furnaces and the corresponding methods of temperature measurement were developed successively [20,21] . Compared with the heating furnace in reference [20] , better stability, higher heating efficiency and greater thermal inertia can be achieved in the heating furnace presented in this paper. The schematic diagram of the testing system and the photograph of the furnace are shown in Figs. 1a and 2 , respectively. The testing process is illustrated in Fig. 1 a, the specimen and the bars are connected by a kind of inorganic adhesive. A pair of heating furnaces is placed at each side of the specimen. Inside each furnace, a stainless steel bar, which is used as a heat storage, is heated by a heating coil wound around it. A thermocouple, mounted tightly in a central hole drilled in the center of the heat storage, provides the temperature measurement and the feedback to a temperature monitor. The measured temperature rise history is shown in Fig. 3 , where T d is the preset temperature at which the power is switched off by the monitor, and T f is a plateau temperature ( T f is defined as the temperature about 5 K below the maximum temperature). At T f the furnaces are pushed into contact with the specimen, and the specimen is heated by two copper conductors fixed on the heat storage ( Fig. 2 ). In a very short time (about 30 s), a stable and nearly homogenous temperature field can be formed in the testing gage of the specimen, then the tensile impact experiment is performed immediately. The specimen geometry and the connection between the specimen and the bars are shown in Fig. 4 . Due to the difficulties in mounting the thermocouple on the testing gage of the specimen during test [20] , we used an indirect method to determine the temperature of the specimen. In this method, a calibrating experiment was taken to establish the relationship between T f and the specimen temperature T s . As shown in Fig. 4 , three holes are drilled in the testing gage of the specimen, and three thermocouples are placed in the holes to measure the temperature distribution in the testing gage while the copper conductors are in contact with the specimen. At the same time, T f is measured by the thermocouple placed in the central hole of the heat storage. Thus the temperature relationship between T s and T f can be established. Fig. 5 shows the temperature rise history at the central hole of the specimen. It can be seen that after about 1 min, the temperature reaches a stable value ( T s1 ) and keeps for a certain duration Δ t 2 . In this duration, the maximum variance of T s1 is about 1% at all testing temperatures ( Table 1 ). It can be also seen that Δ t 2 gets shorter with increasing T s1 and reduces to a value of 1 min when T s1 = 1073 K. Considering that the dynamic tensile process can be accomplished in about 30 s after T s1 reaches the stable value, Δ t 2 is long enough for testing. Table 1 shows the temperature distribution in the testing gage of the specimen and the relationship between T f and T s . Here we use G = max[( T s1 − T s2 ), ( T s1 − T s3 )]/ T s1 ( T s2 and T s3 denote the stable temperatures of the two side holes) to describe the inhomogeneity of the temperature distribution, and the result shows that G < 3%. To the authors’ knowledge, no other estimation on the temperature gradient in the specimen for the high-rate testing is available expect that reported by A.M. Lennon [23] , their analysis indicated that over 85% of the specimen length experiences less than 10% drop from the initial temperature during the test. So, the present heating method is deemed acceptable for the extraction of high temperature data. The temperature distribution in the input/output bar is shown in Fig. 6 , where X denotes the distance between the measuring point and the face of input/out bar at the connecting end. Because the temperature at X = 0 is hard to be measured (as shown in Fig. 2 ), an one dimensional steady conduction equation T ( x ) = T ∞ + ( T (0) − T ∞ )e − mx to describe this temperature distribution and extrapolate the data to X = 0. From Fig. 6 it can be seen that there is a thermal influence region of length about 18 cm, where the temperature is higher than room temperature. Out of this region, the temperature falls to room temperature. In the present apparatus, the strain gauges adhered on the input/output bar are located far away from the thermal influence region, thus the thermal influence on the strain gauges can be neglected. When the temperature of specimen is 1073 K, the temperature at X = 0 is no more than 540 K. Rosenberg et al. [22] conducted experiment in which the tips of the bars touched each other and were heated up to 673 K, the transmitted and reflected pulses were compared with those obtained at room temperature and the difference in the measured strain pulses was less than one percent. So, in the present research, the influence of the temperature rise in the bars is deemed negligible and no adjustment is applied in the data processing. In order to find out the influence of the friction between the copper conductors and the specimen on the testing result, two tests, one with the copper conductors and the specimen in contact and the other with them separated, were performed at room temperature. It was found that the obtained stress–strain curves are essentially identical, which indicates that the influence of the friction can be neglected. 3 Application of the technique to a commercially pure titanium 3.1 Material and experimental approach A 99% CP-Ti plate was received as the testing material, the chemical composition is given in Table 2 . The as-received plate was first annealed at 977 K for 2 h in vacuum, then cooled to room temperature. Metallographic examination of the annealed material revealed an average grain size of approximately 90 μm. Dynamic tensile tests (at the strain rates of 300 s −1 and 1400 s −1 ) were carried out on the above mentioned apparatus in a temperature range of 298 K–973 K, using the specimen as shown in Fig. 4 a. Quasi-static tensile tests (at the strain rates of 10 −2 s −1 and 10 −3 s −1 ) were also carried out on a MTS809 testing machine in the same temperature range. 3.2 Testing results and discussion The engineering stress strain curves ( σ e = σ e ( ɛ e )) of CP-Ti were firstly obtained from the tests, then these curves were converted into true stress strain curves ( σ = σ ( ɛ )) by the following formulation: σ = σ e (1 + ɛ e ), ɛ = ln (1 + ɛ e ). True stress–true strain curves are shown in Fig. 7 . It can be seen that temperature and strain rate have pronounced effects on the mechanical behavior of CP-Ti. For indicated strain rate, the flow stress decreases dramatically with increasing temperature, while the strain hardening changes little in a certain temperature range (about 423 K–623 K under quasi-static condition and 523 K–773 K under dynamic condition). Previous compression tests conducted by A.M. Lennon and K.T. Ramesh [23] found that both the yield stress and the strain hardening change markedly with temperature. They deemed this characteristic an important distinction between HCP metal (CP-Ti) and BCC metal, and deformation twinning was believed to play an important role to this behavior. Since the response of deformation twinning to tensile and compressive loading are quite different, the distinction of temperature dependence of strain hardening between tension and compression can be caused by this tension–compression asymmetry of twinning. In order to reveal the effect of deformation twinning on the tensile behavior of CP-Ti, the microstructures of the undeformed specimen and the fractured specimens are examined by optical metallography. The optical micrographs from different strain rates and temperature are shown in Fig. 8 . The undeformed specimen is free of any deformation twinning. For the fractured specimens, it's clear that a large number of deformation twins appear at room temperature, and the density of twin increases with strain rate. As the temperature increases, the number of twin decreases dramatically. At 423 K, only a fraction of grains are twinned at strain rate 1400 s −1 and even fewer grains are twinned at strain rate 0.01 s −1 . When the temperature reaches 523 K, very few number of twins exist at strain rate 1400 s −1 and no twin can be observed at strain rate 0.01 s −1 (not shown in Fig. 8 ). Previous study [24] on the compressive behavior of CP-Ti also revealed that the density of deformation twin decreases with increasing temperature and decreasing strain rate. However, deformation twin is observed at nearly all testing temperatures (77 K–1000 K) in compression tests. Compared with the present results, it seems deformation twinning is more likely to occur under compressive loading condition. In the case where slip and twinning are co-existent in a deformed specimen, the shear strain involved in twinning may give a lower strain hardening. On the other hand, twinning may divide the grains thus reduce the effective slip distance and thereby raise the hardening rate [25] . It can be seen in Fig. 7 that in an indicated strain rate, the strain hardening rate at room temperature is obviously higher than those at higher temperature. Considering the difference of twin density at various temperatures as shown in Fig. 8 , the present results seem to indicate that the main function of deformation twin is to raise the strain hardening rate by the grain-refined mechanism. Under dynamic conditions, the total elongation firstly decreases with temperature, then increases with it ( Fig. 9 ). Based on the above metallographic observation, the decrease of total elongation is probably caused by the reduction of deformation twins. As the temperature increases, the number of deformation twins decreases thus reduces the strain hardening rate. Smaller strain hardening rate is apt to cause local deformation, and leads to a decreasing of total elongation. Under quasi-static condition, the total elongation shows a trend of decreasing–increasing–decreasing–increasing with increasing temperature ( Fig. 9 ). The reason for the first decreasing of total elongation is as mentioned above. The second decreasing appears at the “blue brittle” temperature [26] , this “blue brittle” temperature increases with strain rate, which makes the second decreasing of total elongation disappear at dynamic condition. The quasi-static stress–strain curves show no obvious yield point at all testing temperatures. On the contrary, the curves under dynamic conditions show more complicated yield behaviors: At ε ˙ = 300   s − 1 , no obvious yield point can be seen when T s < 693 K, a yield point appears when T s = 693 K and this yield point is replaced by a more marked single yield drop when T s > 693 K. At ε ˙ = 1400   s − 1 , an obvious yield point appears at T s = 623 K, and when T s > 623 K, stress oscillation with multiple peaks appears after the yield drop. Harding [27] observed the similar flow stress oscillation in dynamic compressive tests on CP-Ti at room temperature and at 77 K, and attributed this oscillation to the effect of twinning. Considering that twinning is apt to occur under low temperature or high strain rate and the present stress oscillation tends to be pronounced at higher temperature, it seems twinning is not responsible for this phenomenon. An exact explanation required further investigation. The temperature dependence of flow stress at various strain rates is shown in Fig. 10 . It can be seen that at strain rate 10 −3 s −1 , the flow stress appears to be temperature-independent in the temperature range 623 K < T s < 773 K. Compressive tests on CP-Ti [24] gave the similar result. In addition, under dynamic conditions, the flow stress is rate-independent when 693 K < T s < 773 K. The rate and temperature independence of flow stress is generally explained by dynamic strain aging. In suitable range of temperatures and strain rates, when the point defects are mobile enough to diffuse along with the moving dislocation, an effective drag will occur and result in the “abnormal” temperature and strain rate dependence of flow stress. The “blue brittleness” at quasi-static condition is also a feature of dynamic strain aging. 4 Conclusion By introducing a rapid contact heating device to the self-designed tensile impact apparatus, a high-rate high-temperature tensile testing system was developed for the experimental study on metallic materials in the strain rate range of about 200 s −1 –2000 s −1 , and temperatures up to 1073 K. A thorough calibration on the testing system showed that the present technique is capable of obtaining a stable and nearly homogenous temperature field in the testing gage of the specimen and avoiding a significant temperature rise in the input and output bars during test. Tensile experiments on the CP-Ti were carried out in a temperature range of 298 K–973 K and a strain rate range of 10 −3 s −1 –1400 s −1 . The testing results indicate that: (1) The density of deformation twinning rapidly decreases with increasing temperature, which leads to a noticeable difference of strain hardening rate of the stress–strain curve at room temperature 298 K and higher temperatures. (2) Compared with the existed compression testing results, the compressive loading seems apt to promote deformation twinning. (3) The total elongation versus temperature curves show multiple humps and valleys. However, there exist different trend between dynamic and quasi-static loading conditions. (4) The yield point shows a complicated temperature and rate dependence. Stress vibration appears at the high-rate high-temperature condition. fmpgIS07.title: Research on the tool- setting technology based on SINUMERIK 840D
fmpgIS07.abstract: In order to set up the workpiece coordinate,to measure the position and pose,and to calibrate the MRF's blade,it's necessary to finish the tool- setting automatically in the MRF machines before machining workpiece. To satisfy the MRF with high repositioning accuracy,high safety and reliability,the tool-setting method and the module are designed based SINUMERIK 840D with renishaw's MCP probe. The technology can also be applied to other NC machines to realize the tool- setting automatically with lower.

PVZAdtU1.title: Changes of QT interval and QT dispersion in maintenance hemodialysis patients
PVZAdtU1.abstract: Objective To discuss the effects of hemodialysis on QT interval and QT dispersion in maintenance hemodialysis patients. Methods Left ventricular thickness and mass were measured by echocardiogram in 58 maintenance hemodialysis patients. QT interval and QT dispersion were measured by 12-lead synchronously recording ECG and corrected QT internal, QTcd were calculated. Results LVMI, QTcmax, QTd and QTcd of hemodialysis patients were longer than that of normal controls(P<0.05); post-values of QTmax、 QTcmax、 QTd、 QTcd were longer than pre-values (P<0.01); QTd was directly correlated to LVMI and pre-dialysis MAP (r=0.41 and 0.34 respectively, P<0.05). Conclusion The hemodialysis session may predispose some individuals to ventricular arrhythmias, and measuring QTd, QTcd may be a way to evaluate the risks of ventricular arrhythmias.

wqMxPAH1.title: Effect of doxycycline on connexin 43 protein expression of cardiomyoblast cells in anoxic rat
wqMxPAH1.abstract: Objectives To investigate the effects and the possible mechanisms of doxycycline on the expression of connexin 43(Cx43) in rat H9c2 cardiomyoblast cells under hypoxic conditions.Methods H9c2 cardiomyoblast cells were cultured with hypoxia treatment for 6 h,12 h and 24 h.Expressions of Cx43 in cardiomyocytes were quantified by Western Blotting,as well as the changes intervened by matrix metalloproteinases(MMPs) inhibitor(doxycycline),PI3K inhibitor(LY294002),ERK1 / 2 inhibitor(U0l26) under hypoxic conditions.Results Expression of Cx43 in hypoxia group was obviously lower than that in normal control group(P<0.01).Expressions of Cx43 in doxycycline group and U0126 group were obviously higher than that in hypoxia group after 6 h of hypoxia(P <0.05)..Expression of Cx43 in U0126 group was still obviously higher than that in hypoxia group after 12 h(P<0.05)..Expressions of Cx43 in doxycycline group and U0126 group had no significant differences with that in hypoxia group after 24 h(P >0.05).Expressions of Cx43 in LY294002 group were significantly lower than that in hypoxia group during the observation(P <0.01).Conclusions By inhibiting the activity of MMPs,doxycycline increased Cx43 protein expression in anoxic H9c2 cardiomyoblast cells,which indicates that this effect can partly inhibit ERK1 / 2 signaling pathway.

agiwd8pH.title: Analysis and Research on the Real-Time Performance of Profibus Fieldbus
agiwd8pH.abstract: As the Profibus is generally applied in the field of control, its feature of real-time has become more and more important. This paper promotes an improved analyzing method on the single-master Profibus stations. In this method, single-master Profibus DP networks' feature and its protocol are analyzed, and the impact on the messages' real-time and network load of different priority level using different token processing modes is researched. After that, it gives a calculation method of the response time in the Profibus' worst network condition. At last, we could conclude that Profibus is a type of definite network. At the same time, Profibus network's real-time feature could meet the needs in most application situation.
agiwd8pH.venue: Software Engineering, 2009. WCSE '09. WRI World Congress

zxqh8nz9.title: In vitro evaluation of tectoridin, tectorigenin and tectorigenin sodium sulfonate on antioxidant properties.
zxqh8nz9.abstract: Tectoridin (4',5,7-thrihydroxy-6-methoxyisoflavone-7-O-β-d-glucopyranoside) isolated from the flowers of Pueraria thunbergiana is reported to have less hepatoprotective, hypoglycemic, antiallergic and anaphylaxis inhibitory activity than its aglycone form tectorigenin. To obtain tectorigenin, tectoridin was hydrolyzed in the current study. However, practical limitations of tectorigenin do exist due to its poor water-solubility. To increase its water-solubility, tectorigenin was sulfonated with sulfuric acid (98wt.%) and mixed with saturated salt water to produce tectorigenin sodium sulfonate. Tectoridin and the two transfer products were identified by UV, IR, HPLC-MS, (1)H NMR and (13)C NMR, and the solubility of tectorigenin sodium sulfonate was increased about 9-fold than tectorigenin. Antioxidant experiments of tectoridin, tectorigenin and modified tectorigenin in vitro including reducing power, superoxide anion radical scavenging activity, hydroxyl radical scavenging activity, 1,1-diphenyl-2-picryl-hydrazyl (DPPH) radical scavenging activity and anti-lipid peroxidation were carried on comparing with ascorbic acid (Vc) or butylated hydroxytoluene (BHT). The results suggested that the antioxidant activity in all the experimental systems exhibited the same order as follows: tectorigenin sodium sulfonate>tectorigenin>tectoridin. Due to the high water-solubility and good antioxidant properties with tectorigenin sodium sulfonate, appropriate chemical modifications could greatly improve the biological activities of the naturally occurring products.

8UDQ08Js.title: ZNF569, a novel KRAB-containing zinc finger protein, suppresses MAPK signaling pathway.
8UDQ08Js.abstract: Transcription factors play an essential role in altering gene expression. A great progress about transcription factors has been made towards the understanding of normal physiological processes, embryonic development, and human diseases. Here we report the identification and characterization of a novel KRAB-containing zinc-finger protein, ZNF569, which is isolated from a human embryonic heart cDNA library. ZNF569 encodes a putative protein of 686 amino acids. The protein is conserved across different species during evolution. Expression of ZNF569 was found in most of the examined human adult and embryonic tissues with a higher level in heart and skeletal muscles. The KRAB and ZNF motifs of ZNF569 represent potent repression domains. When ZNF569 is fused to Gal-4 DNA-binding domain and co-transfected with VP-16, ZNF569 protein suppresses transcriptional activity. Overexpression of ZNF569 in COS-7 cells inhibited the transcriptional activities of SRE and AP-1, which may be silenced by siRNA. The results suggest that ZNF569 protein may act as a transcriptional repressor that suppresses MAPK signaling pathway to mediate cellular functions.

yrPqbOK3.title: Statistical dynamic tensile strength of UHMWPE-fibers
yrPqbOK3.abstract: Dynamic tensile properties of UHMWPE fiber bundles were studied at two strain rates and two temperatures. The integral stress–strain curves were obtained. Experimental data show that UHMWPE fiber bundle has strain rate and temperature sensitivity. A fiber-bundle constitutive equation was used to describe the tensile behavior of UHMWPE fiber bundles at high strain rates. The good consistency between the simulated results and experimental data indicates that the 5-parameter Weibull function can represent the tensile strength distribution of UHMWPE fibers and the method of extracting Weibull parameters from fiber bundles stress–strain data is valid.

8C9UaZoh.title: Production of diosgenin from Dioscorea zingiberensis tubers through enzymatic saccharification and microbial transformation.
8C9UaZoh.abstract: In order to develop a clean and effective approach for producing the valuable drug diosgenin from Dioscorea zingiberensis tubers, two successive processes, enzymatic saccharification and microbial transformation, were used. With enzymatic saccharification, 98.0% of starch was excluded from the raw herb, releasing saponins from the network structure of starch. Subsequently, the treated tubers were fermented with Trichoderma reesei under optimal conditions for 156 h. During microbial transformation, glycosidic bonds, which link beta-D-glucose or alpha-L-rhamnose with aglycone at the C-3 position in saponins, were broken down effectively to give a diosgenin yield of 90.6+/-2.45%, 42.4% higher than that obtained from bioconversion of raw tubers directly. Scaled up fermentation was conducted in a 5.0-l bioreactor and gave a diosgenin yield of 91.2+/-3.21%. This is the first report on the preparation of diosgenin from herbs through microbial transformation as well as utilizing other available components in the raw material, providing an environmentally friendly alternative to diosgenin production.

1G5QYUt3.title: The relationship between platelet count and inflammation-malnutrition state in maintenance hemodialysis patients
1G5QYUt3.abstract: Objective To investigate the relationship between platelet count and inflammation-malnutrition state in maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) patients. Methods A total of 68 clinically stable MHD patients in Beijing Tongren Hospital were recruited for this study. Patients were divided into 6 groups according to platelet count. General conditions, routine blood counts and serum biochemical indexes were compared among the groups. Data were processed by using SPSS17.0 software. Results Dialysis age, blood urine nitrogen, serum albumin, total cholesterol, low density lipoprotein-cholesterol (LDL-C), high sensitive C-reactive protein (hsCRP), white blood cell (WBC), blood hemoglobin were significantly different among the six groups. Multiple regression indicated that platelet count positively correlated with hsCRP (β=0.208, P<0.05), LDL-C (β=1.143, P<0.05) and WBC (β=0.631, P<0.05), and negatively correlated with serum albumin (β= -0.320, P<0.05) and hemoglobin (β=-0.271, P<0.05). Conclusion In MHD patients, inflammation-malnutrition state correlates to the increase of platelet count, which may be one of the mechanisms underlying the high risk of cardiovascular events in these patients.

58F7UJYs.title: Correlation between the soldiers' mental status,and their coping style and social supports in a military exercise
58F7UJYs.abstract: Objective To investigate the correlation between the soldier' mental status and their coping style and the social supports in a jointed military exercise.Methods 538 servicemen who took part in a jointed military exercise were selected as study objects.All the objects were interviewed with the aid of Symptom Check List-90(SCL-90),Eysenck Personality Questionnaire(EPQ),Simple Coping Style Questionnaire(SCSQ)and the Social Support Rating Scale(SSRS).Collected data were analyzed by statistical methods including t-test,chi-square test and Pearson product correlation analysis.Results The SCL-90 factor scores of the study objects were significantly higher than that of Chinese military personnel norms(P<0.01).14.7%(79/538)of the objects showed positive result(any single score ≥3)and had obvious psychological symptoms.The SCL-90 factor scores of 219 persons who had not previously taken part in other military exercise was higher than that who had taken part(P<0.05).There was significant correlation between the mental health of the servicemen and the coping style and social supports during jointed military exercise.There was negative correlation between SCL-90 scores except somatization and self-reproach(P<0.05),and negative correlation between SCL-90 and help-seeking,except interpersonal-sensitivity,intolerance,(P<0.05).All SCL-90 score was positively correlated with illusion(P<0.05).SCL-90 score was negatively correlatedly with retreatism(P<0.05),but not with somatization and hostility.SCL-90 score was positively correlated with rationnalization(P<0.05),but not with somatization and depression.SCL-90 score(interpersonal-sensitivity,depression,phobia,obsessive-compulsive and somatization)was negatively correlated with social support(P<0.05).SCL-90 score(depression,phobia,obsessive-compulsive and somatization)was negative correlated with objective supports(P<0.05).SCL-90 score(depression,phobia and somatization)was negative correlated with subjective supports(P<0.05).SCL-90 score(depression and obsessive-compulsive)was negative correlated with availability(P<0.05).Conclusion The servicemen who took part in a jointed military exercise showed strong psychological stress symptom.There is close correlation between the soldiers' mental health and the coping style and social supports.

PYmHBaw6.title: Biological effects of hypoxia on mesenchymal stem cells
PYmHBaw6.abstract: BACKGROUND: Oxygen is involved in the synthesis of ATP in cells for cellular metabolism, and the concentration of oxygen is also an important factor to control the physiological functions of cells. Physiological and pathological events of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells always occur under hypoxia condition, but the mechanism is still unclear. OBJECTIVE: To overview the research progress of the biological effects of hypoxia on mesenchymal stem cells. METHODS: A computer retrieval of PubMed database, Wanfang database, Weipu database and CNKI database (1997-01/2011-10) was conducted to search the related articles with the key words of "mesenchymal stem cells, hypoxia, hypoxia-induced factor" in English and Chinese. A total of 1 120 articles were retrieved, and finally 48 articles were included in final analysis according to the inclusion criteria. RESULTS AND CONCLUSION: Hypoxia induction could reduce the apoptosis of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells by upregulating the expression of vascular endothelial growth factor and anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2 and downregulating the expression of p53 apoptotic signaling. Hypoxia could increase the proliferation of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells by inhibiting WNT signaling pathway and bone morphogenetic protein signaling pathway. Hypoxic tissue could induce the migration of mesenchymal stem cells to hypoxic region, the main signal pathways in this process include vascular endothelial growth factor signaling pathway, stromal cell-derived factor-1 signaling pathway and c-Met signaling pathway. Hypoxia could also increase the adhesion of mesenchymal stem cells mainly through the high expression of cytoskeletal proteins and cell-cell adhesion molecule. Hypoxia could promote cell differentiation by increasing the expression of angiopoietin-1 and vascular endothelial growth factor and other factors.

7D9EtzQ5.title: Relationship between Apolipoprotein and Cardiocerebrovascular Complications in Patients with CRF
7D9EtzQ5.abstract: Objective:To assess the effect of hemodialysis on apolipoprotein AI(apoAI),apoB and apoB/apoAI ratio and to study the relationship between apolipoprotein and cardiocerebrovascular complications in patients with chronic renal failure(CRF).Methods:Sixty-five patients with end stage renal failure were divided into CRF group and maintain hemodialysis(MHD) group,which also including two subgroups separately:with or without cardiocerebrovascular complications.Twenty-one healthy persons were included in control group.apoAI,apoB,apoB/apoAI and serum albumin (Alb) were measured.Resultes:Comparing with control group,apoB,apoB/apoAI level were increased in CRF group(P<0.05),but there was no difference between control and MHD group;In both CRF and MHD group, comparing with subgroup without cardiocerebrovascular complications,the level of apoB,apoB/apoAI ratio were higher in subgroup with complications,but there was no statistical significance.Conclusion:Hemodialysis can decrease the level of apoB,apoB/apoAI ratio in CRF patients,but it has to carry out more studies to discuss whether they can be the lipoprotein related risk marker of cardiocerebrovascular diseases in patients with CRF.

u1gZK7Cb.title: Stability analysis of seven agronomic traits for soybean [(Glycine max (L.) Merr.] Tokachi nagaha and its derived cultivars using the AMMI model
u1gZK7Cb.abstract: The stabilities of seven agronomic traits were analyzed and the general stabilities of soybean [Glycine max (L.) Merr.] accessions were evaluated based on the additive main effects and multiplicative interactions (AMMI) model using the founder parent Tokachi nagaha and 137 of its derived cultivars as materials. The objective was to provide a theoretical basis for effectively using germplasm in soybean breeding and production. Analysis of variance (ANOVA) showed that genotype, environment, and genotype by environment interactions were significantly different for each trait. The first three interaction principal components axes (IPCA) were highly significant, accounting for 61.28–70.00% of the total variation. The stability differed for the different traits. 50 cultivars with high general stabilities were identified. The general stability of Tokachi nagaha was moderate, as the stability coefficients (Di) of its seven traits were relatively high; this must be considered by breeders using this cultiva...

wErExMp9.title: The strategy of stent graft repair for peripheral arterial injuries
wErExMp9.abstract: Objective To investigate the methods and efficacy of endovascular stent graft repair for patients with injury of peripheral artery. Methods A total of 20 cases involved, including 13 cases of open injury and 7 cases of closed injury. Of them, there were penetrating injury in 8 cases, occlusion after blunt injury in 5 cases, traumatic pseudoaneurysm in 3 cases and iatrogenic injury in 4 cases. Patients with mild arterial wall injury underwent endovascular treatment using stent graft directly,patients with severe damage of arterial wall or contusion of intimal received endovascular repari by antigrade and retrograde access. Results The success rate of operation was 100%,and no amputation and death occurred in peri-operative period. Mean follow-up time was 12.8 months(range,3～24 months). Good blood circulation was observed in the affected upper extremities by Doppler examination,and blood pressure difference between both sides of the limbs was less than 10%. The ankle brachial index(ABI) of patients with lower extremity arterial injuries improved from 0.37±0.16 to 0.96±0.08 before and after endovascular therapy. Mild stenosis at both ends of stent graft was observed in 2 patients by CT during the follow-up. Conclusion Endovascular therapy with stent graft is a less invasive and safe, effective treatment for peripheral arterial injuries.

9Sxmj1FC.title: Identification of a Heat-Inducible Element of Cysteine Desulfurase Gene Promoter in Lentinula edodes .
9Sxmj1FC.abstract: Volatile organosulfur compounds are the main components that contribute to the unique aroma of dried . They are mainly generated during the hot-air drying process, and cysteine desulfurase is the key enzyme in this process. Temperature may be an essential factor of volatile organosulfur compound production by influencing the expression of the cysteine desulfurase gene. In this study, the promoter sequence of the cysteine desulfurase gene () was cloned and analyzed using bioinformatics tools. A series of 5'deletion fragments and site-directed mutations of  were constructed to identify the element that responds to heat stress. Six heat shock transcription factor (HSTF) binding sites were predicted by SCPD (The Promoter Database of ) and three of the binding sites were predicted by Yeastract (Yeast Search for Transcriptional Regulators and Consensus Tracking) in . The results indicated that  was able to drive the expression of the  (Enhanced Green Fluorescent Protein) gene in . Moreover, the fluorescence intensity increased after heat stress. The changes in fluorescence intensity of different 5'deletion fragments showed that the heat response region was located between -500 bp and -400 bp in . The site-directed mutation analysis further showed that the heat-inducible element was between -490 bp and -500 bp (TTTCTAGAAT) in . Our results provide molecular insight for studying the formation of volatile organosulfur compounds in dried .

VNTkSEGh.title: Brain-derived neurotrophic factor induces rat bone marrow stromal cells to differentiate into neuron-like cells in vitro]
VNTkSEGh.abstract: To investigate brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF)-induced differentiation of rat bone marrow stromal cells (MSCs) into neuron-like cells in vitro and observe its neuroprotective effect of BNDF on the differentiated cells, which might provide the better seed cells for treatment of nervous system diseases.The fifth-passage MSCs were induced by BDNF and 2-mercapto ethanol beta-ME respectively, 1, 3 and 6 h after which the induced neuron-like cells were counted and compared. At 3 h, the neuron-like cells were identified by the immunocytochemical staining, reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and Western blotting.The two induced cells both displayed neuronal morphologies with long and multipolar cell projections, but BDNF-induced cells survived for a longer time than beta-ME-induced ones. The results of immunocytochemical staining showed that the two neuron-like cells expressed nestin, neuron-specific enolase (NSE), neurofilament (NF), microtubule-associated protein (MAP-2), but not glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). RT-PCR detected mRNA-positive NSE, NF and MAP-2 in the induced cells, with also mild positive GFAP mRNA. Western blotting identified also NSE expression in these neuron-like cells.BDNF alone may induce rat MSCs to differentiate into neuron-like cells in vitro, which have longer lifetime to better serve the purpose of transplantation and gene therapy for nervous system diseases.

QT0OIFwg.title: The effect of excess expression of GFP in a novel heart-specific green fluorescence zebrafish regulated by nppa enhancer at early embryonic development.
QT0OIFwg.abstract:
In order to study the impalpable effect of GFP in homozygous heart-specific GFP-positive zebrafish during the early stage,
 the researchers analyzed the heart function of morphology and physiology at the first 3 days after fertilization. This zebrafish
 line was produced by a large-scale Tol2 transposon mediated enhancer trap screen that generated a transgenic zebrafish with
 a heart-specific expression of green fluorescent protein (GFP)-tagged under control of the nppa enhancer. In situ hybridization experiments showed that the nppa:GFP line faithfully recapitulated both the spatial and temporal expressions of the endogenous nppa. Green fluorescence was intensively and specifically expressed in the myocardial cells located both in the heart chambers
 and in the atrioventricular canal. The embryonic heart of nppa:GFP line developed normally compared with those in the wild type. There was no difference between the nappa:GFP and wild type lines with respect to heart rate, overall size, ejection volume, and fractional shortening. Thus the excess
 expression of GFP in this transgenic line seemed to exert no detrimental effects on zebrafish hearts during the early stages.

Jnms8F7x.title: Oxidative stress mediated by lipid metabolism contributes to high glucose-induced senescence in retinal pigment epithelium.
Jnms8F7x.abstract: Retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) dysfunction is thought to increase the risk of the development and progression of diabetic retinopathy (DR), the leading cause of blindness. However, the molecular mechanism behind high glucose-induced RPE cell damage is still blurred. We reported that ARPE-19 exposed to 25mM glucose for 48h did not induce apoptosis, but senescence validated by SA-β-Gal staining, p21 expression and cell cycle distribution. High glucose also increased oxidant species that exerted a pivotal role in senescence, which could be relieved by the treatment with antioxidant N-acetylcysteine (NAC). The accumulation of lipid droplets and the increase of lipid oxidation were also observed in ARPE-19 treated with high glucose. And the supplementation of free fatty acids (FFAs) indicated that lipid metabolism was associated with the generation of hydrogen peroxide (HO) and subsequent senescence in ARPE-19. PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway was shown to be responsible for the accumulation of intracellular lipids by regulating fatty acid synthesis, which in turn controlled senescence. Furthermore, high glucose induced autophagy in ARPE-19 with the treatment of glucose for 48h, and autophagy inhibitor hydroxychloroquine (HCQ) or bafilomycin further aggravated the senescence, accompanying by an increase in oxidant species. Whereas, prolonged high glucose exposure inhibited autophagy and increased apoptotic cells. Experiments above provide evidence that lipid metabolism plays an important role in oxidative stressed senescence of RPE.

jqGqGkWO.title: Dynamic tensile behavior of 5CrMnMo at elevated temperatures
jqGqGkWO.abstract: An experimental technique has been developed for the performance of high temperature, high-strain rate tensile experiments in the self-designed tensile impact apparatus. This technique uses rapid contact heating method to heat the specimen to the desired temperature, thus avoids a significant temperature rise in incident and transmitted bars, and at the same time it is capable of retaining a nearly homogeneous temperature field within the specimen. As an illustration of its application, the high-temperature response of the forging die steel 5CrMnMo at high strain rates has been examined. Stress-strain curves are obtained for this material at strain rates ranging from 230s-1 to 1200s-1 and at temperature ranging from 25 to 600°C, respectively. For comparison, quasi-static experiments are performed over a slightly smaller range of temperatures.

uXFKG4O7.title: Entropy sets, weakly mixing sets and entropy capacity
uXFKG4O7.abstract: Entropy sets are defined both topologically and for a measure. The set of topological entropy sets is the union of the sets of entropy sets for all invariant measures. For a topological system (X, T) and an invariant measure μ on (X, T), let H (X, T) (resp. H μ (X, T)) be the closure of the set of all entropy sets (resp. μ- entropy sets) in the hyperspace 2 X. It is shown that if h top(T) > 0 (resp. h μ(T) > 0), the subsystem (H(X, T), T̂) (resp. (H μ (X, T), T̂)) of (2 X, T̂) has an invariant measure with full support and infinite topological entropy. Weakly mixing sets and partial mixing of dynamical systems are introduced and characterized. It is proved that if h top(T) > 0 (resp. h μ(T) > 0) the set of all weakly mixing entropy sets (resp. μ-entropy sets) is a dense G δ in H(X, T) (resp. H μ(X, T)). A Devaney chaotic but not partly mixing system is constructed. Concerning entropy capacities, it is shown that when μ is ergodic with h μ(T) > 0, the set of all weakly mixing μ-entropy sets E such that the Bowen entropy h(E) ≥ h μ(T) is residual in H μ(X, T). When in addition (X, T) is uniquely ergodic the set of all weakly mixing entropy sets E with h(E) = h top(T) is residual in H(X, T).

ZbqUNzXT.title: The structural and functional changes of heart and the related factors in patients with maintenance hemodialysis
ZbqUNzXT.abstract: Objective To analyze the structural and functional changes of heart and the related factors in patients with maintenance hemodialysis. Methods The echocardiogram was used to observe the heart structure and function in maintenance hemodialysis patients. The characteristics of the patients were analyzed retrospectively. Results In patients for five years hemodialysis,the left ventricle and left atrium were enlarged,left ventricular compliance was reduced than patients for one year hemodialysis. The left ventricle diameter and left ventricular compliance was positively related to with the weight gain,percentage of body weight gain and serum iPTH level during the dialysis,and it was negatively related to inadequate dialysis. The left ventricular systolic function was negatively related toweight gain and percentage of body weight gain during the dialysis,and was positively related to inadequate dialysis. Logistic regression analyses indicated that the independent risk factors for the enlargement of left ventricle and the reduction of left ventricular compliance were weight gain,percentage of body weight gain,serum iPTH during the dialysis and inadequate dialysis,the independent risk factors for the reduction of left ventricular systolic function were weight gain,percentage of body weight gain,serum iPTH during the dialysis and inadequate dialysis. Conclusions In the patients for five years hemodialysis,the left ventricle and left atrium are enlarged,left ventricular compliance is reduced. Weight gain,percentage of body weight gain,serum iPTH during dialysis and inadequate dialysis are the independent risk factors for the structural and functional change of heart in maintenance hemodialysis patients.

a3v7IMJf.title: Supramolecular prodrug micelles based on the complementary multiple hydrogen bonds as drug delivery platform for thrombosis therapy
a3v7IMJf.abstract: To improve the effect of thrombosis therapy, an amphiphilic supramolecular prodrug consisting of diosgenin derivative (theophylline–diosgenin) and uracil-terminated poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG-U) was designed and synthesized successfully. The prodrug could self-assemble into micelles which was not only enhanced the drug solubility but also prolonged systemic circulation. Bleeding time assay confirmed that the micelles have a better antithrombotic activity compared to diosgenin in vivo, and platelet aggregation assay in vitro got the same results. The low cytotoxicity of supramolecular copolymer micelles was confirmed by MTT assay against LO2/HK-2 cells and acute toxicity studies in mice. Based on these results, the supramolecular prodrug micelles are very promising candidates for thrombosis therapy.

tltAJ8W6.title: Advances in epidemiological study of post-traumatic stress disorders among survivors of war trauma
tltAJ8W6.abstract: Post-traumatic stress disorder(PTSD) is a feeling of persecution arising from the exposure to a life-threatening event.PTSD shows three kinds of characteristic syndrome including invasive,evading,and easy-to-wake up syndromes.Numerous literature had been published on the study of the PTSD epidemiology.However,research results varied due to different research subjects and evaluation methods used.A big difference exists among studies on refugees,migrating people,and community population,because these studies are affected by different definition of war trauma,difference in choice of samples,and application of psychological intervention.Therefore,no exact conclusions have been established on the accurate incidence of PTSD in civilians after having endured the trauma of war or mental cruelty.Currently,studies on PSTD are still inadequate.The first reason for this inadequacy is the difference existing between previous studies.In addition,differences also exist between the statistical results of different research groups,as bias existed in sample selection of non-western ethnics and some specific population as study objects.Secondly,the majority of the studies did not set up a control group,thus,the results lacked reliability and universality.The third reason is that more attention should be paid to the impact of nationality and cultural background on the study of PTSD after the war.In summary,a large amount of work should be done in the field of PSTD epidemiology in the future.Therefore,it is very important to look for simple tools for screening and measuring PTSD for the Chinese population,as well as studying the incidence of PTSD after all kinds of traumatic events and its distribution,in order to effectively prevent and treat PTSD.

ll63YtVs.title: Determination of Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point for Processing of Pot Stewed Duck Neck
ll63YtVs.abstract: In this research,basic principle and method of hazard analysis critical control point (HACCP) was used to analyze the potential hazard from biology and chemistry aspects,which were consisted of the amount of microganism,the content of nitrite,chloride and pH value of pot stewed duck neck,and critical control points (CCP) was also determined during the processing of pot stewed duck neck. The results indicated that CCP included the procedure of cleaning,boiling,packing and sterilization. According to the significant hazards,the table of HACCP plan was set up,which could provide scientific basis for quality and safety control of pot stewed duck neck.

dfUYupaa.title: Exploring the Fecal Microbial Composition and Metagenomic Functional Capacities Associated With Feed Efficiency in Commercial DLY Pigs.
dfUYupaa.abstract: Gut microbiota has indispensable roles in nutrient digestion and energy harvesting, especially in processing the indigestible components of dietary polysaccharides. Searching for the microbial taxa and functional capacity of the gut microbiome associated with feed efficiency (FE) can provide important knowledge to increase profitability and sustainability of the swine industry. In the current study, we performed a comparative analysis of the fecal microbiota in 50 commercial Duroc × (Landrace × Yorkshire) (DLY) pigs with polarizing FE using 16S rRNA gene sequencing and shotgun metagenomic sequencing. There was a different microbial community structure in the fecal microbiota of pigs with different FE. Random forest analysis identified 24 operational taxonomic units (OTUs) as potential biomarkers to improve swine FE. Multiple comparison analysis detected 8 OTUs with a significant difference or tendency toward a difference between high- and low-FE pigs ( < 0.01,  < 0.1). The high-FE pigs had a greater abundance of OTUs that were from the Lachnospiraceae and Prevotellaceae families and the - and  genera than low-FE pigs. A sub-species  subsp.  could be an important candidate for improving FE. The functional capacity analysis found 18 KEGG pathways and CAZy EC activities that were different between high- and low-FE pigs. The fecal microbiota in high FE pigs have greater functional capacity to degrade dietary cellulose, polysaccharides, and protein and may have a greater abundance of microbes that can promote intestinal health. These results provided insights for improving porcine FE through modulating the gut microbiome.

0LZXD7KG.title: Preparation of ellagic acid from biodegradation of valonia tannin by multi-strain co-cultivation
0LZXD7KG.abstract: Using valonia extract as substrate, 14 strains were cultivated and selected. Effects of single-strain cultivation and co-cultivation of strains on biodegradation of valonia tannin were investigated. It was showed that both bioconversion rate of valonia tannin and yield of ellagic acid would be remarkably increased when co-cultivation of strains 1 # and 3 # was employed. The former is the strain that has faster degradation rate of tannin with weaker tannin with weaker tannin resistance; the later is the one that has stronger resistance to tannin with slower degradation rate. Co-cultivation at 28°C for 8 days results in 68% bioconversion rate of valonia tannin and 23% yield of ellagic acid, which provides an effective way to produce ellagic acid from valonia tannin.

U8KmKil7.title: Effect of Sodium Tripolyphosphate on Properties of Beef Muscle
U8KmKil7.abstract: The effects of soaking in different concentrations of sodium tripolyphosphate solutions and cold storage time on the properties of duck muscle such as color,water-holding capacity(WHC) and TPA parameters were investigated.The results showed that the WHC and TPA parameters of duck muscle were increased by soaking in 3 g/100 mL sodium tripolyphosphate solution.Meanwhile,the total phosphorus residue did not exceed the limit and good eating quality was obtained.

vM4PTI01.title: Changes of Plasma Soluble Vascular Cell Adhesion Molecule-1 in Uremic Patients with Maintenance Hemodialysis and Its Significance
vM4PTI01.abstract: Objective To investigate the changes of plasma soluble vascular cell adhesion molecule-1(sVCAM-1) and its significance in uremic patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis(MHD).Methods Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay was used to measure the plasma sVCAM-1,CRP and sCD40L in maintenance hemodialysis patients(MHD group,n=48) and healthy volunteers(control group,n=22).Results The levels of sVCAM-1,CRP and sCD40L were significantly higher in MHD patients than those in control(P<0.01),and the levels of sVCAM-1,CRP and sCD40L were also higher in MHD patients with coronary heart disease(CHD) than those without CHD(P<0.01).The linear correlation analysis showed that sVCAM-1 level was positively related to CRP(r=0.413,P<0.01) and sCD40L(r=0.368,P<0.05).Conclusion The elevated levels of sVCAM-1 in MHD patients,particularly in those with CHD,suggested the possible relation to the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis.

qQhFMtBH.title: Epistasis dominates the genetic architecture of Drosophila quantitative traits.
qQhFMtBH.abstract: Epistasis-nonlinear genetic interactions between polymorphic loci-is the genetic basis of canalization and speciation, and epistatic interactions can be used to infer genetic networks affecting quantitative traits. However, the role that epistasis plays in the genetic architecture of quantitative traits is controversial. Here, we compared the genetic architecture of three Drosophila life history traits in the sequenced inbred lines of the Drosophila melanogaster Genetic Reference Panel (DGRP) and a large outbred, advanced intercross population derived from 40 DGRP lines (Flyland). We assessed allele frequency changes between pools of individuals at the extremes of the distribution for each trait in the Flyland population by deep DNA sequencing. The genetic architecture of all traits was highly polygenic in both analyses. Surprisingly, none of the SNPs associated with the traits in Flyland replicated in the DGRP and vice versa. However, the majority of these SNPs participated in at least one epistatic interaction in the DGRP. Despite apparent additive effects at largely distinct loci in the two populations, the epistatic interactions perturbed common, biologically plausible, and highly connected genetic networks. Our analysis underscores the importance of epistasis as a principal factor that determines variation for quantitative traits and provides a means to uncover genetic networks affecting these traits. Knowledge of epistatic networks will contribute to our understanding of the genetic basis of evolutionarily and clinically important traits and enhance predictive ability at an individualized level in medicine and agriculture.

Hd5Up58r.title: Study on the synthesis and antitumor activities of diosgenyl saponin derivatives
Hd5Up58r.abstract: OBJECTIVE To synthesize diosgenyl saponin derivatives and preliminaryly study their antitumor activities.METHODS Target compounds were prepared with Vorbrueggen glycation procedures,and the antitumor activities with MTT were studied.RESULTS The compounds were synthesized in a method which is simpler and more efficient than that in literature.And the structures were confirmed with 1HNMR,13CNMR,ESI-Q-TOF-MS and X-ray analysis.CONCLUSION Compound Ⅴ and Ⅶ were found to inhibit the growth of MDA-MB 231.

Iklhs5Vd.title: Structure design and optimization of levelling-tooling with high precision
Iklhs5Vd.abstract: One kind of portable levelling-tooling was described in this paper. The structure of the tooling is simple. Multi-sized columniform optic workpieces could be clamped by this tooling. Levelling technique, which is based on the principle of two-dimensional-angle levelling, is very effectual in avoiding levelling coupling. Thus level surfaces with high precision could be obtained rapidly with the method. In order to solve the problem in practical using, structure of the tooling was optimized. Results showed that after optimization, the using-performance, adaptive-capability and levelling-precision of the tooling were advanced a lot.

Qxde0Xwl.title: Effects of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor on focal cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury in rats]
Qxde0Xwl.abstract: To study the therapeutic effects of granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) on focal cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury in rats.Adult male SD rats were subjected to transient (2 h) middle cerebral artery occlusion (MCAO) and scored 48 h later for such neurological functions as spontaneous movement, paresis, forelimb motor function, climbing ability, pain sensation, and position sense. Twenty rats with the total score less than 12 were divided equally into two groups to receive daily subcutaneous injection of 20 microg/kg of G-CSF for 19 days or the same dose of saline injection (control group). The rats in the two groups were also given intraperitoneal injection of Brdu10 mg/kg for 19 days. The neurological functions of the rats in both groups were examined on a weekly basis after MCAO and on day 21, the rats were killed to prepare frozen sections of the brain tissues for double immunohistochemical staining with Brdu and glial fibrillary acidic protein antibody to identify the neural cells newly evolved from the stem cells.The rats in G-CSF group showed better neurological function recovery than the control rats 3 weeks after MCAO (P<0.05). Obvious regeneration of the neural cells was observed around the infarction area in the rats receiving G-CSF treatment.G-CSF promotes neurological function recovery and neural cell regeneration after cerebral infarction in rats and can be effective for intervention of focal cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury.

i9DGuxB6.title: Deltonin induces apoptosis in MDA‑MB‑231 human breast cancer cells via reactive oxygen species‑mediated mitochondrial dysfunction and ERK/AKT signaling pathways.
i9DGuxB6.abstract: Deltonin, a steroidal saponin isolated from Dioscorea zingiberensis Wright, exhibits high cytotoxic activity in cancer cells. In the present study, the effects of deltonin on cell proliferation and apoptosis were evaluated in the MDA‑MB‑231 human breast carcinoma cell line. Following treatment with deltonin, the viability of MDA‑MB‑231 cells was analyzed using MTT assay and apoptosis, mitochondrial membrane potential (∆Ψm) alternation and intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation was determined by flow cytometry. In addition, western blot analysis was performed to examine the expression of apoptosis‑associated proteins. The results demonstrated that deltonin induced apoptosis in MDA‑MB‑231 cells in a time‑ and concentration‑dependent manner. Apoptosis was associated with depolarization of ∆Ψm and time‑dependent ROS generation. Deltonin treatment also resulted in Bax upregulation, Bcl-2 downregulation, activation of caspase‑3 and ‑8 and poly (ADP ribose) polymerase cleavage. Decreased levels of phosphorylated extracellular signal‑regulated kinase (ERK) and phosphorylated AKT were also observed. Results indicate that the proliferation inhibitory effect of deltonin is associated with its apoptosis‑inducing effect, which may correlate with ROS‑mediated mitochondrial dysfunction as well as activation of the ERK/AKT signaling pathways. Therefore, deltonin may be a potential chemotherapeutic agent for the treatment of breast cancer.

zqWETU0d.title: Design of portable leveling-tooling with high rigidity
zqWETU0d.abstract: One kind of portable leveling-tooling was described in this paper.With the help of vacuum adsorption or mechanical clamping,multi-sized circular or quadrate optic workpieces could be clamped firmly by this tooling.The leveling principle of the tooling is based on rise-leveling technology,which is very effectual in avoiding leveling coupling.The precision of leveling is high and the speed is very fast.Static and dynamic performance of the tooling was studied by simulation,the result showed that the rigidity of this tooling was high,which could explain the leveling-tooling had the strong ability of resisting distortion.

Z232lsLn.title: Effect of strain rate on the mechanical behaviors of SiC fiber
Z232lsLn.abstract: In the present paper, tensile experiments of SiC fiber bundles under different strain rates (quasi-static: 10-4–10-3 s-1, dynamic: 200–1200 s-1) are carried out and the corresponding stress-strain curves are obtained. It is found that the mechanical properties of SiC fiber bundles are rate-dependent: the elastic modulus E, strength sb and the failure strain eb remain unchanged under quasi-static condition, while they apparently increase with increasing strain rate under dynamic condition. Based on the fiber bundles model and the statistical theory of fiber strength, a bi-modal Weibull statistical model of the strain rate dependence is adopted to describe the strength distribution of SiC fiber, and the Weibull parameters are obtained by the fiber bundles testing method. Consistency between the simulated and experimental results indicates that the model and the method are valid and reliable.

GUODvbMf.abstract: Iron chloride has been found to be an efficient catalyst for the disproportionation of allylic alcohols, which provides a convenient method for selective transformation of allylic alcohols to alkenes and α,β- unsaturated ketones. VeidA9CL.title: Effect of bone marrow stem cell transplantation on mdx mice at different ages
VeidA9CL.abstract: AIM: To study the effect of bone marrow stem cell transplantation on mdx mice at different ages. METHODS: The bone marrow stem cells of C57BL/6 mice (4 - to-weeks age) were cultured in vitro for 3 days, then injected intravenously into the 6 -week and 8-week aged mdx, which were preconditioned with 7 Gy γ ray. 12 weeks after being transplanted, the mdx mice were studied for the dystrophin protein expression on the skeletal muscle membrane. RESULTS: Three months after transplanted with bone marrow stem cells, about 16% and 7% muscles cells in 6-week and 8-week mdx mice expressed dystrophin protein, respectively. CONCLUSION: 12 weeks after transplantation with bone marrow stem cells of homologous series mice, different amounts of dystrophin protein expressed on the membrane of skeletal muscle cells were observed in different aged mdx mice. Bone marrow stem cell transplantation show more benefic effect for younger mdx mice.

hQYEH2Rd.title: The causes and related factors of hospitalization in elderly patients with maintenance hemodialysis
hQYEH2Rd.abstract: Objective To analyse the cause of hospitalization in elderly patients with maintenance hemodialysis.Methods Fifty-five hemodialysis elderly patients were enrolled.Age,dialysis age,blood pressure,hemoglobin,blood glucose,serum creatinine,serum BUN,serum potassium,serum calcium,serum phosphorus,albumin,cholesterol,triglyceride,LDL,HDL,Ferritin,iPTH and uRR.KT/V were compared between hospitalization group and non-hospitalization groups.The main cause and related factor for hospitalization were reviewed.Results Twenty-four out of 55 patients were hospitalized and they have 38 hospitalizations in observed period.Average hospitalization was 0.69 per patient and hospitalized days were(19.7±9.7)days per hospitalized patients.The main causes of hospitalization were cardiovascular disease and pulmonary infection.Compare with non-hospitalization group,the levels of diastolic pressure,serum BUN,albumin,serum creatinine,HDL,KT/V,URR were lower than those in MHD patients(74.2± 8.6 vs 79.4±10.6,P=0.029)mmHg,(609.0±172.9 vs 779.2±268.9,P=0.002)μmol/L,(16.8±5.8 vs 24.0±7.0,P=0.000)mmol/L,(31.4± 6.2 vs 36.8±4.3,P=0.000)g/L,(1.0±0.4 vs 1.2±0.4,P=0.023)mmol/L,(0.6±0.1 vs 0.7±0.1,P=0.003)(1.2±0.2 vs 1.4±0.2,P=0.011).Stepwise multivariate regression analysis showed the level of hemoglobin,BUN and KT/V were related factors to influence the hospitalization in elderly patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis.Conclusions Infection and cardiovascular disease were the important causes for hospitalization in elderly hemodialysis patient.The level of hemoglobin,BUN and KT/V were related factors to influence the hospitalization in elderly patients undergoing maintenance hemodialysis.

uv0xkXZ6.title: Relationship between Soluble CD40 Ligand Level and Cardiovascular Events in Maintenance Hemodialysis Patients
uv0xkXZ6.abstract: Objective To investigate the relationship between soluble CD40 ligand(sCD40L) level and cardiovascular events in maintenance hemodialysis(MHD) patients.Methods 48 MHD patients were enrolled in this study.Plasma sCD40L and related parameters were measured at the beginning of study.MHD patients were divided in two groups according to sCD40L level above or below the median(154 μg/L).The patients were followed up for 36 months.Cardivascular events(including cardiac failure or acute coronary syndrome) were recorded during the period.Results During the 36 months follow up period,48 MHD patients occurred cardiovascular event 79 times,and 14 patients died(29.2%).Frequency of cardiovascular events and cardiovascular mortality rate were significantly higher in the high level sCD40L group than in the low level sCD40L group(P<0.05).Kaplan-Meier analysis showed survival rate was significantly lower in the high level sCD40L group than in the low level sCD40L group(P<0.05).The sCD40L level(>154 μg/L) was significantly associated with the occurrence of cardiovascular events by multiple Cox regression analysis(RR=5.52,P=0.01).Conclusion The elevated sCD40L level is the independent risk factor for cardiovascular events,and is also an important predictor for prognosis in MHD patients.

ShaMt7R8.title: Phenotypic characterization and genetic dissection of nine agronomic traits in Tokachi nagaha and its derived cultivars in soybean (Glycine max (L.) Merr.).
ShaMt7R8.abstract: By using the soybean founder parent Tokachi nagaha and its 137 derived cultivars as materials, a genome-wide association analysis was performed to identify the single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) underlying soybean yield and quality related traits at two planting densities. Results of ANOVA showed that genotype, environment, and genotype by environment interaction effects were all significant for each trait. The Tokachi nagaha-derived soybean population could be divided into two subpopulations based on molecular data, and accessions in each subpopulation were almost all from the same Chinese province. Relatedness was detected between pair-wise accessions within the population. Linkage disequilibrium was obvious and the level of intra-chromosome linkage disequilibrium was about 8370kb. A total of 40 SNPs with significant signal were detected and distributed across 18 chromosomes. Some SNP markers were located in or near regions where QTLs have been previously mapped by linkage analysis. Nineteen SNPs were identified both in low- and high- density planting treatments, indicating those loci were common and sTable Sixteen SNPs were co-associated with two or more different traits, suggesting that some of the QTLs/genes underlying those identified SNPs were likely to be pleiotropic.

Yyi6tSja.title: An experimental study on the in situ strength of SiC fibre in unidirectional SiC/Al composites
Yyi6tSja.abstract: In order to investigate the effect of strain rate and high temperature exposure on the mechanical properties of the fibre in the unidirectional fibre reinforced metal-matrix composite, in situ SiC fibre bundles are extracted from two kinds of SiC/Al composite wires, which are heat-treated at two different temperatures (exposed in the air at 400 and 600 °C for 40 min after composition). Tensile tests for these two fibre bundles are performed at different strain rates (quasi-static test: 0.001 s −1 , dynamic test: 200, 700, and 1200 s −1 ) and the stress–strain curves are obtained. The experimental results show that their mechanical properties are rate-dependent, the modulus E , strength σ b and unstable strain ε b (the strain corresponding to σ b ) all increase with increasing strain rate. Compared with the mechanical properties of the original SiC fibre, those of the two in situ fibres degrade to some extent, the degradation of the in situ fibre extracted from the composite wire exposed at 600 °C (hereafter referred to as in situ fibre 2) is more serious than that of the in situ fibre extracted from the composite wire exposed at 400 °C (hereafter referred to as in situ fibre 1). The mechanism of the degradation is investigated. A bi-modal Weibull statistical constitutive equation is established to describe the stress–strain relationship of the two in situ fibre bundles. The simulated stress–strain curves agree well with the experimental results.

EVUUiHAw.title: The changes of endothelial cell function and coagulation-fibrinolysis system in maintenance hemodialysis patients with diabetic nephropathy
EVUUiHAw.abstract: Objective To find out the changes of endothelial cell function and coagulation-fibrinolysis system in maintenance hemodialysis(MHD)patients with diabetic nephropathy(DN).Methods The plasma levels of TM,PAI-1,TAT and PAP in 28 DN-MHD,34 non-DN MHD and 40 controls were measured by ELISA.Results (1)The levels of TM,PAI-1,TAT and PAP in both DN group and non-DN group were significantly higher than those in control group,P<0.001.(2)In two MHD groups,the post-HD levels of PAI-1 were obviously lower than pre-HD levels, P<0.001; the post-HD levels of TAT and PAP were significantly higher than that of pre-HD,P<0.001,but there were no significant differences between the two MHD groups.(3)There is significant positive correlation between HD duration and plasma levels of TM in both MHD groups,P<0.05.Conclusion There were dysfunction of endothelial cells and coagulation-fibrinolysis in both DN and non-DN MHD patients and HD may impose the damage.
keywords: Diabetic nephropathy Hemodialysis Endothelial cell function Coagulation Fibrinolysis

AK7zjEFV.title: Ultra-sensitive graphene photodetector with plasmonic structure
AK7zjEFV.abstract: We report a graphene-based photodetector with ultra-high photoresponsivity and wavelength selectivity, targeting at the mid-infrared (MIR) regime. To enhance the spectral selectivity, a gold-grating structure is designed and implemented under the graphene layer to excite surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs). The electromagnetic field with specific wavelength can be guided to and confined within the designed subwavelength structures. The graphene layer contacted by metal is slightly p-type doped due to gold grating, improving the interband transition rate of electrons. The built-in potential established in the contact region facilitates the separation of non-equilibrium carriers generated on graphene layer, leading to a photovoltage. With optimized structural design the photodetector exhibits excellent photoresponsivity of 1 V/μW at the wavelength of 9 μm.

RqCZvdXK.venue: Chinese Journal of Medical Library and Information Science

gWcumj1P.title: Difference in Medical Graduate Education Between America and China:From the Perspective of Science Fair of American Elementary Schools
gWcumj1P.abstract: With the growing number of graduate students in China,more and more students go to developed countries for advanced education and training after graduation.This paper makes an in-depth discussion of differences in medical graduate education between America and China,especially research innovation,academic honesty,funding source,education process and internationalization of graduate education,the role of mentors and academic atmosphere in graduate education.The aim of this paper is to improve the quality of graduate education in our country,keep in pace with the international standard,create a better academic environment and attract more talents.

czymmpk5.title: The Genetic Architecture of Quantitative Traits Cannot Be Inferred from Variance Component Analysis.
czymmpk5.abstract: Classical quantitative genetic analyses estimate additive and non-additive genetic and environmental components of variance from phenotypes of related individuals without knowing the identities of quantitative trait loci (QTLs). Many studies have found a large proportion of quantitative trait variation can be attributed to the additive genetic variance (VA), providing the basis for claims that non-additive gene actions are unimportant. In this study, we show that arbitrarily defined parameterizations of genetic effects seemingly consistent with non-additive gene actions can also capture the majority of genetic variation. This reveals a logical flaw in using the relative magnitudes of variance components to indicate the relative importance of additive and non-additive gene actions. We discuss the implications and propose that variance component analyses should not be used to infer the genetic architecture of quantitative traits.

s8LtO8HO.title: Genetic Basis of Natural Variation in Body Pigmentation in Drosophila melanogaster.
s8LtO8HO.abstract: Body pigmentation in insects and other organisms is typically variable within and between species and is often associated with fitness. Regulatory variants with large effects at bab1, t and e affect variation in abdominal pigmentation in several populations of Drosophila melanogaster. Recently, we performed a genome wide association (GWA) analysis of variation in abdominal pigmentation using the inbred, sequenced lines of the Drosophila Genetic Reference Panel (DGRP). We confirmed the large effects of regulatory variants in bab1, t and e; identified 81 additional candidate genes; and validated 17 candidate genes (out of 28 tested) using RNAi knockdown of gene expression and mutant alleles. However, these analyses are imperfect proxies for the effects of segregating variants. Here, we describe the results of an extreme quantitative trait locus (xQTL) GWA analysis of female body pigmentation in an outbred population derived from light and dark DGRP lines. We replicated the effects on pigmentation of 28 genes implicated by the DGRP GWA study, including bab1, t and e and seven genes previously validated by RNAi and/or mutant analyses. We also identified many additional loci. The genetic architecture of Drosophila pigmentation is complex, with a few major genes and many other loci with smaller effects.
