pk2BLv2Z.title: Effects of heat-treatment and strain rate on the mechanical properties of SiC/Al composite wires—experimental and constitutive modeling
pk2BLv2Z.abstract: In order to investigate the effects of heat-treatment and strain rate on the mechanical properties of SiC/Al composite wires, tensile tests at different strain rates (0.001, 200, 700 and 1200 s −1 ) were carried out on two kinds of SiC/Al composite wires with different heat-treatment (composite wire 1: exposed at 400 °C for 40 min; composite wire 2: exposed at 600 °C for 40 min), and the stress–strain curves were obtained. The experimental results show that both of the two composite wires are rate dependent, their modulus, strength, and unstable strain all increase with increasing strain rate; the rate sensitivity is due to that of both the matrix and the fiber. The heat-treatment temperature also significantly affects the mechanical properties of the composite wire, since the strength of the composite wire 2 is about 42–46% lower than that of the composite wire 1. The mechanism of this effect is discussed. A bi-modal Weibull elastic–plastic coated-fiber-bundles model is established to describe the rate-dependent stress–strain relationship of SiC/Al composite wire, which fits the experimental results well. Keywords A. Metal–matrix composites (MMCs) B. Impact behavior C. Statistical properties/methods Heat treatment 1 Introduction Fiber reinforced metal–matrix composites (FRMMC) have the potential to provide desirable mechanical properties, including high specific stiffness, lower density, high strength, high creep resistance and good oxidation and corrosion resistance. These properties make FRMMC attractive for a wide range of applications in automobile, aerospace and defense industries. For instance, light armoured vehicles, unmanned air vehicles and littoral ships have successfully exploited such composites to reduce overall weight and increase manoeuvrability. Largely driven by these applications, extensive theoretical and experimental studies have been made in recent years to uncover the mechanics and mechanisms underlying the macroscopic behavior of FRMMC [1–3] . There are several methods in FRMMC manufacturing. In one of the most important methods, the pre-form composite wires are firstly made, and then pressed into structures [4] under high temperature. It has been reported that temperature and fiber exposure time significantly affect the properties of the composite wires during the first process [3,5] . So, in order to get a full knowledge of the temperature effect on the final properties of FRMMC, the influence of temperature on the composite wire in the second process will be investigated in the present paper. The mechanical response (such as strength and fracture) of FRMMC, like many other materials, depends on the rate of deformation [6] . In the past decades, the mechanical behavior of FRMMC has usually been characterized in terms of quasi-static loading [7,8] , and the influence of high strain rate on the material has received relatively little attention. However, many structural applications made of FRMMC endure dynamic loading, so a better understanding of the dynamic behavior of such materials is required to provide the basis for more sophisticated design for high rate service. Recently, Zhou et al. [3] studied the tensile behavior of T300/Al and M40J/Al composite wires and their components in a large range of strain rate (from 0.001 to 1300 s −1 ). The results showed that T300 and M40J carbon fibers are strain-rate independent, while T300/Al and M40J/Al composite wires are rate dependent, this is caused by the rate dependence of Al matrix. For the SiC/Al, it has been found that both the original and in situ SiC fibers (fibers which are extracted from the SiC/Al composite wire) are rate-sensitive [9,10] , so the rate dependence of SiC/Al is expected to be influence by both the rate dependence of fiber and Al matrix. The purpose of the present work is to investigate the effects of heat-treatment and strain rate on the mechanical properties of SiC/Al composite wires. The composite wires used in the present paper are Nicalon SiC fiber reinforced Al matrix. Two groups of composite wires, which are exposed in 400 and 600 °C, respectively for 40 min, were tensile tested at different strain rates. The effects of rate dependence of both fiber and matrix on that of the SiC/Al, and the effects of high temperature exposure on the mechanical properties of the SiC/Al are discussed. Meanwhile, a rate-dependent constitutive model is proposed to describe the stress–strain relation of this material. 2 Experimental 2.1 Specimen The two kinds of specimens used in the present study were made by heat-treating a kind of SiC/Al composite wire at two different temperatures. The composite wires were produced by the ultrasonic liquid infiltration method [11] . Then they were exposed in the air at 400 and 600 °C for 40 min, respectively, and cooled down to the room temperature. Hereafter, the composite wires exposed at 400 and 600 °C are referred to as composite wire 1 and composite wire 2, respectively. The as received fiber bundle used to prepare the composite wire was Nicalon SiC fiber bundle, which was produced by Nippon Carbon Co. Ltd, with the trademark NLM202. Each bundle contained 500 fibers and had a cross-sectional area of 8.667×10 −2 mm 2 . The density of the fiber was 2.537 g/cm 3 . The matrix was a commercial pure aluminum (>99.6 wt% purity), and the volume fraction of fiber in the composite wire was 50%. 2.2 Testing method Quasi-static (strain rate: 0.001 s −1 ) and dynamic tensile tests (strain rate: 200, 700 and 1200 s −1 ) were performed at a Shimazu DT-5000 testing machine and a self-designed Split Hopkinson Tension Bar [12] , respectively. The specimen and its connection are shown in Fig. 1 . First the lining blocks (1) were glued on the supplement plate (2) perpendicularly. Then 10 composite wires (3) were put into the slot of the lining blocks in parallel, glued with the blocks by high shear strength adhesive and covered with a metal plate. Finally, blocks were connected to the slots in the ends of incident bar (4) and transmitted bar (5) with the adhesive. The supplement plate was taken off before testing. By controlling the height and the range of input pulse, three groups of tensile impact tests (corresponding to strain-rate of 200, 700 and 1200 s −1 ) for SiC/Al have been conducted. In addition, the quasi-static tensile experiments were performed on the Shimazu DT-5000 testing machine for comparing with the above tensile impact results. The loading speed is 0.5 mm/min and the corresponding strain rate is 0.001 s −1 . The average experimental values and their maximum deviations at different strain rates are shown in Fig. 2 a and b (the symbols E , E 1 , σ s , σ b and US will be defined in the following section). 2.3 Experimental results and discussion The stress–strain curves of composite wire 1 and wire 2 at different strain rates are shown in Fig. 3 . The rear part of the quasi-static stress–strain curves cannot be obtained due to the limitation of the sampling rate. It can be seen that both of the two composite wires are rate dependent, their ‘yield stress’ σ s under high strain rate (the stress corresponding to the ‘yield point’ on the high rate stress–strain curve), strength σ b (the maximal stress on the stress–strain curve), unstable strain US (the strain corresponding to the strength σ b ), initial modulus E (the modulus before the ‘yield point’) and E 1 (the modulus immediately follow the ‘yield point’) all increase with increasing strain rate. Compared with the quasi-static stress–strain curve, a ‘yield point’ can be seen in the dynamic stress–strain curve. Before the yield point, the stress in the fiber is very low and the fiber fracture is negligible, which makes the curve appear linear. After the yield point, the curve exhibits a nonlinear character due to the accumulated fracture of the fibers. The yield point is supposed to be caused by the strain-rate hardening effect of Al [13] . Since the thermal expansion coefficient of the fiber (3.1×10 −6 ) is far less than that of Al (2.0×10 −5 ), the residual thermal stress will certainly exist in matrix and fiber during the high temperature manufacturing process. The quasi-static yield strength of pure aluminum matrix is rather low (about 80 MPa) and the matrix is apt to be tensioned to the plastic deformation state by residual thermal stress during the cooling process. Under tensile impact tests, because of the strain rate hardening effect, the stress–strain curve of aluminum will jump from quasi-static plastic deformation to the high strain rate plastic deformation. During the jumping process, the deformation of aluminum is elastic, as shown in Fig. 4 . That means there will be a new yield point on dynamic stress–strain curves. When using the linear hardening elastic–plastic model [13] to describe the stress–strain relationship of Al matrix under different strain rates, it can be seen that, the modulus of the composite wire before yield point approximately equal to the mean value of in situ fiber modulus [10] and matrix modulus, while the modulus after the yield point approximately equals to the mean value of in situ fiber modulus [10] and matrix strain-hardening modulus (the mechanical properties of the two in situ fibers are shown in Fig. 5 a–c). When comparing the mechanical properties of the two composite wires, it can be seen that there is a sharp decrease in strength when the exposure temperature rise from 400 to 600 °C. The strength of composite wire 2 is about 42–46%% lower than that of composite wire 1 under various strain rates. In order to further investigate the effect of exposure temperature on the composite wires, the as-received SiC fiber and the in situ SiC fiber extracted from the two composite wires were tested [9,10] , and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen the mechanical properties of the two in situ fibers both decrease to certain extent when compared with the as-received fiber, which is probably caused by fiber damage during manufacturing and heat-treatment process [14] . However, the strength of in situ fiber bundle 2 (extracted from composite wire 2) is only about 4.5–11.5% lower than that of in situ fiber bundle 1 (extracted from composite wire 1) under various strain rates, which indicates that besides fiber damage during manufacturing process, other mechanisms which affect the mechanical properties of the composite wire arise during the heat-treatment process. The fracture modes of the two SiC/Al composite wires are shown in Fig. 6 . Wire heat-treated at 600 °C fails in a brittle manner without fiber pullout ( Fig. 6 a), while the failure of the wire heat-treated at 400 °C is typically of the fiber pullout type ( Fig. 6 b). It has been found that in FRMMC the brittle and the fiber pullout modes are corresponding to low strength and high strength of the material, respectively, and this is deemed to be caused by the detrimental effects of the interfacial reactions between fibers and matrix materials [5,16] . Studies on SiC/Al composites [15] showed that the rate of aluminum carbide formation due to interface reactions was directly related to the exposure temperature and could affect the mechanical properties. A high exposure temperature results in the formation of brittle reaction products that governs the failure mechanisms, as the formation of Al 4 C 3 in SiC/Al composites may provide sites for initiation of cracking that may cause composite failure. So it could be concluded that the obvious decrease in the strength of composite wires heat-treated at 600 °C should also be attribute to, at least partly, the activated interfacial reactions. 3 Constitutive modeling According to the coated-fiber-bundles model [17] and the stress–strain curves of the composite wires at different strain rates, an elastic–plastic coated-fiber-bundle model [3] is used to study the constitutive relationship of SiC/Al. In this model, the unidirectional reinforced SiC/Al wire is simplified as a coated-fiber-bundle with N coated fibers, and each coated fiber of length L and cross-sectional area A is made up by a single fiber surrounded by aluminum matrix ( Fig. 7 ). Assume that the coated fiber strength complies with the ‘weakest link’ postulate, i.e. the coated fiber is composed of links with different strength, and the strength of the coated fiber is controlled by the weakest link. Based on the experimental results, the strength distribution of the coated fiber is supposed to comply with bi-modal Weibull distribution (The detailed reason will be discussed in the following section.) [18] . In the present paper, a bi-modal Weibull constitutive model is proposed to describe the rate-dependent stress–strain relationship of the composite wire. The postulates of the model are: • The stress–strain relationship of every coated fiber are elastic–plastic, and the initial modulus and strain hardening modulus of each coated fiber are the same ( E 1 = αE ) ( Fig. 8 ). Coated fiber only fractures in plastic deformation stage and there is no coated fiber fracture occurred before yield point. However, the strength of each fiber is different from others. The coated fiber in the present paper is referred to as ‘elastic–plastic coated fiber’. • The interaction between coated fibers is neglected. As n coated fibers break, the load they carried before fracture is instantaneously distributed equally among the surviving N – n coated fibers, and the stress can be described as: (1) σ = { E ε ( ε < ε s ) [ ( 1 − α ) σ s + E 1 ε ] ( 1 − n N ) ( ε > ε s ) where σ s = Eε s , and for quasi-static condition σ s = ε s =0. The parameters in Eq. (1) are obtained from the stress–strain curves and can be simulated by the following equations: For composite wire 1 α = 0.73 (2a) ε s = 0.00052 ( ε ˙ 200 ) 0.316 E = 115 ( ε ˙ + 1.73 200 ) 0.0232 E 1 = 83.6 ( ε ˙ + 0.27 200 ) 0.0313 For composite wire 2 (2b) α = 0.73 ε s = 0.00038 ( ε ˙ 200 ) 0.361 E = 105 ( ε ˙ + 40.09 200 ) 0.0156 E 1 = 71.5 ( ε ˙ + 34.85 200 ) 0.0338 • The strength of the coated fiber follows the bi-modal Weibull distribution, that is (3) H ( ε ) = n N = 1 − exp { − [ ( 1 − α ) σ s + E 1 ε σ 01 ] β 1 − [ ( 1 − α ) σ s + E 1 ε σ 02 ] β 2 } ( ε > ε s ) where σ 01 and σ 02 are scale parameters, β 1 and β 2 are shape parameters. From Eqs. (1) and (3) , the stress–strain equation of the coated-fiber-bundles can be rewritten as: (4) σ = { E ε ( ε < ε s ) [ ( 1 − α ) σ s + E 1 ε ] exp { − [ ( 1 − α ) σ s + E 1 ε σ 01 ] β 1 − [ ( 1 − α ) σ s + E 1 ε σ 02 ] β 2 } ( ε > ε s ) Eq. (4) is the constitutive equation for unidirectional metal matrix composite wires. Use Ln ( ( 1 − α ) σ s + E 1 ε ) as abscissa, Ln [ Ln ( 1 / 1 − H ) ] as ordinate, and H = n / N = σ / [ ( 1 − α ) σ s + E 1 ε ] for ε > ε s , the Weibull plot can be obtained based on the experimental results, as shown in Fig. 9 . It is shown that the Weibull plots of the coated-fiber-bundle under different strain rates are characterized by competition between two lines. It was reported that if there are several kinds of defects in fiber, it is too rough to describe the strength distribution of fiber with single Weibull distribution [9,10,18,19] . When there are two kinds of defects exit simultaneously, the experiment results on the Weibull plot appear to be bi-linear, as shown in Fig. 9 . It was also reported that the SiC fibers are broken in a brittle manner with two kinds of defects: surface and inner defects [19] . Since the strength distribution of the coated fiber is dominated by that of the in situ SiC fiber, we adopt, in this case, the bi-modal Weibull distribution to describe the strength distribution of the coated fiber. In Eq. (4) , the four statistical parameters σ 01 , σ 02 , β 1 and β 2 of the constitutive equation for the dynamic case can be determined by the regression analysis method [9] with Weibull plot, the results are shown in Fig. 10 . It must be noted that since the integral quasi-static stress–strain curves are not recorded, the upper portion of quasi-static Weibull plot cannot be obtained, so the statistical parameters of the constitutive equation for the quasi-static condition cannot be determined directly by the Weibull plot. In the present paper, an indirect method is used to get these parameters. Considering that β 1 and β 2 stand for the strength dispersion of the coated fibers [3] , we suppose that β 1 and β 2 are independent of strain rate, the average value of β 1 and β 2 under dynamic state are used as the initial values for the estimation of β 1 and β 2 under quasi-static state, then the nonlinear regression method [9] is used to get all the statistical parameters according to the experimental data. From Fig. 10 , it can be seen that the shape parameters change only slightly under different strain rates (with the average value β ¯ 1 = 0.96 , β ¯ 2 = 17.5 for composite wire 1 and β ¯ 1 = 1.18 , β ¯ 2 = 18.1 for composite wire 2), but the scale parameters σ 01 and σ 02 are rate-dependent and cater for the following power function (the relation between strain rate and Weibull parameters is shown in Fig. 10 ): For the composite wire 1: (5a) σ 01 = 5.7 ( ε ˙ + 48.14 200 ) 0.0781 σ 02 = 2.19 ( ε ˙ + 5.47 200 ) 0.0720 For composite wire 2: (5b) σ 01 = 3.02 ( ε ˙ + 55.00 200 ) 0.116 σ 02 = 1.08 ( ε ˙ + 18.46 200 ) 0.0673 Substituting the modulus, yield strain (Eq. (2a) and (2b) ), and Weibull parameters (Eq. (5a) and (5b) ) into Eq. (4) , the simulated stress–strain curves can be obtained ( Fig. 3 a and b). The simulated results consist with the experimental data well. 4 Conclusion 1. SiC/Al composite wire is a strain rate-dependent material, because of the strain rate sensitivity of both the matrix and the fiber. The modulus, strength and failure strain of this material all increase with increasing strain rate. 2. When the exposure temperature rises from 400 to 600 °C, the strength of SiC/Al suffers a great decrease. Besides the strength decrease of in situ fiber during temperature rise, the effect of the interface chemical product between fiber and matrix should be also counted. 3. Based on coated-fiber-bundles model, a bi-modal Weibull elastic–plastic coated-fiber-bundles model has been established to describe macroscopic behavior of the composite wires at different strain rates. The simulated stress–strain curves coincide with the experimental data well. The results show that elastic–plastic coated-fiber bundles model is effective and reliable. l4A3huYg.title: Improved characteristics of 4H-SiC MESFETs with partly P-type doped space layer
l4A3huYg.abstract: 4H-SiC MESFET with partly p-type doped space layer is proposed and the DC and RF characteristics are analyzed in this paper by 2D numerical simulation. The simulated results show that the breakdown voltage is about 56% larger than that of the conventional structure, and the saturated drain current obtained 4.4% enhancement too. The calculated maximum output power density at operation point VGS=-10V, VDS=40V are 10.8W/mm and 6.2W/mm respectively for 4H-SiC MESFETs with the proposed structure and conventional structure. As compared with the conventional structure, RF simulation results show that the MESFETs with partly p-type doped space layer have a 2.7dB gain improvement at 2GHz. ©2009 IEEE.

1P853bU9.title: Stent-graft placement with early debridement and antibiotic treatment for femoral pseudoaneurysms in intravenous drug addicts.
1P853bU9.abstract: Explore the application of endovascular covered stent-graft (SG) placement in femoral pseudoaneurysms in intravenous drug addicts.We evaluated a consecutive series of pseudoaneurysm in intravenous drug addicts treated with SGs from August 2010 to December 2013.15 patients with 16 arterial pseudoaneurysms were enrolled in this study. All were males with a mean age of 36.9 years. Hemorrhage was the most common reason (93.8 %) for seeking medical care, and 3 of these patients were in hemorrhagic shock at admission. All patients received broad-spectrum antibiotics, and debridement and drainage were implemented after SG placement. 7 of the 13 cases which had microbiologic results showed mixed infections, while gram-negative bacteria were the major pathogens. Except for 2 patients, who were lost to follow-up, two new pseudoaneurysms formed due to delayed debridement, and one stent thrombosis occurred, none of the remaining cases had SG infection or developed claudication.SG placement controls massive hemorrhage rapidly, gives enough time for subsequent treatment for pseudoaneurysms due to intravenous drug abuse, and reduces the incidence of postoperative claudication. With appropriate broad-spectrum antibiotics and early debridement, the incidence of SG infection is relatively low. It is an effective alternative especially as temporary bridge measure for critical patients. However, the high cost, uncertain long-term prospects, high demand for medical adherence, and the risk of using the conduits for re-puncture call for a cautious selection of patients. More evidence is required for the application of this treatment.

DI2UL7MS.title: Experimental Study of Immune Protective Effecacy of The Liposomes-encapsulated Recombinant H. pylori Vaccine
DI2UL7MS.abstract: In order to investigate the immune protective efficacy and immune protective mechanism of the lipsome-encapsulated Helicobacter pylori (Hp) recombinant protein vaccines, the oral lipsome-encapsulated vaccines with/without CT were used. Phosphatidyl choline (PC) and cholesterols (Chol) were prepared using reverse evaporation method whose size distribution of folate liposomes was measured by electronic microscopy. BALB/c mice were divided into six groups and immunized by BPS alone, liposome alone, rUreB plus CT, liposome-encapsulated rUreB, liposome-encapsulated rUreB plus CT and liposome-encapsulated (rUreB and rKat) plus CT orally respectively once a week for four weeks. All mice were challenged by alive Hp three times in two weeks after the last immunization and sacrificed in five weeks after the last challenge. Hp was determined by the fast urease test. The bactrerial colonizing density semi-quantitation , the inflammation severity grades and activity grades of the gastric histopathology were observed. IFN-γ and IL-4 mRNA expression of spleen T lymphocyte cell in different groups were studied with RT-PCR. The lipsome-encapsulated vaccines were obtained successfully. The mean size of folate liposome was (0.7 ± 0.2) μm. Protective rates of BPS alone, liposome alone, rUreB plus CT, liposome-encapsulated rUreB, liposome-encapsulated rUreB plus CT and liposome-encapsulated (rUreB and rKat) plus CT were 0(0/11), 0(0/11), 58.3%(7/12), 54.5%(6/11), 63.6%(7/11) and 75.0%(9/12) respectively. Protective rate of rUreB plus CT was equal that of the liposome-encapsulated rUreB group (P > 0.05). Protective rate of liposome-encapsulated (rUreB and rKat) plus CT was significantly higher than that of liposome-encapsulated rUreB plus CT (P < 0.05). The mice gastrically inoculated with the latter four immune antigens had been significantly less infected by Hp and had mild inflammation of gastric tissue (P < 0.05). There was not significant difference among any vaccine group (P > 0.05). After Hp attacked, the level of INF-γ mRNA expression of every vaccine group was significantly lower than that of the PBS and liposome group (P < 0.05) while the level of IL-4 mRNA expression of every vaccine group was significant higher than that of the PBS and liposome group (P < 0.05). There was not significant difference among any vaccine group (P > 0.05). The lipsome-encapsulated vaccines can significantly decrease Hp coloning density and reduce inflammation degree in mouse model. The double- candidate vaccines have more stronger immune protective function against Hp than that of sigle-candidate vaccines. After Hp attack, the mice which infected without vaccine induce a predominant Th1 immune inflammatin response while the mice which have accepted vaccine can induce a predominant Th2 protective immune response.

VWNmgkt0.title: Preparation of functional jelly with extract from the housefly larvae.
VWNmgkt0.abstract: It has been demonstrated that maggots Musca domestica L.are rich in nutrition,and contain many bioactive substances.Using orthogonal L_9(34) and scientific sense evaluation,the best formula for producing jelly was 35% crude extraction from housefly larvae,15% sugar,0.18% citric acid and 1.4% carrageenan.The result revealed that 0.02% ascorbic acid plus 0.02% citric acid was the optimum colour fixative,and 0.04% potassium sorbate was the best preservative.

fsnqDxHK.title: Optimization of ellagic acid production from ellagitannins by co-culture and correlation between its yield and activities of relevant enzymes.
fsnqDxHK.abstract: Aspergillus oryzae was co-cultured with Trichoderma reesei using acorn cups extract containing up to 62% ellagitannins as substrate to produce ellagic acid with relatively high levels of ellagitannin acyl hydrolase, cellulase and xylanase. Ellagitannins concentration, initial pH, T. reesei and A. oryzae during the fermentation were identified as important process parameters effecting ellagic acid accumulation and the enzymes syntheses. These parameters were optimized by uniformity design to determine the optimum condition for ellagic acid production. Under optimum operational condition, ellagic acid yield could be arrived at 24%, when the fermentation run lasted 96h with an initial pH of 4.5, an ellagitannins concentration of 4gl(-1), T. reesei of 3ml and A. oryzae of 3ml. Meanwhile, it was found that the three enzymes activities correlated very well with ellagic acid yield, resulting in model with high coefficient of determination (R(2)=0.98). The results indicate that the mixed culture of T. reesei and A. oryzae is an effective approach to produce an enzyme system of degrading ellagitannins for ellagic acid production.

TusSEuep.title: SmCl3-catalyzed C-acylation of 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds and malononitrile.
TusSEuep.abstract: A recyclable, convenient, and efficient catalytic system for C-acylation of 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds and malononitrile with acid chlorides has been developed, giving moderate to excellent yields under mild conditions. This is the first catalytic example of such reactions. In addition, by applying this protocol as the key step, 3,5-disubstituted-1H-pyrazole-4-carboxylate can easily be synthesized in high yields in a one-pot procedure.

ILYj7Bju.title: Study on the occurrence of fatigue due to military operation among the recruits during training period
ILYj7Bju.abstract: Objective The present work was meant to investigates the relationship between the occurrence of fatigue as a result of military operation and sleep quality of recruits during period of training.Methods The Modified Fatigue Rating Scale(MFIS) and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index(PSQI) were used to conduct the survey of over 500 recruits undergoing basic military training.The aim of the survey was to analyze the relationship of their sleep quality and the occurrence of military fatigue.Results The mean fatigue score of the 500 recruits was 23.55.The physical fatigue score was 12.52,which was obviously higher than that of mental fatigue,which was 11.02(P<0.05).MFIS-13(always feeling muscle weakness),MFIS-21(more frequent or longer rest necessary),and MFIS-10(difficult to keep physical strength for a long period) ranked highest in the 21 items of the MFIS,and all of them indicated physical fatigue.Among the recruits,mild symptoms of fatigue accounted for 51%(255/500),which was the highest percentage.The incidence of moderate fatigue was 4.6%(23/500),and no severe fatigue was reported.Among the participants,the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index was higher than 7 in 190 recruits(38%) and it was reflected as prolonged predormition period,poor quality of sleep.A positive correlation between score of sheep quality and fatigue scores(P<0.05) was found.Conclusions Poor sleep quality of the recruits may be one of causes of the occurrence of fatigue,and the aggravation of fatigue can affect sleep quality.Therefore,the management and regulation of sleep quality of the recruits should be emphasized in order to reduce military fatigue.

qf4rds4g.title: Dihydrodiosgenin inhibits endothelial cell-derived factor VIII and platelet-mediated hepatocellular carcinoma metastasis
qf4rds4g.abstract: Our previous studies have demonstrated that diosgenin and diosgenin derivatives exhibit excellent antithrombotic activity via regulating platelet function and coagulation factor level. Platelets and blood coagulation system are highly associated with tumor hematogenous metastasis. Therefore, the purpose of this study was to evaluate whether dihydrodiosgenin (dydio) mediated-platelet inhibition or coagulation factor level modulation is involved in hepatocellular carcinoma cell (HCC) metastasis.  Cell viability was examined by MTT and colony formation assays. Platelet aggregation text and morphology were used to assess dydio's role on tumor cell-induced platelet activation (TCIPA). Scratch assay, adhesion assay and Western blot were used to evaluate dydio's role on platelet-mediated metastasis. Western blot and fluorescence detection were performed to clarify dydio's role on endothelial cell (EC) function. The mice lung metastasis model was constructed to investigated dydio's function on coagulation factor and platelet-mediated metastasis.  This study found that pretreatment with dydio caused a significant inhibition of TCIPA. Platelets exposed to dydio significantly inhibited their adhesion to tumor cells, meanwhile, releasates of platelets that pretreated with dydio led to diminished cancer cell proliferation and migration along with the increase of epithelial markers E-cadherin and loss of mesenchymal phenotype. Additionally, ECs pretreated with dydio suppressed factor VIII (FVIII) level which in turn restrained the activation of platelets and the adhesion of cancer cells or platelets to ECs. Interestingly, our study demonstrated that FVIII could promote HCC proliferation. In vivo study revealed that mice intragastrical (i.g.) administration with dydio significantly inhibited the lung metastasis of hepal-6 cells which is highly correlated with the altered platelet function and coagulation level.  Taken together, these results demonstrated that dydio altered platelet function and coagulation FVIII level, resulting in decreased metastatic potential of HCC. Thus, our study reveals that dydio exerts novel mechanisms of antitumor action beside its direct antitumor activity.

GdKBYWfE.title: Change of trehalose,glycogen and polyol contents of the diapausing larvae of Mylabris phalerata (Pallas) (Coleoptera:Meloidae) at different diapausing stages
GdKBYWfE.abstract: Blister beetle,Mylabris phalerata(Pallas)(Coleoptera:Meloidae),natural enemy of Chondracris rosea rosea(De Geer)(Orthoptera:Acridiidae)and important Chinese medicine material,has important economic significance.In this research,influence of diapause duration on trehalose,glycogen and polyol metabolism of the diapausing larvae of M.phalerata was examined.The results indicated that trehalose content in diapause larvae haemolymph,higher than non-diapausing larvae,was increased with the extension of the diapause duration:the maximal was 5.61 μmol/mL,which appeared in haemolymph of larvae diapaused for 5 months.During the diapause,glycogen content showed linear decrease:glycogen content was 0.72 mg/mL early in 0.5 month of diapause,but only 0.1 mg/mL at the end of diapause(5 months).Trehalose content in fat body in diapausing larvae was higher than in non-diapausing larvae,which was three times as high as that in non-diapausing larvae in one month of diapause,and five times as high as that in non-diapausing larvae in 5 months of diapause(2.5 μmol/g fat body).Glycogen content were decreasing during the diapause:in the early and middle period of diapause,glycogen content in fat body of the diapausing larvae was higher than in non-diapause larvae.Polyol in the haemolymph of the diapausing larvae was mainly glycerol,next was sorbitol;but in fat body was mainly glycerol,next sorbitol and a little mannitol.These suggested that diapausing larvae accumulated trehalose and some polyol,but not glycogen.The content of glycogen decreased with the development of diapause.Thus glycogen may offer carbon source for producing trehalose,sorbitol,or glycerol.

YbT2OpF7.title: Plasmon resonance enhanced WS2 photodetector with ultra-high sensitivity and stability
YbT2OpF7.abstract: Abstract   Tungsten disulfide (WS 2 ) has been demonstrated for optoelectronic devices due to its favorable semiconducting band gaps, high stability and higher carrier mobility than other transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs). However, the photoresponsivity of WS 2 -based photodetector is low due to the poor optical absorbance, which limits its application in high-performance photodetection. Here, we show an easy realized method to improve the responsivity of WS 2  detectors by Au nanospheres (NPs). The Au NPs concentrate free space electromagnetic wave efficiently by localized surface plasmon resonances (LSPR), strongly enhance the electric field on WS 2  films. As a result, more carriers are excited with the assistant of LSPR. With optimized design, the detector exhibited several times to ten folds enhancement from near infrared to visible spectrum region, and reach an excellent high responsivity of 1050 A/W at the wavelength of 590 nm. Furthermore, the photodetector showed an excellent temperature stability after annealing at 300  ° C on air environment. The work provides a new way for high-performance and stable photodetector for extreme and harsh environment.

MskY7Qxu.title: Role of Endogenous H_2S in the Accumulation of Extracellular Matrix of the Diabetic Nephropathy
MskY7Qxu.abstract: Objective To explore changes of fibronectin(FN)in the kidney tissues of diabetic nephropathy)(DN)rats,and to study the role of endogenous H2S in the pathological development of diabetic nephropathy.Methods Twenty-eight rats(male,Sprague-Dawley)were randomly divided into four groups:control group,diabetic nephropathy group,DN+NaHS(H2S donor)group and DN+DL-propargylglycine(PAG,H2S synthetase inhibitor)group.Relative location and expression of FN in kidney tissues were measured respectively by Western blotting and immunohistochemistry.Results FN was positive in both the intraglomerular mesangial region and the extracellular matrix(EMC)in kidney tissues of DN group,and its expression level increased significantly.Western blotting:DN group(48 896±779)vs control group(38 531±902),P<0.01.Compared with that of DN group and DN+PAG group,NaHS significantly inhibited the over-expression of FN,Western blotting:DN+NaHS group(42 737±1 196)vs DN group(48 896±779)and DN+PAG group(48 252±1 068),P<0.01.Conclusion Endogenous H2S can alleviate the pathological progression of DN by inhibiting the accumulation of ECM.

ZCyNpLTj.title: Polishing Properties of Cerium Oxide
ZCyNpLTj.abstract: Constituent,microstructure,physical and chemical properties,polishing properties and selection of cerium oxide polishing powders were reviewed and summarized.Physical and chemical interactions between polishing powder and glass surface during polishing process were analyzed particularly.Influences of cerium oxide polishing powders' granularity and its distribution,physical and chemical properties,and their concentration in polishing fluids,as well as additives,on polishing efficiency were determined,which provided technical foundations for right selection and use of cerium oxide polishing powders for optical glasses.

6sqCksgC.title: Open and endovascular surgery for subclavian artery injury
6sqCksgC.abstract: Objective To compare the open and endovascular surgery for subclavian artery injury and traumatic pseudo-aneurysm.Methods Twenty-one patients with subclavian artery injury were enrolled in this study.Of them,12 underwent open surgery according to the site,severity,time,and involved area of their injury,through supra-and sub-clavian incision,sternal midline incision,trans-rib left neck incision,with the following techniques such as vascular wall repair,vascular anastomosis,vascular transplantation,vascular suture and ligation,auxiliary extracorporeal circulation or balloon hemostasis,and 9(1 in failure,4 with hemorrhagic shock,and 2 with traumatic artery occlusion) underwent endovascular surgery.Results The injury was completely healed in all patients.The mean operation time of endovascular surgery and open surgery was 2.1 h and 4.5 h,respectively(P<0.05),and the mean average blood loss was 200 ml and 1 800 ml in two groups,respectively(P<0.05).The hospital stay time of the two groups was 9 and 21.3 d,respectively(P<0.05).The patients were followed up for 4-30 months,during which partial vascular stenosis occurred in 1 patient after repair.The stent patency was 100% with no severe vascular stenosis and occlusion occured.Conclusion Endovascular surgery is a safe procedure for subclavian artery injury and traumatic pseudo-aneurysm with less minimal invasive injuries and complications than open surgery.

7ZEqsHDf.title: Aberrant Activation of Intrarenal Renin-angiotensin System during Kidney Development in Type 2 Diabetic Rats
7ZEqsHDf.abstract: Objective To define the precise patterns of intrarenal renin-angiotensin system(RAS) activities during kidney development in OLETF rats.Methods AngiotensinⅡ(Ang Ⅱ) contents and mRNA levels of RAS components were measured in male OLETF and control LETO rats at postnatal 1,5,14 days and 4-30 weeks of age.Results In both LETO and OLETF rats,kidney Ang Ⅱ levels hit the peak at one day postnatal and decreased age-dependently during the pre-and post-weaning periods.During the pre-and post-weaning periods(1 day-4 weeks),Ang Ⅱ levels and gene expression of RAS components,including angiotensinogen(AGT),renin and angiotensin-converting enzyme were not different between the animals(P > 0.05).In LETO rats,kidney Ang Ⅱ levels further decreased during puberty(from 7 to 11 weeks of age),whereas no further age-dependent decline was observed in the kidney Ang Ⅱ levels in OLETF rats during puberty.At 11 weeks of age,kidney Ang Ⅱ levels,urinary excretion rate of AGT,and mRNA levels of AGT and renin were higher in OLETF than in LETO rats(P < 0.05),while no difference was observed of the blood glucose levels between the animals.Conclusion These data indicated that a lack of proper reduction in intrarenal Ang Ⅱ during pubescent may contribute to the onset and development of diabetic nephropathy in their later life.

d5pV6gjm.title: Haloemodin as novel antibacterial agent inhibiting DNA gyrase and bacterial topoisomerase I.
d5pV6gjm.abstract: Drug-resistant bacterial infections and lack of available antibacterial agents in clinical practice are becoming serious risks to public health. We synthesized a new class of haloemodins by modifying a traditional Chinese medicine component, emodin. The novel haloemodin exerts strong inhibitory activity on bacterial topoisomerase I and DNA gyrase, and not on the topoisomerases of human origin. In principle, it shows remarkable antibacterial activities against laboratory and clinically isolated Gram-positive bacteria, including vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus faecium and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. We further expanded its antibacterial spectrum into against Gram-negative bacteria with the assistance of polymyxin B nonapeptide, which helps haloemodin to penetrate through the bacterial outer membrane. Finally, the therapeutic effect of haloemodin in vivo was confirmed in curing S. aureus-induced keratitis on rabbit model. With distinctive structural difference from the antibiotics we used, the haloemodins are of value as promising antibacterial pharmacophore, especially for combat the infections caused by drug-resistant pathogens.

tKFdxAST.title: Design and Application of Communication Gateway Based on FlexRay and CAN
tKFdxAST.abstract: Different protocol conversion is a regular problem on industrial field data communication networks. In this article, we design a Flex Ray and CAN communication gateway, mainly discussing system design, hardware design and software design in detail. The gateway can realize bidirectional transceiving data on FlexRay bus and CAN bus. It implements a conversion of two different protocols. In addition, the gateway can acquire 0-5 V analog data directly, as well as communicate with supervisory system through RS232 interface. The communication gateway has a wide range of application in industrial control field.

LxDr5AdZ.title: Construction of prokaryotic expression vector of human neuronal pentraxin 2 gene,and expression and purification of its recombinant protein
LxDr5AdZ.abstract: Objective To construct the prokaryotic expression vector of human neuronal pentraxin 2(NPTX2) gene,induce the expression of the recombinant fusion protein in E.coli BL21,and purify the recombinant fusion protein.Methods The pReceiver-M15 plasmid containing full-length cDNA of NPTX2 was digested by restrictive enzyme EcoR I and Not I,and then cloned into the plasmid pGEX-4T-1 which contained the glutathione-s-transferase(GST).After restriction enzyme digestion identification,polymerase chain reaction(PCR) amplification and sequencing,the pGEX-4T-NPTX2 plasmid containing the correct target DNA fragments was obtained and transformed into E.coli BL21(DE3).By restriction enzyme digestion and sequencing,the positive transformed clones were identified.The expression of GST-NPTX2 fusion protein was induced with IPTG,and the products were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting.The proteins were purified through affinity chromatography.Results The results of digestion and sequencing indicated that the recombinant prokaryotic vector pGEX-4T-NPTX2 was successfully constructed.After transformation with pGEX-4T-NPTX2 and induction with IPTG,the recombinant target protein of about 70kD was obtained by SDS-PAGE analysis,which was consistent with our anticipation.Western blotting suggested that the new band was purified recombinant GST-NPTX2 protein and possessed good immunogenicity.Conclusions The prokaryotic expression vector of human NPTX2 gene has been successfully constructed.The GST-NPTX2 fusion protein could be expressed in prokaryotic expression system of E.coli.Purified recombinant proteins are obtained through affinity chromatography,which is helpful for further study.

u4PCAHNh.title: Isolation, characterization and antioxidant of polysaccharides from Stropharia rugosoannulata.
u4PCAHNh.abstract: In this study, polysaccharides from Stropharia rugosoannulata were isolated and purified by macroporous adsorption resin and ion exchange chromatography to produce SRP-1 and SRP-2. Preliminary structural characteristics of SRP-1 and SRP-2 were also investigated. Our results showed that SRP-1 was neutral, while SRP-2 was acidic polysaccharides. The molar ratios of monosaccharides in SRP-1 and SRP-2 were different, but glucose was the main monosaccharide. Both α-type and β-type glycosidic linkages were detected in SRP-1, whereas β-constitution was dominant in SRP-2. Both SRP-1 and SRP-2 had a (1 → 6)-α-D-glucan backbone. Furthermore, the antioxidant activities of polysaccharides against ABTS, DPPH and OH radicals were determined in vitro. The results indicated that SRP-2 had a stronger antioxidant capacity than that of SRP-1. Our results may be valuable with regard to the utilization of polysaccharides from S. rugosoannulata as potential pharmaceuticals.

0g8L9j1w.title: Carboxymethylated modification technology of Poria cocospowder
0g8L9j1w.abstract: Objective To definite the technological parameter of carboxymethylation modified product of Poria cocos,improve the water-soluble ability of Poria cocos and to expand the processing applications of P.cocos in Chinese medicine industry.Methods Taking the P.cocos powder as raw materials,The single-factor experiment of carboxymethylated modification was carried out to gain the greatest degree of substitution.Results Reaction medium,85% ethanol solution reaction temperature,50 ℃,6 h of etherification after 2 h of and molar ratio of alkali/acid controlled in 2.5∶1-3∶1,and the water-soluble ability was improved.Conclusion Using ethanol as reaction medium and method of two steps of alkaline addition to obtain carboxymethylation modified product of P.cocos,the processing characteristics of modified pro-duct could be greatly improved and be used in processing applications.

YsdMzDBv.title: The relationship between MTHFR gene polymorphism and cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases in hemodialysis patients.
YsdMzDBv.abstract: Objective To investigate the relationship between methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) gene polymorphism and cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases (CVD) in hemodialysis(HD)patients. Methods The technology of polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) was used to detect MTHFR gene C677T polymorphism in 74 HD patients and 30 healthy controls. Results Mean age in HD patients without CVD was signifi- cantly lower than that in HD patients with CVD. However, mean levels of serum creatinine in HD patients without CVD were significantly higher than that in HD patients with CVD. The frequency of MTHFR T allele in HD patients with CVD was significantly higher than that in healthy controls (39.6% vs.18.3%, P<0.05). The frequencies of MTHFR TT genotype among HD patients with CVD, HD patients without CVD and control subjects were 20.8%, 12.0% and 6.7%, respectively. There was no significant difference in the distributions of MTHFR TT genotype (P >0.05). Conclusion This study can’t confirm that MTHFR TT genotype is one of the genetic risk factors for CVD occurrence in HD patients.

JoGYZ1xS.title: Selection of Reference Genes for qRT-PCR Analysis in Lentinula edodes after Hot-Air Drying.
JoGYZ1xS.abstract: Volatile sulfur compounds gradually develop in  after hot-air drying, and many genes are involved in the generation of these sulfur compounds. The expression stability of reference genes may vary in a particular experimental treatment when analyzing their expressions by quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR). In this study, the expression profile of 17 candidate genes was assessed in  under treatment at 50 °C for 0, 1, 2, and 3 h, and the expression stability of each reference gene was analyzed by three statistical algorithms, including geNorm, NormFinder, and BestKeeper. Results indicated that the two optimal reference genes for mycelium and fruiting body were  and  as well as  and , respectively. Additionally,  and  were found to be the two most stable reference genes across the mycelium and fruiting body set. Our results will provide a genetic foundation for further research on the metabolism genes of sulfur compounds in .

k8mOgk7P.title: Analyses of the cause of hospitalization and its related risk factors in maintenance hemodialysis patients
k8mOgk7P.abstract: Objective To analysis the cause of hospitalization and its related risk factor in maintenance hemodialysis (MHD) patients. Method A total of 99 MHD patients were enrolled in this study. Age, dialysis age, blood pressure, hemoglobin, blood glucose, serum creatinine, serum potassium, serum calcium, serum phosphorus, plasma albumin, iPTH and KT/V were compared between hospitalization and outpatient groups. The main causes and its related risk factors for hospitalization were reviewed. Result In the observation period for 24 months, 59 out of the 99 patients were hospitalized with a total hospitalization of 106 times, average hospitalization of 1.07±1.22 times/patient and 28.27±24.73 days/patient. The main causes of hospitalization were cardiovascular disease, stenosis of vascular access and pulmonary infection. Patients were older in hospitalization group than in outpatient group (66.6±12.62 vs. 56.63±13.16 years; P=0.00). Serum creatinine and plasma albumin before dialysis were lower in hospitalization group than in outpatient group (For serum creatinine: 804.05±226.01 vs. 954.80±226.35ìol/L, P=0.03; for plasma albumin: 33.13±4.16 vs. 37.30±3.33 g/L, P=0.000). Stepwise multivariate regression analysis showed that hypoalbuminemia and shorter dialysis age were the risk factors for hospitalization in MHD patients. Conclusion The important causes for hospitalization were cardiovascular disease, stenosis of vascular access and pulmonary infection, in which cardiovascular disease was the leading cause for hospitalization in MHD patients.

Lovlhovz.title: Effects of continuous sleep deprivation on cognition,monoamine neurotransmitters and the structure of hippocampus in rats
Lovlhovz.abstract: OBJECTIVE To investigate the effects of 72-hour continuous sleep deprivation on cognition,monoamine neurotransmitters and the structure of hippocampus in the brain stem of rats.Twelve rats were randomly divided into the normal sleep control group and the sleep deprivation experimental group.A sleep deprivation tank was used to deprive the rats of sleep.After 72-h continuous sleep deprivation,a Y-shape electric maze was used to measure the learning and memory of rats,then,levels of neurotransmitters,such as norepinephrine(NE),adrenalin(AD),dopamine(DA),and 5-serotonin(5-HT) were detected in the rat brainstem,and the expressions of NMDA receptor subunits NR1/NR2A and GABA receptor GABAARα1 in the hippocampus of rats were monitored,and the neuronal ultrastructure of the hippocampus was observed with transmission electron microscopy.In Y-shaped electric maze,correct response rate for the animals in the experimental group was significantly lower than that of the control group(P<0.05).The levels of NE,AD and DA for the rats in the experimental group were significantly lower than those of the control group(P<0.05),while the level of 5-HT was higher than that of the control group(P<0.05).The levels of NR1mRNA and NR2A mRNA expressed in the experimental group were significantly lower than those of the control group,while the expression level of GABAARα1 mRNA for the experimental group elevated significantly,when a comparison was made with the control group(P<0.05).In the experimental group,severe swelling,obvious degranulation,cristal lysis and fusion of neuronal mitochondria were marked.Continuous sleep deprivation could significantly decrease the learning and memory of rats,which might be related to the central neurotransmitter synthesis disorders and structural damage of neurons of hippocampus.

yf4shXHi.title: EFFECT OF DIFFERENTIATED BONE MESENCHYMAL STEM CELLS ON NEUROLOGICAL DEFICITS IN RATS WITH STROKE
yf4shXHi.abstract: Objective: To investigate the effect of bone mesenchymal stem cells(BMSCs) induced by brain-derived neurotrophic factor(BDNF) on neurological deficits in the rats with stroke.Methods: The BMSCs were harvested from 6-week-old male Sprague-Dawley rats.Adult male Sprague-Dawley rats weighing 250~280 g with transient middle cerebral artery occlusion were administered with 1×107 BMSCs or BMSCs induced by BDNF in 1 mL phosphate-buffered saline via tail vein at 48 h after stroke.All animals underwent neurological function test on days 2,7,14,21 and 28.Immunohistochemical staining and Western blotting for neuron specific enolase(NSE) were applied.Results: The rats treated with BDNF-BMSCs and BMSCs showed significant improvement of neurological deficits compared to vehicle controls on days 21 and 28(P<0.05),especially,BDNF-BMSCs exhibited remarkable functional recovery compared to BMSCs transplantation alone on day 21(P<0.05).Both BDNF-BMSCs and BMSCs,especially BDNF-BMSCs,upregulated the NSE protein levels.Conclusion: BDNF and BMSCs might contribute to the functional improvement of neurological deficits partly via upregalating NSE expression level.
