Zyhs4Rp6.title: Ultrasonic and fermented pretreatment technology for diosgenin production from Diosorea zingiberensis C.H. Wright
Zyhs4Rp6.abstract: The present study evaluated the efficiency of ultrasonic and fermented pretreatment technology for diosgenin production from Diosorea zingiberensis C.H. Wright (DZW). The optimum extraction conditions were as follows: ultrasonic pretreatment condition, 20 min, 50 kHz, 100 W; fermented pretreatment condition, 30 °C, 3 d and 0.8 g yeast dosages per 100 g raw materials; acidic hydrolysis condition, 1.5 mol/L sulfuric acid, 4 h; petrol extraction condition, 5 h. Under these conditions, diosgenin yield could reach 2.30%. Scanning electron micrographs indicated morphology changes of materials during diosgenin extraction process. UV–vis and GC–MS analysis revealed wastewater from the new approach contained 20 kinds of organic compounds which were mainly acids, esters, ketones and hydrocarbons. The research indicated the new approach could not only increase 42.5% diosgenin yield, recover 81.6% starch and 50.8% cellulose, but also efficiently reduce 69.7% COD, comparing with the conventional approach. Abbreviations COD chemical oxygen demand HPLC high performance and liquid chromatography GC–MS gas chromatography–tandem mass spectrometry UV–vis ultraviolet–visible spectrophotometry t R retention time SEM scanning electron microscopy Keywords Diosorea zingiberensis C.H. Wright (DZW) Diosgenin Ultrasound Fermentation Alcohol Wastewater 1 Introduction Diosorea zingiberensis C.H. Wright (DZW) tuber is one of the widely-used raw materials in the pharmaceutical industry for diosgenin production, a chemical used for the synthesis of adrenal cortex hormone, sex hormone, progestational hormone and anabolic steroid ( Huang et al., 2008; Zhang et al., 2006 ). DZW tubers contain 1–5% saponin, 45–50% starch and 40–50% cellulose. Saponins mainly contain carbohydrate and diosgenin. The carbohydrates which connect with diosgenin by glucosidic bond are: d -glucose, d -xylose, d -galactose, l -rhamnose, l -arabinose, etc. In acidic condition, saponins could be hydrolyzed into diosgenin and monosaccharide. The pathway of the production of diosgenin was represented in Fig. 1 . Previous studies ( Cheng et al., 2009 ) showed that the conventional extraction of diosgenin from DZW tubers predominantly uses directly acidic hydrolysis to decompose saponins contained in DZW tubers by hydrochloric or sulfuric acid. As demonstrated by the previous studies ( He et al., 2006 ), the conventional approach could produce about 1.20% diosgenin with high concentration of COD (about 120 g/L) in the wastewater. In addition, many cellulose and starch of DZW were conversed into sugar and discarded together with wastewater, resulting in wasting of resources. So far, there has been few report of successful technology for diosgenin production, which is economic and eco-friendly. Ultrasound which is often complementary to classical methods is particularly useful in sterilisation, pasteurisation, extraction, emulsification, cleaning, cutting, freezing, thawing and filtration, providing reduced processing time and increased efficiency ( Chemat et al., 2004 ). Ultrasound-assisted extraction is a well-established method in the processing of plant materials, particularly to extract low molecular weight substances ( Hromádková et al., 2002 ) and bioactive substances from plants ( Rodrigues et al., 2007 ). The enhancement on extraction yield by ultrasonic pre-irradiation was attributed to the disruption of cell walls, reduction of the particle size and the facilitation on the mass transfer of the cell content to the solvent caused by the collapse of the cavitation bubbles ( Polade et al., 2009 ). The acoustic cavitation bubble by ultrasound is carried out above 20 kHz. The propagation of ultrasonic irradiation in liquid promotes a series of compression and rarefaction waves. Bubbles grow in successive cycles forming bubbles of cavitation which, at sufficient high power, reach an unstable size and collapse violently. The materials release of heat follows the formation of so-called “hotspots” reaching temperature and pressure limits of 5000 °C and 2000 atm., respectively. When water vapors, dissolved gas and/or organic substances are exposed to these extreme conditions, bond rupture occurs. Then, sonolysis (indicated as Eq. (1) ) generates hydroxyl radical from water dissociation: (1) H 2 O ⟶ Ultrasonic   irradiation H + ⋅ OH In the presence of oxygen, the perhydroxyl radical is also promotion to be formed as follows (Eq. (2) ): (2) H + O 2 → OOH The radicals formed are diffused in the dissolution, simultaneously with the hydrogen peroxide released from the combination of OH and OOH radicals (indicated as Eqs. (3) and (4) ): (3) 2 OH → H 2 O 2 (4) 2 OOH → H 2 O 2 + O 2 During the process, three zones can be described: the cavitation bubble, the supercritical interface and the bulk of the dissolution. For instance, the degradation of volatile compounds is carried out in the gas phase of the cavitational bubble and/or in the interface of the hotspots. Hydrophilic and non-volatile compounds, on the contrary, are principally degraded once the reactive radical species reach enough diffusion mass transfer in the aqueous phase. Several studies ( Méndez-Arriaga et al., 2008; Matthieu et al., 2009; Torres et al., 2007; Song and ŎShea, 2007; Pétrier and Suslick, 2000 ) have shown the decomposition of organic molecules-pharmaceutical, pesticides, dyes, etc. in water by means of ultrasonic irradiation. Scanning electron microscopy data proved that ultrasonic pretreatment facilitated development of microfractures and disruption of cell walls ( Sharma and Gupta, 2005 ). As shown in previous studies ( Hemwimol et al., 2006 ), ultrasonic-assisted extraction has been proven to improve the extraction efficiency by increasing extraction yield and shortening extraction time, comparing to conventional extraction method. However, little information about utilization of ultrasonic pre-irradiation on improvement of DZW processing for diosgenin production is available. The pretreatment on DZW tubers using fermentation ( Liu et al., 2005 ) before hydrolysis could increase diosgenin accumulation. Previous studies ( Wang et al., 2006 ) on the fermented pretreatment on DZW for diosgenin production showed that the extraction yield increased dramatically. In order to improve diosgenin yield, many technologies such as enzyme pretreatment technology, microbial fermentation technology and supercritical fluid extraction for diosgenin production from DZW tubers had been studied ( Lin and Ren, 2005 ). But when these technologies were applied to actual production, there were many insufficiencies ( Qiao et al., 2006 ). In this study, a highly efficient system for diosgenin production from DZW tubers by ultrasonic and fermented pretreatment combined with acidic hydrolysis was developed. The raw materials were ultrasonic pre-irradiated, fermented, acidic hydrolyzed and petrol extracted. The process parameters were studied by single factor test. Furthermore, the wastewater produced by the new technology was treated and fermented to produce alcohol and the finial wastewater was analyzed through UV–vis and GC–MS. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials The dried DZW tubers were kindly supplied by Tianhe Pharmaceutical Company, Yunxi, Hubei, China. These materials were ground by a pulverator (DJ-048 Pulverator, Beijing Huanya Tianyuan Co., Ltd., Beijing, China) and the powder was screened through a 60-mesh stainless steel sieve (0.45 mm). Angel high-temperature resistant and highly-active dry yeast was from Angel Yeast Company, Yichang, Hubei, China. Ninety-eight percent of diosgenin (Sigma, USA), 99.8% absolute ethanol (Merck, Germany), 120 # petrol (b.p. 80–120 °C) and other reagents were purchased from Changzheng Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Chengdu, China. 2.2 The new efficient approach One hundred grams of dry DZW tubers were cut into slices, ground in a pulverator, and then passed through a shaking screen with 60-mesh to remove 10 g of fiber. Ninety grams of screen underflow was soaked in 350 ml water and ultrasonic pre-irradiated when the working frequency under 50 kHz and sonic power at 100 W (varying ultrasonic pre-irradiated time from 20 to 60 min). After ultrasonic pre-irradiation, the materials were held for 1 h. Then about 10 g supernatant fiber was separated out and 100 ml water was employed to wash it. Thereafter, fermented pretreatment was performed in an incubator (varying temperature from 20 to 50 °C, varying time from 1 to 7 d and varying yeast dosage from 0.2 to 1.4 g per 100 g raw materials). After carrying out ultrasonic and fermented pretreatments, acidic hydrolysis was performed in the boiling water bath (varying sulfuric acid concentration from 0.5 to 3 mol/L and varying hydrolytic time from 1 to 7 h). After acidic hydrolysis, the soil residue was separated from filtrate (raw wastewater) by vacuum filtration and washed into neutral using water. Petrol extraction (varying extraction time from 1 to 7 h) was carried out in the 500 ml reflux type Soxhlet column using 350 ml petrol. Extract was collected, filtered and dried. To indicate the efficiency of the new technology, diosgenin, COD and reducing sugar in raw wastewater were determined. In addition, the raw wastewater was fermented to produce alcohol. After fermentation, the COD and reducing sugar in final wastewater were also determined. 2.3 Conventional approach The conventional method could be described as following. DZW tubers were cut into small pieces (<5 mm), dried at 55 °C for 48 h. Dried and ground powder (100 g) was hydrolyzed with 1.5 mol/L sulfuric acid in boiling water bath for 5 h. The soil residue was separated and washed with water until neutral and dried at 55 °C for 12 h. The filtrate was discharged as wastewater. The dried hydrolytic tuber powder loaded in the 500 ml reflux type Soxhlet column was continuously extracted for 6 h using 500 ml 120 # petrol. Extract was collected, filtered and dried. In previous study, the parameters involved in the conventional processing have been optimized. The recovery of diosgenin was determined. Meanwhile, COD and reducing sugar in wastewater were analyzed. 2.4 Alcoholic fermentation The raw wastewater was deep brown in color and of pungent odor. It contained high concentration of COD and reducing sugar and its pH was less than 0.50. In the pretreatment of the raw wastewater, a quicklime dosage of 100 g/L was used as both the neutralizing agent and the precipitating agent and then the wastewater was centrifuged (4000 rpm, 30 min). After centrifuging, the supernatant was extract, and sodium carbonate was used to adjust pH. Fermentation condition was optimized and the best condition was as follows: 30 °C, 3 d, 2 g/L yeast dosage and pH 4.5. After fermentation, alcohol was distilled using Rotary Evaporators (R215, Buchi, Switzerland). 2.5 Chemical analysis HPLC quantitative determination for diosgenin was carried out in the reverse-phase on an HPLC/Diode Array (HP1100, a diode array detector G1513/87311, Agilent Technologies, Wilmington, USA) with detection at 210 nm. Firstly, sample was filtered (0.22 μm), and injected onto a Cosmogel C18 column reverse-phase column (415 cm × 4.6 cm, 5 μm, Agilent Technologies, Wilmington, USA). The mobile phase composition was optimized and the best composition obtained was water–methanol (5:95, v/v). The flow rate was 1.0 ml/min. The diosgenin yield could be computed as follows: diosgenin yield (%) = diosgenin weight (g) after extraction/DZW tuber powder weight (g). Samples were assayed in triplicate and the data were given as mean value ± SD. COD in wastewater was analyzed using COD radiometer (COD-571, Beijing, China) with potassium dichromate colorimetry method. Potassium hydrogen phthalate (A.R.) was employed to prepare standard solution while potassium dichromate (A.R.) was employed to prepare oxidant. When the COD digestion instrument was preheated for 1 h, 2 ml sample and 3 ml oxidant were added to reaction tube. After digestion for 2 h, the reaction tubes were taken out and cooled until room temperature. Then about 1.5 ml sample solution or standard solution was added into cuvette and the concentration of COD was read through the radiometer. Reducing sugar in wastewater was determined according to government standard (GB/T5009.7-2003). Alcohol distilled from the fermented wastewater was measured by alcoholmeter (YBFJ110, Beijing, China). Recovery of ethanol (g) = the solid content of distilled liquid (g/ml) × the volume of the distilled liquid (ml) × the concentration measured by alcoholmeter (%). 2.6 Wastewater analysis 2.6.1 UV–vis analysis Wastewater was diluted and scanned with the UV–vis spectrophotometer (BECKMAN, DU800 nucleic acid/protein analyzer). The wavelength range was from 200 to 800 nm. 2.6.2 GC–MS analysis GC–MS was employed to analyze organic compounds by liquid–liquid extraction using CH 2 Cl 2 (chromatogram pure grade, Fisher Corporation, USA). Before extracting, the wastewater was adjusted to pH 6–7 and centrifuged (10,000 rpm, 15 min) to remove the precipitates. Then 50 ml supernatant was extracted in a separatory funnel using CH 2 Cl 2 and the extraction was repeated three times. The CH 2 Cl 2 phase was collected and dried using nitrogen. The 1 ml pretreated sample was analyzed by 5973N/A2973 GC–MS system (Agilent Corporation, USA). High purity He (99.999%) was employed as carrier gas at the flow rate of 1 ml/min. A DB-MS5 capillary column with inner diameter 0.25 mm and length 30 m was adopted in the separation system. The temperature of the gasification compartment was first set to 40 °C for 5 min, then raised linearly to 280 °C at the rate of 5 °C/min, and maintained at 280 °C thereafter. The electron energy was 70 eV and the electron double voltage was 1050 V. Molecular weight was scanned in the range from 45 to 450 Da. Organic compounds were analyzed with reference to the NIST02 mass spectral library database. Those compounds which covered more than 0.5% of the integration area by GC–MS were taken as the primary organic constituents. 3 Results and analyses 3.1 Studying the conditions of ultrasonic and fermented pretreatment technology for diosgenin production from DZW tuber In the present study, ultrasonic and fermented pretreatment technology was employed for diosgenin production from DZW tubers. Before the study, the main parameters independently influencing diosgenin extraction were investigated as ultrasonic pre-irradiated time, pre-fermentation time, pre-fermentation temperature, pre-fermentation yeast dosage, acidic hydrolysis time, sulfuric acid concentration and petrol extraction time. 3.1.1 Ultrasonic pretreatment condition Ultrasound, having frequency between 20 and 100 kHz, is now well known to have significant effects on the rate of various processes in the analytical laboratory ( Smain et al., 2004 ). Méndez-Arriaga et al. studied the effect of the applied ultrasonic power on the degradation of ibuprofen and concluded that a higher applied power lead to higher degradation rate in almost lineal relationship. Although more than 100 W of applied power should lead to faster degradation, it is not recommendable to exceed this value, because the piezoelectric generator of the ultrasound instrument could be damaged ( Ricardo et al., 2008 ). In this study, ultrasonic pre-irradiation was carried out in a SB5200DTD ultrasonic bath (Ningbo, Zhejiang, China) with a maximum capacity of 5 L when the working frequency was 50 kHz for different times (varying ultrasonic pretreatment time from 20 to 60 min). The output power of the generator was 100 W while the power dissipated in the medium was about 60 W, as measured by calorimetry. Fig. 2 showed diosgenin yield under ultrasonic pre-irradiation for 20, 40 and 60 min. It can be noted that the diosgenin yield under ultrasonic pre-irradiation for 20 min increased by 4.76% when compared with that of non-irradiation. But the diosgenin yields of those which were ultrasonic pre-irradiated for 40 and 60 min, decreased 2.19 and 3.51%, respectively. The result indicated that moderate ultrasound was helpful to release saponins from the fiber package, resulting in increase in diosgenin yield ( Han et al., 2007 ). The enhancement on extraction efficiency by ultrasound can be explained that the collapse of cavitation bubbles during ultrasonic pre-irradiation released enormous amount of energy, which was expected to damage cell walls and resulted in better contact with the extraction medium ( Seong et al., 2009; Aparna and Gupta, 2006 ). During sonication, the cavitation process caused the swelling of cells or the breakdown of cell walls, which allowed high diffusion rates across the cell wall in the first case or a simple washing out of the cell contents in the second ( Vinatoru, 2001 ). However, when the ultrasonic pre-irradiated time was too long, the diosgenin yield decreased. GC–MS analysis indicated the presence of smilagnenone and epi-smilagnenone after ultrasonic pretreatment too long. These results confirmed that ultrasonic pretreatment led to formation of byproducts with low volatility and high hydrophilic character, migrating to the bulk of the solution, and thus, they did not follow a degradation process by pyrolisis or OH attack. As depicted in Fig. 2 , the highest diosgenin yield could achieve 2.36% when the ultrasonic pretreatment was performed for 20 min. 3.1.2 Fermented pretreatment condition The parameters of the fermented pretreatment were investigated including temperatures (varying the temperature from 20 to 50 °C), times (varying the time from 1 to 7 d), and yeast dosages (varying the dosage from 0.2 to 1.4 g per 100 g raw materials). It can be observed in Fig. 3 a that diosgenin yield increased with increasing the yeast dosage. There was an obvious increasing trend when the yeast dosage increased from 0.2 to 0.8 g per 100 g raw materials, while the remarkably increasing trend turned to slight when the yeast dosage reached 0.8 g. As shown in Fig. 3 b, the diosgenin yield could be observed to have a significant increase with increasing temperature from 20 to 30 °C. However, the yield significantly decreased when the temperature was over 30 °C. Fermentation could improve extraction yield was attributed to that glycosidase in the tubers promoted saponins enzymolysis which increased diosgenin accumulation. But higher fermentation temperature could devitalize the glycosidase so that the extraction yield decreased. Fig. 3 c revealed that the diosgenin yield increased with increasing fermentation time. There was an obvious increasing trend in diosgenin accumulation when the fermentation time increased from 1 to 3 d. After that, the increase of diosgenin yield was slight and reached a plateau after fermentation for 4 d, and then appeared a slight decrease after the fermentation for 4 d. This phenomenon is probably because saponins were hydrolyzed into smilagnenone and epi-smilagenone when the fermentation lasting over 4 d. It can be noted in Fig. 3 a–c that the highest diosgenin yield can reach 2.60% when the fermentation was performed at 30 °C for 3 d with the yeast dosage of 0.8 g per 100 g raw materials. 3.1.3 Acidic hydrolysis condition The parameters involved in the acidic hydrolysis process, including sulfuric acid concentrations and hydrolysis time, were investigated in boiling water bath. The effect of sulfuric acid concentration on diosgenin yield was shown in Fig. 4 a . When the sulfuric acid concentration increased from 0.5 to 1.5 mol/L, diosgenin yield increased significantly. However, when the acid concentration increased from 1.5 to 2.0 mol/L, the increase of diosgenin yield was slight and reached a plateau. It can be noted that when the acid concentration exceeded 2.0 mol/L, the diosgenin yield appeared to be a decrease. This might be explained that lower acid concentration led to incomplete hydrolysis while the higher acid concentration resulted in disruption of diosgenin structure, even carbonization. The effect of hydrolysis time on diosgenin yield was shown in Fig. 4 b. The result indicated that the extraction yield increased with prolonging hydrolysis time, while decreased beyond 4 h. GC–MS analysis indicated the presence of yamogenin, yonogenin and tokorogenin after hydrolysis run more than 4 h. Therefore, the decreased yield of diosgenin can be due to the excessive long hydrolysis time. It can be noted in Fig. 4 a and b that the acidic hydrolysis presented the highest efficiency when the process was carried out in boiling water bath for 4 h with 1.5 mol/L sulfuric acid. 3.1.4 Petrol extraction condition Soxhlet extraction was always employed to extract organic compounds. In this study, 120 # petrol was employed as organic solvent to extraction diosgenin from the hydrolysis production. Petrol extraction (varying the time from 1 to 7 h) was carried out after hydrolysis in a 500 ml reflux type Soxhlet column using 350 ml petrol. The effect of petrol extraction time on diosgenin yield was shown in Fig. 4 . The result indicated that the diosgenin yield increased with the increasing petrol extraction time. When the extraction time lasted for 5 h, the diosgenin yield reached a peak, and then began to decrease. This was probably due to thermal degradation of diosgenin structure resulted from the longer extraction. Another reason was that with prolonging the extraction time, some diosgenin volatilized together with the solvent. According to Fig. 5 , the optimal petrol extraction time was 5 h. 3.1.5 Morphology changes of raw materials during diosgenin extraction The morphology changes of the raw materials during the ultrasonic and fermented pretreatment technology for diosgenin production were studied using scanning electron microscopy. Fig. 6 a showed the raw materials, which were non-treated, were tight irregular coupled of starch and cellulose. When ultrasonic pre-irradiated for 20 min, microfractures appeared and the link of starch and cellulose became relaxed, as shown in Fig. 6 b. As mentioned earlier, these changes in morphology were likely to be attributed to the damage of structure due to the cavitation energy. After fermenting for 3 d, most of the starch particle in the raw materials was disappeared as demonstrated in Fig. 6 c. This phenomenon was because the starch was fermented into alcohol and the previous ultrasound pretreatment also intensified this effect. Then nearly all the starch and most of the cellulose of the raw material were hydrolyzed into monosaccharide after acidic hydrolysis, so only several cracked cellulose can be observed in Fig. 6 d. 3.2 Comparison of the new technology with conventional technology The starch and cellulose in DZW tubers was hydrolyzed into sugar and discarded together with the wastewater during the conventional technology for diosgenin production, not only causing serious environmental pollution but also resulting in waste of useful resources as reported by Liu (2001) . In this study, the raw wastewater produced from the new technology was fermented to produce alcohol. The 18.6 ml alcohol could be obtained from the raw wastewater produced by 100 g DZW tuber powder, resulting in 81.6% starch recovery. The cellulose from the new approach was about 20 g (collected from the oversize product when sieving and the supernatant materials from soaked materials after ultrasonic pre-irradiation). The recovery of cellulose in the study was 50.8%, which could be used in many fields of industries and agricultures ( Li et al., 2006 ). Previous studies ( Li and Feng, 1999 ) on cellulose utilization were preparing them into carboxymethyl cellulose by alkalinization and etherification. In this study, the re-utilization of cellulose was not performed and it will be studied in the future research. As about 50.8% cellulose was separated out in the previous process which reduced the resource of sugar and the raw wastewater from the new process was fermented to produce alcohol, the COD and residual reducing sugar in the final wastewater was dramatically reduced. As the results depicted in Table 1 , the utilization efficiency of DZW tubers by the new approach significantly improved, resulting in 2.30% diosgenin, 81.6% starch recovery and 50.8% cellulose recovery with 58 g/L of COD and 16.8 mg/ml of residual reducing sugar in the final wastewater. However, the conventional approach produced 1.26% diosgenin, only production, with 147 g/L COD and 85.9 mg/ml reducing sugar in wastewater. The present work showed that the two byproducts had no adverse effect on either yield or quality of diosgenin. It can be noted that the new approach could more efficiently use natural resources with minimizing the sources of wastewater and pollution during the process. 3.3 Analysis of organic compounds in diosgenin wastewater 3.3.1 UV–vis scanning for wastewater UV–vis analysis showed that organic compounds had strong absorption peak near 280 nm. Absorption within this zone indicated the presence of aromatic structure, aldehydes, ketones, and conjugated unsaturated structure compounds in the wastewater. Since the UV–vis scanning method has limitation in detecting all the contaminants and organic ingredients in the wastewater, further analytic measures should be employed in order to provide more information. 3.3.2 GC–MS analysis for wastewater GC–MS showed the relative abundance of organic compounds in wastewater. It revealed that there were 29 kinds of organic compounds in the wastewater of traditional process while 20 kinds in the wastewater of the new process, as shown in the Table 2 a and b , respectively. The main organic compounds in the wastewater of traditional process were furfural and their derivatives such as 2-furancarboxaldehyde, 5-methyl and 2-furancarboxaldehyde, 5-(hydoxymethyl) which covered more than 60% of the total integration area. Certain other minor compounds, such as tyramine, pyridine, 2-butanone, 4-(4-hydroxyphenyl)- and hexane, 3,3-dimethyl-, which covered less than 0.5% of integration area were not list in Table 2 a. As over 80% starch was conversed into sugar and fermented to produce alcohol, aldehydes were significantly decreased and the mainly organic compounds in the wastewater of new process were mainly acids and ketones such as benzeneacetic acid, 4-hydoxy-3-methy, n -hexadecanic acid, 9,12-octadecadienoic acid, 5-androsten-17-β-ol-3-one, and (1,1′-bicyclohexyl)-2-one. They were much easier to degrade, when compared with the traditional process. It should be pointed out that, due to the limitations of GC–MS method, not all the organic compounds could be identified ( Mondello et al., 2008 ). Further analysis will be carried out in order to explain biodegradation mechanism of the contaminants in our future study. 4 Discussion and conclusions In this study, we have investigated ultrasonic and fermented pretreatment technology for diosgenin production from DZW tubers. As demonstrated by the investigation, the diosgenin yield could achieve 2.30%. The optimal operating extraction conditions, resulting in maximum extraction efficiency, were found to be provided by 20 min sonication time, 3 d fermentation time, 30 °C fermentation temperature and 0.8 g yeast dosage per 100 g raw materials, 1.5 mol/L sulfuric acid concentration and 4 h hydrolysis time, and 5 h petrol extraction time. The final wastewater from the new approach contained 20 kinds of organic compounds, which were less organic in nature and easier to be degraded, when compared with the conventional method. According to the study, the new approach could not only increase 42.5% diosgenin yield, but also efficiently reduce 69.7% COD and recover 81.8% starch and 50.8% cellulose. The research indicated that the proposed system could be a technological-efficient and economic alternative to process DZW tubers in the chemical and pharmaceutical industries. bDVt0qYh.title: Effects of Different Fertilizer Application on Quality and Yield of Tomato
bDVt0qYh.abstract: For increasing and improving quality of greenhouse tomato,the experiment used randomized block design 3 times.It studied the effects of fertilization at different period of swelling fruit on the quality and yield of tomato products under conditions of medium fertility soils with the variety of Jinfenzaoguan as material.The results showed that the best period fertilization in tomato was the bud period.This period of fertilization could increase the fruit hardness,extend storage time,improve the quality of tomato products,also could improve tomato yield per unit area significantly.Treatment 1 could significantly increase the per unit area yield of tomato 20.9%.It could provide the theoretical basis of increasing yield for farmers.

Y6bq1Nys.title: Deficiency of telomerase activity aggravates the blood-brain barrier disruption and neuroinflammatory responses in a model of experimental stroke.
Y6bq1Nys.abstract: Epidemiology and genetic studies indicate that patients with telomere length shorter than average are at higher risk of dying from heart disease or stroke. Telomeres are located at the ends of eukaryotic chromosomes, which demonstrate progressive length reduction in most somatic cells during aging. The enzyme telomerase can compensate for telomere loss during cell replication. The present study sought to investigate the contribution of telomerase to stroke and blood-brain barrier (BBB) dysfunction. Telomerase reverse transcriptase knockout (TERT(-/-)) mice and littermate controls with normal TERT expression were subjected to a 24-hr permanent middle cerebral artery occlusion (pMCAO). The stroke outcomes were assessed in terms of neurological scores and infarct volumes. In addition, we evaluated oxidative stress, permeability across the BBB, and integrity of tight junctions in brain microvessels. Neurological testing revealed that TERT(-/-) mice showed enhanced deficits compared with controls. These changes were associated with a greater infarct volume. The expression of tight junction protein ZO-1 decreased markedly in ischemic hemispheres of TERT(-/-) mice. The brain microvessels of TERT(-/-) mice also were more susceptible to oxidative stress, revealing higher superoxide and lower glutathione levels compared with mice with normal TERT expression. Importantly, TERT deficiency potentiated the production of inflammatory mediators, such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha, interleukin-1 beta, and intercellular adhesion molecule-1, in the ischemic hemispheres of mice with pMCAO. Our study suggests that TERT deficiency can predispose to the development of stroke in an experimental model of this disease.

uOzM4IGa.title: In situ arterialization of the great saphenous vein for the treatment of ischemic lower limbs, report of 88 cases
uOzM4IGa.abstract: Objective To investigate the effects of in situ venous arterialization on extensive artery obliterans occlusion of the lower extremity. Methods Lumbar sympathetic ganglionectomy and one stage in situ arterialization of the great saphemous vein were performed in 104 ischemic limbs of 88 patients with extensive arterial occlusion. Results Eighty-two of 104 limbs were followed-up from 6 months to over 6 years. The intermittent claudication, night pain improved in all cases, with satisfactory wound healing and no swelling of the lower limbs. Conclusions Arterial blood flow through venous conduit improves and reconstructs the blood circulation of the ischemic limbs.

G6lNa46F.title: The early diagnostic value of endoscopic ultrasonography for pancreatic carcinoma
G6lNa46F.abstract: Objective To assess the early diagnostic value of endoscopic ultrasonography(EUS) for the patients with pancreatic carcinoma.Methods One hundred and twenty-six patients were finally diagnosed as pancreatic carcinoma by pathological examination in the institute of gastroenterology,Changhai Hospital of the Second Military Medical University.All patients had been given ultrasonography(US),EUS and spiral CT urography(SCT) examinations half a month before operation.Postoperative reports showed that 28 cases were small pancreatic adenocarcinoma(diameter≤2cm) and 98 cases were adenocarcinoma(diameter>2cm).A retrospective analysis was performed to compare such indexes before and after operation as radiological unusual discovery rate,diagnostic accuracy and indirect signs(abnormal ultrasonography of biliary systems,main pancreatic duct stricture,encroached organs,blood vessels and lymph nodes),unusual rate of US,SCT and EUS for evaluating the early diagnostic value of US for pancreatic carcinoma.Results Combined application of EUS and SCT improved both radiological unusual discovery rate and diagnostic accuracy,which showed significant difference compared with those applied with US,EUS and SCT alone(P<0.05).There was not significant difference between EUS and SCT for assessment of tumor indirect signs such as peri-pancreatic tissues and vascular involved in carcinoma(P>0.05).The diagnostic accuracy of EUS to small pancreatic adenocarcinoma was remarkably higher than that of US and SCT(P<0.05).Conclusions EUS possesses important early diagnostic value for the patients with pancreatic carcinoma.EUS combined with SCT can significantly improve the early screening rate of pancreatic carcinoma.

5HFx9lYJ.title: Deltonin, a steroidal saponin, inhibits colon cancer cell growth in vitro and tumor growth in vivo via induction of apoptosis and antiangiogenesis.
5HFx9lYJ.abstract: Deltonin, a steroidal saponin, isolated from Dioscorea zingiberensis Wright (DZW), has shown high-cytotoxic activity in cancer cells. However, its mechanisms and in vivo anti-cancer effects remain unknown. In the present study, we evaluated the effects and explored the anti-tumor mechanisms of deltonin on a panel of colon cancer cell lines and in a mouse model of murine colon cancer C26. Deltonin had more cytotoxic effect on C26 cells than 5-fluorouracil had, promoting dramatic G2-M phase arrest and apoptosis in C26 cells in a concentration-dependent manner; oral administration of deltonin significantly inhibited the tumor growth and prolonged survival of the tumor bearing mice. The deltonin treatment caused a noticeable apoptosis in tumor tissue, which associated with increased levels of Bax, activated caspase-3, caspase-9, and cleaved poly (ADPribose) polymerase, decreased pro-caspase-8, pro-caspase-9, Bcl-2 expression levels and extracellular signal-regulated kinase-1/2 activity; and dose-dependently inhibit angiogenesis. In conclusion, the findings in this study demonstrated that deltonin is an effective natural agent for cancer therapy, which may be mediated, in part, by induction of apoptosis, as well as involve mitogen-activated protein kinase pathways, and inhibition of angiogenesis.

ijviJDIW.title: Relationship between magnetic susceptibility and grain size of sediments in the China Seas and its implications
ijviJDIW.abstract: Although magnetic susceptibility (MS) of sediments is widely used as an indicator in paleoclimate reconstructions, its significance is unclear in short-term environmental change in muddy sediments on the continental shelves of the Yellow Sea and the East China Sea. In the present study, we found positive and negative correlations between MS and the median grain size (MZ) of fine sediments near the Yangtze estuary and in the North Yellow Sea, respectively. These distinct relationships between MS and MZ depend on sources of materials thus can be used to study changes in material sources of sediments in the South Yellow Sea. According to these relationships, the positive correlation between MS and MZ in the central South Yellow Sea Mud before 1920 AD revealed the impact of materials from the Yangtze River; and the negative correlation after 1920 AD could be attributed to the changes of location of the Yangtze trunk stream to the sea. The inference of the geological change around 1920 AD was also supported by the abrupt change in trends of TOC/TN ratio. ? 2013 Elsevier Ltd.

qSkieUJX.title: The experience of endovascular treatment for chronic total occlusion of iliac-femoral artery
qSkieUJX.abstract: Objective:To evaluate the efficacy and safety of interventional therapy for iliac-femoral artery occlusion disease,To discuss prevention of complication.Methods:A retrospective study was conducted to review 143 patients who were hospitalized between from March,2006 to May,2010 after vascular imaging and interventional therapy.These patients were treated with percutaneous transluminal angioplasty(PTA) or PTA and implantation of stent in accordance with their TASC type and disease conditions.Results:Of 143 patients(165 involved lower limbs),158 leisions were successfully treated with interventional therapy.The remnant stenosis was no more than 30%.The success ratio of the operation was 96.5%.Conclusion:Interventional therapy is an effective and safe procedure for the treatment of iliac-femoral artery total occlusion disease.

Oerzftb5.title: Purification and characterization of a cadmium-binding protein from Lentinula edodes.
Oerzftb5.abstract: Many organisms possess the ability to produce metal-binding proteins to absorb cadmium. Metallothioneins, an important family of cysteine-rich metal-binding proteins, have been isolated and well characterized. However, Lentinula edodes may have a different type of cadmium-binding protein that contains fewer cysteine residues. In the present study, we purified a cadmium-binding protein from L. edodes (LECBP) by gel filtration and anion exchange chromatography and then identified LECBP by LC-MS/MS. We found LECBP to be a novel cadmium-binding protein which contained 220 amino acid residues but no cysteine residue. LECBP had a high binding affinity for Cd (Ⅱ) with a Kd value of 97.3 μM. The percentages of α-helix, β-sheet, β-turn, and random coil in LECBP were 15.7%, 39.4%, 8.0%, and 37.1%, respectively. In addition, high temperatures and an acidic environment influenced the conformation of LECBP. Our results will thus provide a new perspective to understand the mechanism of cadmium accumulation in L. edodes.

XfSJN4lF.title: Analyses of endothelial cell injury and tissue factor change in maintenance hemodialysis patients with type II diabetes and without diabetes
XfSJN4lF.abstract: Objective To investigate the pathogenesis of endothelial cell injury and coagulation disorder in hemodialysis patients with different primary diseases.Methods Enzyme linked immunosorbent assay was used to measure the plasma soluble vascular cell adhesion molecule-1(sVCAM-1),von Willebrand factor(vWF) and tissue factor(TF) in maintenance hemodialysis patients(MHD group,n=42) and healthy volunteers(control group,n=22).Results(a) The levels of sVCAM-1,vWF and TF were significantly higher in MHD group than in control group(t=-7.809,-6.559 and-16.821,respectively;P =0.005,0.004 and 0.000,respectively).The levels of sVCAM-1,vWF and TF were significantly higher in MHD patients with type II diabetes(2-DM) than those without diabetes(t=-20.605,12.792 and 8.600,respectively;P=0.046,0.032 and 0.047,respectively);(b) Logistic regression analysis showed that sVCAM-1,vWF and TF levels correlated to the presence of 2-DM.(c) vWF level after a hemodialysis session increased significantly as compared to the level before the hemodialysis session(t=-5.943,P = 0.000).TF level increased after a hemodialysis session but without statistical significance(t=-3.558,P =0.205).The differences of vWF and TF levels before and after hemodialysis sessions were insignificant between MHD patients with 2-DM and those without diabetes(t=-3.058,-2.241,-5.931,and-8.439,respectively;P =0.070,0.302,0.085,and 0.155,respectively).The difference of vWF level before and after hemodialysis sessions correlated positively with hemodialysis age(r=0.328,P < 0.05).Conclusion Endothelial cell injury and hypercoagulation state exist in MHD patients with 2-MD as well as in those with other primary diseases.These changes aggravate after hemodialysis especially in those with longer hemodialysis age.

4rfApeQA.title: Prevalence of chronic kidney disease in a rural Chinese adult population: the Handan Eye Study.
4rfApeQA.abstract: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is a worldwide public health problem. The purpose of this study was to investigate the prevalence of CKD and associated factors in a rural adult population in Northern China.This was a cross-sectional study using data from the Handan Eye Study. A total of 5,105 subjects aged >or=30 years were included in this analysis. Spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio was determined. Glomerular filtration rate was estimated with the modified Modification of Diet in Renal Disease equation. CKD was defined by the guidelines proposed by the Kidney Disease Outcomes Quality Initiative. The associations between age, gender, diabetes, hypertension, and kidney damage were examined.Albuminuria and reduced renal function were detected in 16.8 and 0.4% of subjects, respectively. The age-standardized prevalence of albuminuria, reduced renal function and CKD was 14.9% (95% confidence interval (CI) 13.9-15.9), 0.38% (95% CI 0.21-0.55) and 15.2% (95% CI 14.2-16.2), respectively. The prevalence of CKD was greater in women than in men (16.7 vs. 12.9%, respectively, p < 0.001). The increased prevalence of CKD with increasing age was observed in both genders. Older age, female gender, diabetes and hypertension were independently associated with albuminuria. Older age was independently associated with reduced renal function.The prevalence of CKD in the rural Chinese population is relatively high. Factors associated with CKD are similar to those of urban areas in China and developed countries. CKD is a major public health problem in rural China.

ms8EXucy.title: Comparing effects of intravenous and oral iron supplementations and adjustment dosages of recombinant human erythropoietin in renal anemia
ms8EXucy.abstract: AIM:To compare the clinical significant differences of the two adjustment dosages of the re- combinant human erythropoietin(rHuEPO)in hemodialysis(HD)patients with intravenous iron-dextran and o- ral iron-ferrous succinate supplementations.METHODS:Two hundred and sixty patients on maintenance HD with rHuEPO treatment,in addition oral and intravenous iron supplementation,were enrolled in a multi-center, prospective,randomized,controlled trial and divided into two groups.In intravenous group,iron-dextran 100 mg was infused through the veins of end dialyser two times per week for 5 wk,then followed by 100 mg·2 wk~(-1)for 12 wk.In oral group,iron-ferrous succinate 200 mg,po,tid for 12 wk.RESULTS:Two hundred and forty-nine patients completed the trial including 165 patients in intravenous group,and 84 patients in oral group.After 12 wk treatment,mean hemoglobin(Hb),hematocrit(Hct),serum ferritin(SF),transferring saturation(TSAT)in the intravenous group increased significantly greater than those in the oral group((21±s 13)g·L~(-1),0.07±0.03,(334±134)μg·L~(-1),(9±6)%,vs(14±27)g·L~(-1),0.032±0.010,-(9±73)μg·L~(-1),(0±9)%,respectively,P＜0.01).The dosages of rHuEPO used in the intravenous group were much less than those in the oral group((6530±2234)IU·wk~(-1)vs(8839±1922)IU·wk~(-1),P＜0.01). The effective rates in the intravenous group were higher than those of oral group(Hb:73.9% vs 43%,P＜0.01,Hct:78.8% vs 40%,P＜0.01).The rate of adverse reactions were 1.2% in intravenous group and 6% in oral group.CONCLUSION:Intravenous iron-dextran administration is more effective and safe than oral ferrous succinate intake for the treatment of renal anemia in HD patients,and saves the application dosage of rHuEPO significantly.

zP28GOGZ.title: Remediation and mechanisms of cadmium biosorption by a cadmium-binding protein from Lentinula edodes.
zP28GOGZ.abstract: Cadmium bioremediation with metal-binding proteins is primarily conducted using metallothioneins (MTs). However, in the present study, we investigated a non-MT cadmium-binding protein from Lentinula edodes (LECBP) as a remediation tool for cadmium biosorption in E. coli. The results indicated that the expression of LECBP significantly enhanced the cadmium biosorption capacity of transgenic E. coli. The secondary structure and conformation of LECBP were changed after binding with cadmium as evidenced by circular dichroism and fluorescence spectroscopy. The results of Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy indicated that carboxyl oxygen and amino nitrogen atoms were involved in the interaction between LECBP and cadmium. The results further demonstrated that glutamic acid and histidine residues are the potential binding sites. Our results have thus provided new insights into cadmium bioremediation in an aquatic environment.

ynh87aZc.title: Immunomodulatory effects of the extract of Musca domestica larvae on irradiated mice
ynh87aZc.abstract: The immunomodulatory effects of the extract of housefly Musca domestica larvae on irradiated Kunming mice were studied with such indices as the viscera indices,the activity of NK cell,the proliferation of T and B lymphocyte,SOD activity and MDA content assayed.The results indicated that the treatment with the extract consecutively for 18 d increased the mice' Spleen and Thymus indices,the activity of natural killer cell,and the proliferation of T,B lymphocyte.Serum analysis demonstrated that the extract significantly reduced the content of MDA and increased the activity of SOD.The results suggest that the extract of housefly larvae has positive immunomodulatory effects on mice irradiated or not.

zhko7gSW.title: Effects of compound amino acids capsule on the immunological function of naval servicemen
zhko7gSW.abstract: Objective To investigate the effects of the compound amino acids capsule on the immunological function of the naval servicemen during military activity. Methods The subjects included 100 officers and soldiers, whose Modified Fatigue Rating Scale (MFIS) scores were >21 points. The participants were randomly divided into two groups, namely, the amino acids capsule group and placebo group (n=50). Under the condition of military operations, either amino acids capsule (8 kinds of essential amino acids and 11 kinds of vitamins were contained) or placebo capsule was given for 14 days continuously. The humoral immune indices, i.e., IgG, IgA, IgM, and complements C3 and C4, were measured with immunoturbidimetry. The percentage of peripheral blood CD subsets was measured using flow cytometry on the first day and 14th day. Results The levels of IgG, IgM, and complement C3 in the capsule group were significantly higher on the 14th day than on the first day (P<0.05), and no significant difference of their levels was observed in the placebo group. The CD3+CD4+ T lymphocytes and CD3- CD19+ B lymphocytes in the capsule group on the 14th day were higher than those on the first day, whereas the CD3-CD56+NK lymphocytes decreased significantly (P<0.05). There was no significant difference in the placebo group. Conclusion Compound amino acids capsule can improve the humoral and cellular immunological function of naval servicemen.

As5tRpIB.title: The significance of monocyte chemotactic protein-1 and tissue factor in internal arteriovenous fistula thrombus formation in maintenance hemodialysis patients
As5tRpIB.abstract: Objective To investigate the changes of serum monocyte chemotactic protein-1(MCP-1) and tissue factor(TF) after internal arteriovenous fistula operation,and to elucidate the relationship between serum levels of MCP-1 and TF and thrombus formation in the fistula in end stage renal disease patients Method We measured serum MCP-1 and TF by ELISA in 50 patients after internal arteriovenous fistula formation,and then compared serum MCP-1 and TF between patients with thrombus(thrombus group) and those without thrombus(non-thrombus group).Result Serum levels of MCP-1 and TF were significantly higher in thrombus group than in non-thrombus group(P<0.01).Conclusion Serum MCP-1 and TF were significantly higher in patients with thrombus formation in fistula than in those without thrombus,suggesting the close relationship between higher serum levels of MCP-1 and TF and thrombus formation in internal arteriovenous fistula.

RYm9M6st.title: Evaluation of direct digital radiography image quality in dentistry]
RYm9M6st.abstract: To evaluate the quality of direct digital radiograph according to its application in dentistry.1195 patients with dental caries, periodontal diseases, periapical diseases, trauma of teeth or hypodontia were tested with Trophy elitys Radio Visio Graphy(RVG) and the quality of the tests was evaluated at four levels.It was convenient to operate RVG and easy to save the images, which reduced the amount of X-rays. 1587 pictures were taken, among which 92.3% was at level I, 6.3% was at level II,1.14% was at level III and level IV.The quality of the images at different positions is good, which can meet the requirement for clinical diagnosis. However, the radiography receptor should be improved for better images.
